Must see. This was one of the best temples we visited. It's amazing to see the building, culture, and feel the energy at the temples. The monks are cool to see how they follow this old world culture but are talking on a cell phone. What an awesome time.

Magnificent Building. Fabulous temple on the edge of interesting and historic Chinatown. A temple which over the years has been added to and extended. A building the local people are extremely proud of. Not on every tour itinerary but one well worth visiting.

Very peaceful place. It was a very serene and peaceful place. You can almost feel peace coming to you when you just stay there for even 5 minutes. It might be very spiritual for some people but as I don't follow Buddhism so much I don't fell that spiritual.

Golden Buddha wonderful, but experience ok. Was wonderful to see the spectacular Golden Buddha, but the temple seems to be very touristy and is inundated with 1000's of tourists (including ourselves).

Commercial religion. I am very interested in Buddhism. And was disappointed with the way how it works in Thailand. it is very commercial way, for each temple you want to go you have to pay the entrance. But the statue is amazing and it has a very interesting history.

an architectural marvel. located near to china town and the chinese Gate. This temple has the most beautiful golden buddha of sukhothai era. the temple has also interesting display of exhibition on the chinese immigrant from china and its influence over this temple.

Amazing place to visit in Bangkok. We visited this temple on a private tour. It took around 15 minute taxi ride from Bangkok CBD and within walking distance from Bangkok's Chinatown. Interesting history about the golden Buddha statue. The statute itself is breathtakingly beautiful as it is made up of 18kt of solid gold weighing 5.5 tonnes. Dress code is very strict when entering the temple and must be adhered to. Well worth a visit.

Very nice. "But". This is on most peoples hit list, but you must beaware that the heat, the crowds, and the constant approaches by so called guides, and police is a real shame, as you don't need a guide at all.Just get a cab and join the crowds, take some water with you.
Respect the Buddha. This was an amazing place and you get a sense of awe. The art and craftsmanship were amazing and beautiful. The history was fantastic.

A nice and ornately designed temple in traditional thai style. Located comfortably in bangkok and approoachable by ferry or local transport. A must see for people coming to thailand for the first time.

Very calming. Luckily, we arrived quite early, and avoided the inevitable masses. A beautifully crafted Buddha in a relaxed, calming and serene posture, which is transferred to the beholder. Quite amazing. We both felt privileged to be amongst the locals showing their respect.

Made of Gold and you can click photos. This was part of the temple trips we took with family and was worth the visit. Do visit it but as a part of package with the tour organiser as it turns out cheaper under a package

Beautiful and near Chinatown area.. Spectacular golden buddha, the ticketing is a bit strange, temple close to Hualampong Railway Station, take MRT will able to reach, the Railway Station is good photo shooting spot, need to cross 2 road and bridge before we reach the starting of Chinatown, try the duck rice and noodle stall, very good and thumb up, then you take a minute walk and you can see the temple, just not too far turn a right after the temple entrance another 300 meter is the heart of chinatown, remember to try the bird nest soup. I took a tuk tuk back to Hualampong MRT , about 50-80B depends where you pick up the tuk tuk..
Buddha. All buddhas are same. buddhas have been shown in different position, Golden Buddha is massive too. Gives a good calm compose posture and one feel calm to look at.
Temple of Gold. It was eye catching temple where you see the Buddha crowned with gold and people showing their respect toward the Lord, The atmosphere is peace and quiete

Once in a life time. Never miss the opportunity to witness yourself with the huge Buddha statue completely made of gold. It will be equal to 5.5 ton of gold. You can go very close to the statue. No restriction. Entry fee is 40 baht only for the temple. If you want to see the museum then additional 100 applies.
Wonderful!. A very beautiful place well worth the visit. Near the main train station on the edge of Chinatown. A nominal entrance fee is charged.

Golden buddha. Go early as its hot during noon time. Place is big and clean.
Highly recommend for buddist. Able to learn the history of chinatown.

beautiful. well worth the visit a very small entrance fee there is a lift to top but we climbed stairs to get photos unlike reclining budda this one is solid gold fitted trips to both and china town . kings palace jewelry center all in half day trip I so enjoyable day
Peaceful. "Buddha made of 5.5 tons of gold" That's what the tour guide told us. Holy place to visit & make good of your past sins! ;)

golden temple in china town. this temple is in china town and it has a huge golden buddha inside. As I had visited quite a lot of temples in bangkok during my stay so I think maybe it should not be my fav choice.
breath taking. It is incredible to see the Golden Buddha. Its made out of 5.5 tons of gold. Made to perfection. totally enjoyed it

Wow!. 5 tons of solid gold valued at £28 million. Wonder how many rings you could get out of a fingernail... Anyway, it's impressive, and must be seen. Situated just on the edge of Chinatown so combine it with a visit around the area, but check opening hours first so you don't miss out.

Beautiful temple and huge buddha. Photos don't do this temple justice, it is a huge buddha and its unbelievable that it is solid gold. The whole temple is very pretty and catches the sun light. It was a little difficult to find although there were a couple of signs from the train station I did end up asking someone where it was.

Beautiful Golden Buddha. Located on Yaowarat area, the Chinatown of Bangkok.
Nothing very special about this temple except for that golden Buddha statue.
Entrance ticket is THB 40 and you shoud wear proper dress to enter.
After visit this temple, don't forget to explore Chinatown area.

Made of Pure Gold. We went to the Temple of Golden Buddha where a Buddha made of pure gold was located. According to our tour guide, the money spent in making this 5.5 tons of statue came from the people and not from the Government.The place was magnificent. I felt privileged seeing the Golden Buddha with my very own eyes. The place was clean but very crowded so you don't need to stay there very long. I think 30 minutes is enough to see the temple, the Buddha and to take pictures.

Don't Miss This!. This wat was not overcrowded as were the others we visited. We enjoyed the serenity of the wat and our ability to view it from many angles in a quiet, no pushing environment. Lovely and awe-inspiring!
Stunning. Unbelievable golden buddha, very tranquil atmosphere, there is also a museum available which wedding visit good visit to combine with nearby chinatown
Most beautiful Buddha image.. We've seen many Buddha statues but this one is particularly beautiful - made from 5.5 tons of solid gold.

Main Attraction the Golden Buddha. Wat Trimit, the Temple of the Golden Buddha is famous worldwide simply by the weight of the gold on the Buddha image. Now-a-day a visit to the temple become quite difficulty since the Asian are strongly attracted to gold. Hence the tourists from Asia which involved with mass tourism flocked to this famous temple to see the Golden Buddha. So if you are interested in gold, the visit is a must otherwise there are many other temples to visit without fighting the Asian tourists for standing space. If you still like to visit the temple, make it there early after breakfast to avoid the crowd.

Another Buddha, another Temple. I know that it seems a bit harsh to say this but I do wonder why this particular Buddha is one of the most famous as when I saw it, I didn't see anything overly special. I know that it is the world's biggest and that it's over 700 years old which of course is incredible but going off looks alone you wouldn't know this and would therefore find it hard to be intrigued by it. It is centrally located so easy to get to but considering it's importance, I'm surprised that it's not housed somewhere more remarkable as the Buddha's surroundings are sub-standard. At 40 Baht a ticket (approximately AUD $1.50), if you're in the area then of course go and take a look.

Golden Buddha. I love visiting Thailand's many temples. We were on a tight schedule and needed to fit some sightseeing in on our first day in Bangkok. A taxi ride from the Eastin hotel took about 40 minutes in crazy holiday traffic, but only cost 57baht. We were met with local traders jostling for our business, and showing us all sorts of wares before we even tried to climb the stairs, but that's what I love about Thailand. Although the temple was really busy access was well organised. I was very impressed with the Golden Buddha and keenly watched the locals expressing their thanks and offerings and prayers. Do take your camera along as you will get the chance to take lots of photos, enabling you to refuse the many local photographer's and their tacky paraphernalia should you wish to. We arrived an hour before closing time, so were a little rushed.
Busy. Interesting to see how the Chinese settled in Thailand and then history of the Golden Buddha but it didn't seem like it was necessary to pay the 40 baht to see the golden Buddha at the top

Hidden Treasury till 1955-Golden Buddha. One of the most well constructed buddha, the Golden Buddha is made of pure gold and can be disassembled into nine parts but also be put back together smoothly. The Golden Buddha status has experienced quite a few moves after being constructed around the 13~14th century. Not originally housed in Wat Traimit, the status used to be covered in stuccos and plasters. During a move in 1955, the Golden Buddha broke the ropes that were used to lift it and its true materials were discovered. Worth about $250 million USD, the Golden Buddha is a work of art, real treasure and hard to come by.Also enjoyable was the patio area surrounding the temple where one could walk around to take in the view of China Town and enjoy the hard to come by breeze in Bangkok.

Golden Buddha. A Golden Buddha Statue made of 5.5 tons of pure Gold.
Best way to travel is By MRT to Hua Lamphong Station and then take a taxi. Metered Taxi will cost arounfd 50 Baht.According to my view it is the best Buddha statue in Thailand.
Tickets to Golden buddha excluding museum only cost 40 Baht.

If you have to visit only One place, it is this One. Good surprise with the deeply religious ambiance. The Lord Buddha sculpture is a very major work of art. Even scuplted in stone it would be spectacular. But, to use 5,5 tons of gold is out of mind. And, it is still peace inspiring. Dont miss the small Museum explaning the Chinese Thai Community in Bangkok.

A must-see. The temple has the Golden idol of the Buddha (in the attitude of subduing Mara) on the top level. For all its opulence, the sanctum has a quiet ,meditative atmosphere. The idol itself is very impressive and makes you linger. At the ground level there is the other meditation hall, which has a bronze statue of the Buddha and a quiet ambience. Not to be missed on a visit to Bangkok.
awe. We have been wanting to see this temple for a long time , it is world famous , the golden buddha is beautiful , a site that you must see .

Impressive.. We visited this on the day of the King's birthday, a National holiday, so the locals were visiting. Nearby the street vendors were giving free food away so the crowds were huge. Everyone who was Thai were mostly wearing yellow shirts to honor the King so one saw a sea of yellow shirts. It was wonderful. Wear modest dress in respect.

An unusual visit. We just happened to arrive at Wat Traimit during a special festival day. There was chanting that was amplified through a loudspeaker and people all around - really overwhelming for someone unfamiliar with Thai Buddhist culture. The usual tourist tickets were unavailable, but the large room on the lower level of the temple was open. My partner, being braver than me, wandered in with his camera, and I followed him. There were tables full of people who had obviously just finished a meal, people queued up to get a blessing from a monk, and many monks and other people obviously of high rank. We stayed there for almost an hour and found it fascinating.Afterwards, we climbed up the stairs and looked at the Golden Buddha. A quieter experience than some of the other Wats we visited, with many people there to pay their respects.

A place of beauty and real spiritual energy. This Temple is not just a place for a happy snap and a pick. It really is a beautiful place to go and pray, give offering and thanks to the Divine. We found this to be a wonderful place to visit despite the hundreds of tourists flocking by just for a picture or two. At one point I was pushed aside by a fellow Hindu, to my surprise, just so he could get multiple pic of one of the Buddha's within the temple. I stepped aside and waited and then thanked him and said; "is it okay if we pray now" as he finished his last few snap shots. Please remember, this is not just a tourist site, it is a Temple, a place of Worship and Prayer the equal of any shrine for any other faith. The Buddha is Holy to both Buddhists and Hindu's alike so this was a wonderful place to visit for us and the energy and feeling is very peaceful even with all the pushing and shoving of tourists, maybe that explains why I have visited more than once.

Hidden Treasure inside Bangkok . I was there on my last day in Bangkok. The Golden Buddha was beautiful, with its peaceful smile on its face. In addition, the mural painting was amazing, you should look closely on every detail on it. The statue was on the third floor, with another 2 golden statues at the back. They have the museum on the second and first floor. The museum on the second floor was about The Golden Buddha, from the history, making and the relocation. What I liked the most was the Chinese Thai Historical museum on the first floor. They have a complete history on how the Chinese Thai community started and the development of Chinatown until now. I found it interesting, as they set the china town duplicate in the museum from the 18th - 20th century. Highly recommended when you visit Chinatown in Bangkok.
Must visit in Bangkok. Had been to here while our trip to Bangkok, it is must Visit Place with Excellent Golden Buddha Monument.
This is Thailand. For my self this is Thailand - Buddha and all this.As a fan of old culture its well worth a visit to see this Golden Buddha but also the surrounding with the Temples etc

Impressive statue and temple. This is a must see in Bangkok, the delicate glow of the gold statue is something we really admired. The area of the temple is well-maintained, it's definitely worth visiting.
There is a small Chinese temple across the street and the place is really close to China town.

Impressive. This is a small temple with a single star. The Golden Buda!
It's worth visiting though.
The Buda is just amazing.
I was there by 4:00pm and there was not too many people. Pictures are allowed inside.
Impressive Sight. This is a live temple so there are buddist priest in prayer as you look around. The Buddha is impressive. Don't get catch out by the stands outside selling rubbish.

Good place. Had been in Dec,14. One can see golden Buddha statue. Nice place to visit while in Bangkok.
Need to climb some stairs until you see the main shrine.
Average. A bit far away from the Pier. Can take tuk tuk outside the Pier for THB100. Nothing much to see other than the golden Buddha.

Giant gold Buddha. Women must dress appropriately
A watch lady to scold you and don't stand on step at doorway or the attendant will wack your legs .

Peace in Temple. We visited temple in December 2014 in the 1st week. Closing time if 5 PM but better to be latest by 4.30 PM since the entry will be stopped from 4.45 PM. Nice quite and clean. Senior citizens and/or persons with physical disability having trouble to use stairs can avail lift/elevator service free of cost and may ask the helper who are friendly enough.

Gold... gold... and bit more GOLD!. If you hop off the boat buses to the Chinatown exit, you should totally check the Temple of the Golden Buddha! The biggest solid gold statue in the world... cannot go unnoticed! Beauty and gold in the best combination possible!

Impressive Buddha. The Golden Buddha is a Buddha with an amazing history. The temple that houses it is small and simple compared to the others, but the Buddha is most impressive. Not a BBK must see, but a good stop if you have time. Seems like a bit of a tourist trap around the temple- it's a quick stop.

Impressive. This is one of the largest Buddha statues and an early morning trip is quite enjoyable. It's a small temple and you need no more than 15 minutes to go round. The China town and India town are close by but the traffic in mid morning and later during the day gets pretty bad. There is really not much to see or do. Practically every third shop is a gold shop or an eating joint! It took us 30 minutes to drive down a couple of kilometers in the taxi.
Golden Buddha. Not so crowed so more peaceful, a full size Buddha and other things going on. No charge to go in. meet a few local people.

More than just a Golden Buddha. The building of this temple has 3 floors.1st Floor: This temple is situated in China town. This floor is dedicated to the history of Chinese immigrants who migrated to Thailand looking for jobs. There is a lot of interesting billboards and sculptures to see, with many life-size figures of people going about their daily lives in the past. The details from their clothes and facial expression are brilliant, and the different scenes from the markets to living at home are wonderful. There is also some history on the past Kings of Thailand.2nd Floor: This floor is dedicated to the construction and discovery of the buddha. Essentially, when Thailand was at war with Burma hundreds of years ago, they covered the golden buddha with concrete to hide it from the enemies. But during transport and rainy weather, it serendipitously cracked open to reveal the solid gold interior. You should read and view this section first before seeing the buddha in real. 3rd Floor: This floor houses the golden buddha. Weighing 5.5 tonnes, the buddha is estimated to be $250m. Must see.Cost:Foreigners:140B to see all 3 floors. I can't remember how much it cost to see only one but I think its 40B to see just the buddha.

Very beautiful but very large numbers of visitors. This is a very beautiful place but i am not a fan of large numbers of people......still well worth the visit....so much to see that is amazing.....loved looking at the people doing the restoration,,,,,,there are other wats that are just a beautiful and not filled with people

SOLID GOLD. The time off day is important other wise you will be swamped with bus tourists , being early or late is the best I have shown people in the morning and late afternoon , and found the crowds a little less. Great if all the floors are open and if you are lucky this will be so, it depends on what function has been planned for the day,

Not shure why #67 on list. This Buddha must be on the top 5 things to see in Bangkok. Not often that you experience 5.5 tons of gold within a few meters from you. And a very interesting story surrounding this Buddha's history...Once again from me, a must-see. Coenie.
It's ok. It's fun for a day's sightseeing and some nice photos, but the large number of tourists will put you off. You'll see better in Chiang Mai if you go North.

Best Temple to visit. Got a blessing from a monk inside the temple but he seemed a bit distracted even irritated by our presence as he saturated us with his water. Everyone cracked up when his mobile phone rang during the blessing!

Worth the climb up, oh yes siree!. Read the history - its amazing. This was our last temple on our tour and we were dragging our heels on the climb up. But it was so worthwhile making it up there. The Buddha has a mesmeric face and is quite unlike the emerald and the reclining buddha representations. And its all gold!! Although its a fairly new temple (2005) it is serene and traditional in approach and in the bustle of China Town an oasis of calm. DO SEE IT!

ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. After visiting several temples, I was kind of templed out, because I wanted to see other things. However, after visiting this temple, I was amazed at the size and image of this Buddha.It was well worth the trip and I had so much more appreciation for the Temple itself.
must see place in Thailand.. very good place to see.spiritual and architectural combination. one can not miss this temple in thailand visit and it is a lifetime memory.

A modest high-worth temple. Moderate-sized temple with the highest value in the world. The 5-ton 16-foot high Golden Buddha is recorded as a ' sacred object with the highest intrinsic value" worth £37.1 million according to the record in 2003).
The temple is within 20 minute-walking distance from Hua Lamphong MRT Station

Fabulous Buddha. The Buddha is indeed a wonderful sight and the Wat is brilliant when it is glistening in the setting sun but there was a distinct lack of atmosphere in this rather modern temple. Well worth a visit but it just lacked something for us

700 year old Buddha statue. Sukhothai Traimit Golden Buddha doesn't disappoint. Originally completely covered in plaster to protect it from the enemy, this 15 feet tall statue weights impressive 5,5 tons and its price value is even more impressive, £28,5 mil.It's a touristy spot so be prepare for lots of people.You need to be either dropped off as there are limited parking places or visit on foot.You have to take your shoes off in front of the temple and appropriate clothing is required.You can purchase either ticket to the temple or to the museum that's in the same building,children are free. Among all the noise, this is a little oasis that's worthy visiting in Bangkok.

A cultural experience and aesthetic visual. This Wat has a large Buddha made entirely of gold. It is very neat to see. The Wat is open for worship to locals as well, which makes the experience unique. There was also a monk in the temple. There were many people making offerings of all kinds, as you can see at any other Wat. What sets this Wat apart from the many others in Thailand would definitely be the Golden Buddha. If you only see one or two Wats during your visit, make this one of them.

Awsome Architecture. This temple is located near Chinatown and the traffic is terrible. But the architecture of the temple is so marvelously done that you just admire the sheer beauty of the complex and on top of it you see a Buddha statue made out of 5 ton of real Glittering Gold.It is a very serene and sacred place. One feels blessed to be here. Please visit if you are in Bangkok.
The world's largest solid gold statue. Be prepared for a lot of stairs, and to remove your shoes, but it's an amazing site to behold. Don't miss it!
Buddha. it was interesting and the weather held off that day. quite a lot to see in BKK, the tube and boat ride were fun.

A Must See!. Viewing about 5 1/2 tons of solid gold is an awesome sight in itself, but realizing that this was a find resulting from hiding this treasure from invaders in a blanket of concrete and then accidentally having it later discovered in a move makes it all the more astounding! The temple is beautiful and an unforgettable sight of Bangkok. I would also recommend the Emerald Buddha and the Reclining Buddha to round out the visits in a single day!
Stunning. The Buddha is breathtaking as mush of the other architecture is. Much to see, and soak in. GREAT oriental ambience. Best part is that it is off the beaten tourist path
Small Temple. With luxury gold statue but small temple. Need to paid 40baht for visit the temple and another 100bath for exhibition entrance fees.

about bodah. It is in old town in Bangkok and it was near the very good and friendly and cheap hostel I found near this place . Kc guesthouse . Several times meet this place and its wonderful . You must read about this place in Internet before going there . You can not find any info there.

Nice place for tourists. The temple was beautifully decorated due to King's birthday and gave a very pleasing experience. It was still peaceful and cool coconut water being distributed added extra charm. We, a group of ten adults really enjoyed
Wonderful. The history was fascinating. Thanks to our guide from Buffalo Tours we were very well informed. Well worth seeing.
Wat Traimit. We got there accidentally while walking from Hua Lamphong station to Wat Arun. There is small fee for entrance but place is definitely worth a visit.
Huge Buddha. I was surprised by how large this Buddha is considering it is made from 18 carat gold. This is a must see location when visiting Bangkok.

5.5 tonnes solid gold Buddha image- unique in the world. This is a unique Buddha image in the world - made of 5.5 tonnes solid gold. The place around the image has a quiet ambiance. The temple exhibits the typical Thai architecture. One can have a panoramic view of the city from the temple.
huge. A must see in thailand , best to go early as traffic is bad , the temple is world famous and is stunning , the buddha is huge and has great significane for the thais .

Inspiring. This tucked-away temple is well worth seeing. It is awe-inspiring to be in its presence and its history is interesting to witness. Shoes must be removed and you should ask the guardian politely if you wish to take photographs. Cost is minimal, considering the experience.
Temple time. Wicked place. Sucks when it's too hot lol. But such a beautiful place. Great to have look round take in some knowledge

Well worth a quick visit. It will only be a 30 minute trip but it is a pretty spectacular site to see. Apparently it was only discovered in 1955 that the Buddha was pure gold, having been covered in plaster for centuries. At over 12 feet in height, weighing 5.5 tons, the present day value is said to be approximately £30 million!Unlike many temples of height, this one has lifts to the top for those with mobility difficulties. There is a 40 baht (about 80p) entrance fee.

Well worth a visit. This place has one of the best Buddha in Thailand. The story is that the buddha was covered in white plaster and hidden away during the war. They didn't find it for years until someone by accident chip the piece and discover that buddha underneath.

Solid Gold Buddha. I wanted to see the various Buddha sites and this was the last one. It isn't too big, but my guide told me a great story about it. She mentioned in order to protect the 5 1/2 tons of solid gold it had been covered in plaster to protect and hide it! They did a good job, because here it is for us to enjoy.It was very hot at this site.
Well worth a visit. Excellant and unbelieveable. Definitely one not to be missed just such a pity we were rushed around would have like more time to explore the surroundings.

A Golden Buddha. This temple houses a small statue of Buddha made in Gold. Though the statue is not too big but it's beautiful. Lovely statue and placed in a nice temple. You might have to climb some stairs to reach the temple. Though the area surrounding the temple is crowded there's not much crowd inside temple. It's nice and lovely. Do visit.

Found by accident. Hidden in cement for just not be another war treasure for Burma army people hid the Golden Buddha in cover of cement. It was dropped by accident and found with solid gold. Located in China town of Bangkok
Buddha temples. I loved the spiritual home of buddhism & was being practised on our visit. Slightly too many crowds by the time we were leaving but free water was available within the ticket price.
Holy Temple. Interesting to see the fineness of Thai architecture for their temples. This temple is incredible, being generously used gold to highlight the importance of their Buddha.

a nice temple. Don't expect a super big buddha. it's a nice temple with a great history and a different buddha. a gold one. worth the visit. go on sunday and receive the blessing of the monk in front of the temple. it's a little bit too turistic with people selling all kind of stuff but it's worth the try

Golden Buddha. If you love gold, and you love buddha, then this temple you should come and visit!The buddha itself weight about few tons of pure gold. It was being said that olden times the buddha was covered with cement until when they shifted the altar, cracked bit of the cement and they found the buddha was made from gold!Good place to pay respect :) BEWARE OF THE TRAFFIC!
Very interesting. The surroundings. The paintings on the wall of the Central Palace are very beautifyl, interesting and of very good quality.

Impressive!. Recommended. You will enjoy the beauty of the temple, colorful decorations and the view. Of course, make your offers, be respectful and dress appropriately. In Thailand it is disrespectful to wear revealing clothing and you must take your shoes off to enter a temple.

Beautiful temple with historical exhibit. This is one of the smaller temples in Bangkok, but the story of the large, golden buddha that resides there is incredible. The temple also provides two floors of historical exhibits - one about Chinatown, the area in which is resides and another about the golden buddha, which had been masked in plaster for an indefinite amount of time until it accidentally fell from a crane in the mid-1900s and some of the exterior layer broke away to reveal its true form. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Chinatown during the day.

Bless for safety. this temple located near China Town. So after your trip, you can talk to China Town further to experience the Chinese living in BKK.the signature of this temple is Giant Anchient Golden Buddha which people normally come and pray for safety. There's story telling about this sacred place which at past it were fired. But the buddha still remain the same. So people have the strong belief on the sacred Buddha can protect people from harmful and dangerous.

One of Bangkok's TOP 3 MUST SEE'S. A "MUST SEE", one of the top 3 attractions in Bangkok. This elegant Buddha statue is made of several tons of solid gold. Quite old, it was once disguised with plaster in the face of conquering armies, forgotten and rediscovered when it was accidentally broken in transit many years later. Admission is 40 baht for foreigners, and be aware that you have to ascend 3 flights of stairs. There is a lift if you arrange at ticket office.
Must See. Great place to visit for the view over Bangkok. It's free of admission and not far from museums and other must-sees.
Small Wat with a treasure inside. This Wat is not as big as other ones, but inside of it stays the biggest statue of pure gold of a buddha with a size of 3 mts high and 5.5 tons of weight.
A good tourist attraction. This is another one for the trip list if you find yourself in Bangkok with some time to spare. Worth a visit I think and I enjoyed it.
Not worth it!. We walked 6 hours to find this Golden Buddha, really not worth it and a waste of time! It is a plaque on a wall, not what we were expecting!
So far ok. Good: The temple was nice, located near MRT and place have air condition.Bad: Have to buy ticket to go in, dont have enough sign board to assign tourist to MRT station.

Only wheelchair friendly Temple we found in Bangkok. This Temple is comparatively recently built and includes a lift for wheelchairs and those of us who are daunted by flights of stairs. The Buddha is magnificent and the interior of the Temple is less ornate than others we saw but just as beautiful. I note another reviewer wrote that photographing inside the Temple was not allowed. We were not under this impression but then, we may have been mistaken.
Enjoyable Escape. Loved this place. The Golden Buddah is very impressive as were the buildings and surrounding gardens.

Amazing!. This place was certainly worth a visit... The buildings and statues are just amazing - they have to be seen to be believed (particularly as you cannot photograph the Golden Buddha!).Just be careful with fake tour guides (as common everywhere in Thailand), and remember to cover up to be allowed to enter the Temple (or otherwise you can hire robes there).

Dazzling. The temples in Bangkok are like oases in this crowded and noisy city. Wat Traimit is no exception. While the statue itself is dazzling (I don't think i have very seen so much gold ! ), the story is also very interesting. No trip to Bangkok is complete without a visit to this temple.

550 ton of pure gold buddha. Pay 40Baht to see the Golden Buddha . There isn't much in the museum or history floor. Not worth the 100Baht entry fee, golden Buddha is really good just imagine almost all gold of reserve bank of india is there with Buddha
Beautiful temple, but take a walk around chinatown. don't be like most of us, get the tube to Bangkok old station and walk to it, then take a walk around the area and see thai chinatown.

Five and a half tonnes of Gold.. Five and a half tonnes of Gold were used to sculpt this smiling Buddha. Recently it has been placed atop a marble plinth inside a grand white marble edifice all the more accessible for tourists such as myself to gawp at the wonder. After climbing two flights of steep stairs you will see a genuinely beautiful artistic marvel around which the equally beautiful and gracious local Thais still practice their ritual josh-stick sacrifices amidst the jostle of gawping tourists flashing their digital cameras. Everyone seems to make allowances for the others, though in this well mannered society. There is a friendly staff to advise and answer questions, direct traffic flow and to warn that you may not wear your footwear inside on the polished marbles. Now, the elegant Golden Buddha is the purpose of our visit and well worth the trip into the city center to find, but I was caught up with watching the devotions of the Thais who lowered themselves to pray, hands clasped, eyes closed oblivious to the passing and flashing of innumerable tourists. Go on a weekday as we managed for the holidays can become crowded. I stood mesmerized by the elevated golden Buddha's smile. Did the sculptor plan that knowingness , that little gleam which is telling me that he knows that I wish to take more than a digital flash from this place as memento? Avaricious as always I had thought of the tremendous monetary value of five and a half tonnes of nearly pure gold. Then contritely,I put a couple hundred of those Thai Baht in the collection bin to help the monks polish it and keep the grin flashing for those who follow. It was all good clean fun and the view of the city around it is well worth the climb to the top floors, sans sandals and glad of the cool breeze.

A must see. As I've said in a previous reviewIf you see nothing else in BangkokDo the templesGet there earlyBook a taxi to do the 3 Reclining Buddha , golden Buddha and the emerald Buddha at the royal palace

Skip the museum. Pay 40Baht to see the Golden Buddha and go to the next place for sight seeing. There isn't much in the museum or history floor. Not worth the 100Baht entry fee. Save the time and spend in a better place.
Crowd Puller place. A very unique temple with a huge Buddha statue. The temple premise is quite huge and hosts several smaller temples and other sculptures. A crowded yet very peaceful place.

This is a landmark well worth seeing. There is a life sized statue that is made of solid gold. When I was there it was very busy and while I enjoyed the visit and did not feel the need to be there very long, this is partly due to it being a smaller temple, but also I just found some other locations held my interest longer.
A must see. Definitely one of the things to see in BKK and then move onto Chinatown to see a different side of the city
Gold Gold and more Gold. I could not believe it. This is a Buddha with a weight of 5.5 tons and is sold Gold. The building around the complex are also very impressive.

Chinatown's Golden Buddha. We passed on some of the big landmarks of Bangkok and chose to visit this less-crowded temple in Chinatown with YourThaiGuide.com's tour guide, Swai. We took a local river taxi which provided some fresh air and local color. Seeing the solid gold Buddha and hearing its story was wonderful!

unbelievable. this temple is in the heart of the city of Bangkok. the golden budha weighs wround 5.5 ton of gold. the place is so peaceful and the decor and architecture inside is just amazing. must visit place. every wall has stories of bussha depicted on them. most of the decor is glod plated, Its like an unseen bangkok
Golden Buddha. Wow it was a beautiful place to see a must if in Bangkok went by boat there and that was great had a lady sell us drinks on the river from her boat amazing love Bangkok

Lovely temple. Even for a non religious person it is worth visiting a building like this. How clever they have been in the past bulding complexes like this, and there are more impressive temples around!Prepare yourself so you know how to behave inside, and NEVER walk on the doorstep! I have heard the reason for why not, but unfortunately I have forgotten. :-(Anyway. This is a light temple compared to many others. You feel relaxed inside. Be polite and bow in respect the Buddha and the tradition(s) in general.Walk around the bulding and enjoy what must have been a huge time consumption work to make the temple wonderful.

Great start to explore Bangkok. We decide to go here as a start for our Bangkok's Wat (temple) exploration day. It is indeed a massive pure gold Buddha statue! Amazing! Use MRT to Hua Lamphong station and walk about 8 minutes to reach this temple. Rely on Google map! I was on roaming mode on my phone or you can get tourist SIM card for your phone from the Tourist information (left side from the exit door, there's a sign "Tourist information", you can get it free - downside is you have to figure out where to refill the credit and cut the simcard to iPhone 5s size). anyway, finding this temple is easy! getting out from the MRT station, a local stranger was kind enough to approach me and show me the direction, but he said the temple was closed for the day since there is ceremony. Do not believe him! I was warned by my friend that it was their trick to bring us somewhere.Once you reach the temple, purchase the ticket for only THB 40 per person (This is the entrance fee to the Golden Buddha only). They will give you flyer for short explanation on the statue. I think this is better rather than go to the museum.Before entering the temple, you will need to take off the shoes and ladies, if you dressed with short pants or sleeveless tops, you will need to use the coat provided as they want to keep the temple sacred. Hence, dress politely (I know it was such a torture with the humid weather and the sun).If you want to take a photo, make sure you don't step on the carpet as it is only for praying or the guard will scold you. I still can not believe how people are so ignorant about this.

Its very beautiful. The gold Buddha Image has a long history. I have visited many many times. I like theNew Temple now its very beautiful. Although its difficult for the old age people toclimb the steps as there are many. If there is an elevator from inside the temple complex it would have been better as you get many foreigners visiting this Temple.

Get a guide. As I always say, get a guide before experiencing anything of culture or religion. We had a fantastic guide that seemed to just feed my appetite to know more about the gold buddha. Fantastic for mythology buffs. I think I noticed some people meditating as well so we tried our level best to be respectful. Over all, a great place to visit!

Spectacular. The golden Buddha was only discovered by accident as it had been covered by plaster etc to hide it from invading armies in particular the Burmese. It sure is worth a visit. Beautifully crafted.

More to it than meets the eye. Very interesting,but go with a knowlegeable guide. If you do go with. Guide, be aware that they will want to take you to a gem factory which is basically a jewellery shop, and a silk factory Grahams fashion which is a made to measure shop which my advice is don't go, or certainly don't buy. You get cheaper & better off the peg. You will be measured, it will be made, but the two won't necessarily be related.

Nice Temple. Temple houses big gold seated Buddha. In the past, artisans crafted the statue in gold and disguised it with cover of stucco and plaster from invading armies. That it was made of gold was discovered by an accident when it was being moved, they accidentally dropped it revealing a solid gold Buddha.
visual treat. the dolden Buddha is a piece of exquisite art for art lovers but for believers is ideal for meditation.
Interesting. Full of culture and tradition. I liked the location and the people were nice. Very scenic and a pleasure to see. Easy to get to and interesting

Very Special visit. This is a beautiful Temple, but my experience was made even more special when I met one of the volunteers who was kind enough to take me through an entire ritual with explanation on the meaning. I was blessed with water in the proper ritual which made me feel very special. An experience I will never forget. Very peaceful and rewarding visit.
Golden Buddha. Small temple on the outskirts of china town housing the golden buddha , impressive 5500 kgs of 18ct gold 600 years old. No entrance fee well worth a visit if your in the area
rohan. Well worth the time thro the traffic to get there , it is an awesome sight , a huge buddha , the sun reflecting off thr roofs made for an awesome scene .

Good as gold but not a must see. Located at the end of Chinatown and a short distance from Hualamphong railway station. This temple is good to visit if you are in the Chinatown area.The Wat Traimit houses one of the world's largest solid gold Buddha image. (Made of about 83% pure gold and weighing in at five and a half tons)Entrance to see just the Golden Buddha is 40 Baht without the musuem pass. The museum costs an additional 100 Baht. The temple is open 8:00 am to 5:00 pm everyday, but note that the museum is closed on Mondays.Only good to visit if you are in the Chinatown area as the temple is relatively small (compared to Wat Arun) and could be viewed within 30 mins.

Ladies who lunch. FabulousGood foodGood wineGood locationGood staffExcellent location for temples and canal tripGreat fun arriving there in a tuck tuckJust ask your guide to do in your day exactly what you wantAnd enjoy a very relaxing lunch by the canal

Lots to see. This attraction was extremely busy, but don't forget to explore around the grounds as there is more to see than just the reclining Buddha.You get a voucher appended to your ticket for free tourist drinking water too, which is funny but OK i guess as free water is always good.

A revered place.... Massive Buddha that dwarfed some of the other Buddhas I had seen on this trip. I saw a lot of reverence bestowed at this site and a genuine devotion. It was a reassuring feeling to see. Not a big place so do plan a lot of time here. I did have to pay to see this temple -
worth 10 mins if you are passing. On the edge of China Town so worth popping into if you are walking in that area but would not have made a special trip
A magic visit to the large golden buddha. Impressing to see this large golden buddha. Much larger then expected. Free to enter the temple and it was not over-crowded.
Nicest temple we visited. We went to this temple early in the morning before the crowds. Guide was great and very knowledgeable. So much history!!!
Very nice temple. The temple is very beautiful and the Buddha idol is very divine. The temple complex is quite huge and has many other temples inside. The Gold Buddha is very beautiful.

Interesting. A quick day trip within walking distance to Chinatown. Busy, touristy and area can be very sketchy. An interesting mix of locals and various cash making schemes. For those interested a must see. Proceed with common sense.
Beautiful sight. The golden Buddha is a wonderful sight and a must see in Thailand. Anyone with a rich appreciation for Thai culture and tradition will love this.

Golden Buddha. This is my second visit to the Golden Buddha but the first for my family. What a amazing site, seeing the Golden Buddha.....the size, it's height and that it is made from pure gold.The Golden Buddha attracts many visitors and hard to believe that it is made from Gold. We were able to take away lots of pictures and memories from our visit.Our tour guide advised that there is a dress code of which we respected but noted that lots of people just worn what they wanted and did not take any notice. But on the whole it is worth a visit at this spectacular site.

I think it is a must do, it may help you see Thailand.... a visit here allows you to "see Thailand" for its culture and its historical place. Thai people have a rich history and religious icons do abound... sometimes it even gets too much - but that is perhaps because we do not understand their long history. Take the time and Thailand will embrace you. Take the time, watch and listen...
Impressive. A lot to see, highly recommended. Much to see. Very busy with tourists & I can see why. Recommend 2-3 hours at least.

Nice place to pray. From Victory Monument, we took a tax to go one of the famous temple in Bangkok "Wat Traimit". It costs about 85 baht to visit the Golden pagoda - Wat Traimit. This is a nice place and it opening hours: 8am to 5pm – closed on mondays. Admission: 40 Baht and this is a temple no shorts, short skirts or vests are allowed. The giant golden Buddha is an incredible sight with statue weighs 5.5 tonnes and is 3 metres tall and not a bad place to pray for your health and fortune. There are also a small museum and a visit should take 45 minutes at most. It is 100 Baht per person. After visiting the Golden pagoda, you can go Chinatown near to Wat Traimit to see and buy. It costs 50 baht by taxi.
Golden Buddha. Brilliant, amazing and our guide was very interesting and knowledgeable, worth having a good guide to give you the history.

Only Go if You'll Behave. There's nothing wrong with this attraction--I rate it as Very Good. The temple itself is 1950s traditional Thai Wat: nice, but not jaw-dropping architecture. The attraction is the lacquer Buddha on top. This particular oversize (15 feet high) lacquered Buddha sat quieting gathering cobwebs for 700 years. The Wat it was in went to ruin and was decommissioned in the 1930s. The lacquered Buddha was put into storage, but because it was very, very old, over the next 20 years a brand new Wat was built to house the lacquered Buddha. They were hoisting the lacquered Buddha for the trip to its new Wat when there was a hoisting disaster; the hoist slipped, the Buddha fell, and the plaster and lacquer broke off of part of it. Revealing what no one alive had the foggiest was inside: a 5.5 ton solid gold Buddha! To fool thieves and Burmese (or both simultaneously) monks had plastered it over and lacquered it. The secret was so well guarded that NO ONE knew the plaster and lacquer was simply a thin facade. Gold IS a beautiful metal--as jewelers have appreciated for at least 4,000 years. This Buddha is absolutely stunning!Here's my problem. I went there today, and rarely have I been so ashamed to be a member of the human race. Despite extremely unmissable instructions that absolutely no photographs of the Buddha were permitted, when I was there a tour bus full of Indians showed up, and every last one started whipping out cameras, smart phones and tablets, and taking photos left and right: the wife in front of the gold Buddha, the mum, hubby. (For the record, I am 100% certain that not one of the Indian women was Muslim, and not one of the Indian men was a Sikh.). The ticket-taker tried to stop this, but they blew her off and refused to stop, oblivious to the grievous outrage to Buddhist sensitivity they were perpetrating. No sooner did they finally leave than a tourbus-load of French arrived, and did the same thing! (For the record, while the statistical odds are that they were mostly French, one or more of these bozos may have been Swiss or Québécois).It goes with saying that every lady one of them also stood with their feet pointed straight at the Buddha. I would very much support the Thai government passing a law that required tour operators to instruct their customers on basic etiquette when visiting wats, and documenting having done so, or forfeit their licenses to operate. But it was shameful and painful! Outrageous misconduct! You don't HAVE to be crass to appreciate a work of art and of sublime religious spirit made out of 5.5 tons of gold.So I strongly recommend you see this Wat if you behave with due decorum, and strongly recommend you do not, if you cannot.

The Golden Buddha. This is nice temple, smaller than the reclining Buddha ( Wat Pho) and marble temple ( Wat Benchamabophit) and is approximately 700-800 years old. The Buddha statue weighs in at 5,5000kg and less touristy and more intimate and private for those who wish to make their prayers.

Charming and beautiful!. This place was one of the nicest temples we visited while in Bangkok. That being said, another temple in Bangkok...another golden Buddha! The cool thing about this temple though, is that you actually have to climb of a few set of stairs in order to get to the Buddha located on the third level. The bad thing about it is if you are a woman, they make sure you cover every inch of your skin before going inside the temple, therefore making you sweat profusely for the 5 or 10 minutes you are there. Great temple and very cheap to go in (only a few US $)

definitely worth a visit- dont listen to scammers outside. so beautiful but extremely hot- bring water and do not listen to the scammers outside- beware they will try and tell you its closed or your skirts are too short- the temple provides robes for you and you can check on the hours yourself-

Peaceful. A place to visit if you what some peaceful time. The calm sitting golden Buddha towers overs you, an awesome sight to behold. Also this is a place where the monasteries are there but then you can have only a look at them from far. Must visit this place at least once and early mornings are the best .
a wonderful temple!. yes another buddist temple!but the difference is on the golden one!you will like this especial temple!
Golden Temple. Thailand is known for its gold reserves. It is a nice gold temple and you must take photo with Budha in the background to show back home

Can be visited. Since there are not many places of tourist visits in Bangkok and Temple being a religious place, it can be visited. Of course who follow Buddhism must visit this place. The statue is impressive and gives lots of peace.

Beautiful new marble chedi - just watch your timing!. This is a beautiful new raised marble chedi housing the golden Buddha at the entrance to Chinatown. There is also an interesting a/c museum in the basement. However, this place is very much on the tour bus plan, particularly for Chinese tourists. As such, get here as close to opening time (around 8am) as possible to avoid the masses.

A place to learn about Chinese in Thailand. The shrine is located very close to Bangkok Chinatown. The status here is covered by gold paint, which is the only one in Thailand (according to my guide). One tip for travelers: please don't wear any sleeveless top if you plan to visit any temple. Also wear a pair of shoes which is easy to take off because every temple is required you to take off the shoes before entering. Moreover, for respect, we should not stand up when facing the shrine. It is better to knee down.

Jaw-dropping. The solid gold Buddha is beautiful, and is now in a new temple building. One simply can't believe that it is solid gold, and whilst I preferred the old setting (before the new building) the new building does allow for photos from all angles. Combine this with a day strolling the lanes of Chinatown.......an amazing day!

Definitely a must visit when in Bangkok. This temple is within the China town district of Bangkok. The Viharn where the Gold Boudha image is beautiful ( some stairs to climb though ). Since this place is a place of worship , correct dress code is to be respected, though at certain months ( March - June ) it could be very hot here.
good and a must see. great design , great decoration. This one of the major temple attractions in Bangkok. Good dress code is always useful. I hot summer weather , it is good to have small umbrella.

bad experience. there was a huge dissapointment awaiting us since we were not allowed into the golden buddha temple since some relatives of the royal family was present at the temple. the whole area was sealed off, we therefore were very downhearted.

Well worth it - Its GOLD .. need one say more?. My wife and I visited this Wat. I found it quite insightful and the history around this Buddha was quite interesting. Made of pure gold need I say more.Defiantly a sight that needs to be visited when in BangkokI however felt a bit uncomfortable that as a tourist, there were many people taking pictures while Buddhist were praying.

Unique. The selling point to see this Buddha instead of any other is that it is not covered in gold leaf or painted gold but it is solid gold.The temple itself is not that impressive with a few steep steps.

A beautiful and unique temple. A beautiful temple, unique and quite different to other temples in Bangkok.You can hardly comprehend the amount of gold required to make a statue of this size.I don't need to go into the statistics, you can read them elsewhere, but a beautiful story, and a surprising history. It's easy to go in, as long as you're respectfully dressed as per other temples, cover up and take your shoes off.The decoration inside the temple is marvellous. This is an easy to get to, easy to walk in, quick to see, temple. Perfect type for a family who doesn't want to spend tons of time in the Grand Palace etc. Teen boys were awed by this.Monks around the area, please remember to cover your arms ladies.

Awe-inspiring Buddha. 5.5 tons of gold in the magnificent peaceful form of Lord Buddha. A truly humbling experience! The history of the Chinese immigrants is also available at the venue. Either I missed the link or there isn't one.

Temples and Buddhas everywhere - but not like this. Wow, what a big guy this Buddha was in comparison to many of the others. He is a very large golden Buddha. The price of him could possible solve world hunger - or more appropriately now - ebola. The walls are ornate and the ceilings are amazing as well. This place is a sure visit. Again, I do not think you need an official tour guide to appreciate the place, but it does help to get a feel of the history involved.
Must See!. I suggest visiting all of the Wats available for touring. The Wat Traimit is awesome. Make sure you take time to observe, reflect and interact with the monks!

Worth the visit. Lovely temple documenting and explaining the beginnings of Chinatown in Bangkok. Very good value money if you buy the Budda and Museum entrance together. Museum tastefully done with lots of information. Spent a good hour or so. Peaceful and interesting.

Breath taking. An elegant multilevel white and gold temple located at the very beginning of Yaowarat road, making it a perfect starting point for a Chinatown exploration. The main attraction on Wat Traimit is not only its beautiful architecture, but the immense buddha made of solid gold seated inside, the largest of this kind in the world. This five metres high, five and a half ton statue was long hidden under an unimpressive coating of plaster is thought to have been made in the 13th-14th centuries but the gold hidden underneath was only revealed by accident in 1955! Another amazing place that must be on any itinery.
very pretty and neat. My husband and I enjoyed seeing this. Its pure gold and amazing! Great place to take pictures. One can easily see this, reclining buddha and grand palace all in same day

Divine and charismatic. This Buddha temple is located near China town.It is the world's largest solid gold statue, with a weight of 5.5 tons. The temple is situated at a height of about 150 mtrs. It is made in the Sukhothai Dynasty style of the 13th-14th centuries. The entry fee is about 40 baht & an additional 100 baht to visit the museum

Another Bangkok Must See. Of course, you should see this temple. It is another of the must-see locations in Bangkok. The story is very interesting too and I suggest you read about it in advance, or better, get a good guide like I had (see my other review).

Impressive Buddha – 3.5 out 5 rating. After our tour of Jim Thompson House, our next stop was the Temple of the Golden Buddha.The temple is located near one end of Chinatown and also within walking distance of the train station.Although the temple structure housing the Golden Buddha was built in February 2010, the actual Buddha statue was cast in the 13th century.The history of the Golden Buddha is interesting. As the story goes, the golden Buddha was being moved and was accidentally dropped revealing a beautiful solid gold seated Buddha.It shouldn’t take more than 30-45 minutes to visit the Golden Buddha. Our visit was limited to the visit of the Golden Buddha and we did not visit the rest of the museum complex on the 1st and 2nd floors. In hindsight, I wished we had time to visit the rest of the exhibits on the first and second floors.I would recommend visiting the Golden Buddha.I would rate this attraction at 3.5 out of 5. Notes and Tips• You should check out the history of the Golden Buddha. It is interesting.• You will have to remove shoes before entering the temple.• There is a separate admission fee for the museum.• If you want to spend time visiting the museum, I would consider adding up to 60 minutes.• The first floor contains a museum about the history of Chinatown and the Chinese immigrants in Bangkok. The second floor contains an exhibition on the history of the Golden Buddha.• There’s a foreign exchange outlet across the street.• Chinatown centre is nearby – approximately 800 meters (1/2 mile) away• The Golden Buddha is approximately 2.8 kilometers (1 ¾ miles) from Jim Thompson House.• According to one website: At US$1,400 per troy ounce, the gold in the statue (18 karat) is estimated to be worth 250 million dollars. The body of the statue is 40% pure, the volume from the chin to the forehead is 80% pure, and the hair and the topknot, weighing 45 kg, are 99% pure gold.

Stunning oasis in middle of city. Can be a little difficult to find but head for the huge china town gate and is just across the (busy)road. Pay for your ticket round the side of the temple complex, away from the road, and make your way to the top level for some great views of china town area.Put your shoes in one of the bags provided and make your way into the room containing the Golden Budda. The room its self is quite small and very hot. The Budda is amazing and very highly polished. Try not to forget this is a buddist temple and the normal rules apply for visitors. Apparently the image weights 5 tonnes, made from solid gold and is valued at $250 million. Didnt visit the exhibition on the level below so cant comment but the Golden Budda is definately worth a visit.
Special temple. Wat Traimit is the temple of three friends and is so special because it is a temple built by the people for the community with a school attached. Beautiful!
Amazing. Amazing! Definitely impressive. Need to definitely see this temple on your visit. No two temples are alike.
Worth a visit. Bit off the beaten track, behind a train station, but worth a visit. Not as popular as the golden temple, but to see a solid gold Buddha is worth a trip.
must see. great place to visit, as usual with tourist traps be mindful of your belongings. Business or pleasure you must visit on your stay.

Enchanting site!. It's a great site to lean lot about Thailand, I am glad I explored this location. Off course it's a site dedicated to Buddha which has a temple on the 4th floor, which is made of its highest quality of gold.You feel like it's gone melt. Gold work looks so amazing. However the 3rd and 2nd floor also are equally interesting where you learn about the origin of Chin town in Bangkok, and the relationship of China and Thailand from the ancient time. It's has also an exhibition floor, where 1 can learn about how this great statue was done and the story of its origin. One also get a deep insight of Thailand's well preserved chain of Royalty and there kingship. It's really an great architecture marvel but also an great place to learn on Buddhism and About Thailand country, there past relation with china and there business ties, it's simply fantastic!

A decent visit to the world's largest seated buddha. If you've seen the reclining Buddhas in Myanmar, China etc, this is definitely puny in comparison. But nonetheless, it's at the very least, not daunting to look at. When you think the world's largest seated Buddha, you would imagine it to tower over you like a giant and an ant, but it's surprisingly not. To climb up and see the Buddha is free, but to enter the Yaowarat Heritage Center, you'd have to pay an admission fee. Overall, just climb up (good exercise for those who works behind a desk all the time) to see the Buddha, plus the view above is pretty decent too.

Must see. Between this, the reclining Buddha and the grand palace these are the must see sites in Bangkok in terms of temples. Cheaper to visit them without a tour guide but we had a private tour which meant we saw all of it without fighting our way around the city.

Hugh Golden Buddha laying on its side. After the Grand Palace walk a few minutes to see this Buddha. Enormous golden beauty but that is just the beginning of the complex. Walk around and enjoy the fountains and many chambers of Golden Buddhas sitting in rows. Less crowds at the end of the day. Many monks in this place as well. Totally worth the time!
Excellent. This visit was very good and to see such a wonderful exhibit was very interesting and the story behind how it was discovered was very interesting, so get a good guide.

Great experience. As we arrived at the temple there were some guys taking pictures of us we just thought they were tourists. In fact by the time we had a look round and were about to leave the temple these guys had created printed magnets...they were brilliant!!!! Golden Buddha was lovely, the detail and structure was amazing to see,

In the heart of China Town you find the golden Buddha. On Yoawarat road close to the odeon Circle you will find the Temple ground of Wat Traimit. The temple complex gives you 3 times value for the money. You can see the Golden Buddha on the 4th floor but the floor beneath are history about the discovery of the golden Buddha and the Chinese Heritage in Bangkok. Very interesting with a lot of info and images. Very interesting take 2-3 hours to visit the permises. As international you pay 140Baht for all. The Golden Buddha alone will cost you 40 baht; But believe me it impressed me to see it al. Worth the trip. Close by very good Chinese food , crab cakes, duck, Dim sum
Very nice place to visit. Very nice place to visit if you have interest to the budda culture it was very nice exprience. The temple has very nice enviroment

Huge Golden Buddha. Important tip: Get here early. If you're going on a day tour in Bangkok, our travel guide recommended that the Temple of the Golden Buddha is the first thing you have to visit since it gets really crowded. To see the Golden Buddha you have to take about 3 floors worth of stairs. I was amazed with the size of the Golden Buddha, it is huge especially for something made of gold. Weighs about 5.5 tons!

Golden Buddha. The story of how this enormous gold Buddha was discovered, covered in concrete, is really interesting. It was one of the most beautiful temples we visited. If we had to chose this over the Emerald Buddha (we visited both temples), this one was our favorite.
So shiny!. Not much to say, except it is shiny and beautiful. The neighborhood is ver authentic. We had breakfast with the locals around the corner and it was great.

HUGE GOLDEN STATUE OF BUDDHA. More than 5000 kilogram of solid gold statue of Buddha. its a superb peice of art.Must see in a life time. Sometimes this place get crowded at times. You get holy water from there, and you can pay whatever amount you like for it.

What an honour!. We were honoured to arrive at the Temple and meet the Bhudists Scholars / students (Hope this is how they are referred to with all due respect incase they are called something else). It was such a pleasure to see the normal prayer sessions going on despite our arrival at the Temple.

Golden Rendezvous. Imagine a lot of gold, then imagine some more gold and then you get an idea of this statue. Its 5.5 tons of solid gold. There are quite a few smaller statues around too, some made of gold, some encrusted with precious stones, The temple is located in Chinatown. Its a 3 story building and the temple is at the top. There are quite a few stairs to reach the top where the statue is. The lower 2 floors have museums/exhibitions about Chinatown and the Buddha. Please be respectful and wear clothes covering your legs and shoulders.
golden buddha. breathtaking place never seen anything like it. such a large in solid gold always a large crowd there but it is worth wait to get in front of it.
Very nice temple. The statue of Buddha is made of Gold. It is one of the most important tourist attraction very close to China Town.
Not the emerald bouddha upon to me. nice small attraction in BKK if you saw the other ones. Little temple in the iddle of the town. Anyway, can be skipped......

Good. Smaller to Wat Phra Kew, but still a must-go place. Locate in Thai-China area, make sure to try some Thai sticky rice on the way walking to the area. If you just interested in enjoying the view, the architecture or just simply taking photographs, you may walk around the area after go through the entrance gate without buying tickets. But if you want to see inside, you should buy one (I'm not sure if photography is allowed inside the temple or not).
amazing. it's amazing seeing such a huge buddha statue made of pure gold. also the story of the buddha statue is very interesting

Well Worth A Visit. Like many of the temples in Bangkok, this is worth a visit. You can tour the museum at additional charge, but for us climbing to the top and seeing the Gold Buddha was a satisfying introduction to this Wat, and gave good views of the entire complex.
Lovely temple and impressive Buddha. Really nice temple, which is a little less crowded than others. The Golden Buddha is impressive. Worth the small entrance fee.

Giant Sitting Gold Buddha. This attraction was recommended to us by our local taxi driver who we hired for the day, and although we have been to Bangkok many times we would never have found this place ourselves.It is situated in part of Chinatown and dominates the skyline.One of our friends was visiting from the UK and is a wheelchair user so we were a bit unsure what sort of access there was going to be.... and we were very pleasantly surprised as it had proper ramps, a lift to take you to the top and very good disabled toilets, so getting around was no problem and the staff were so helpful as well.The golden sitting Buddha is situated in the main temple near the top, so a little climb is needed, or you can use the lift. Very ornate inside and lots of smaller Buddha statues situated in there as well, good views from the outside over Bangkok and when we were there it was quite busy.Plenty of shops for souvenirs and snacks and drinks, if your in the Chinatown area worth spending an hour looking round here, a small admission fee is payable.

History is made out of gold. The history contained in it, which made ​​us very interested in this temple. How is the struggle of a nation to defend their beliefs, culture and wealth from extinction. The layout of the temple which is slightly higher from the surrounding land mark, add to the splendor of this temple. How does this statue is protected from invaders by covering it with stucco and plaster, up to become the world's largest states massive gold seated Buddha is part from history of Thailand.To see the temple itself is free, and you must pay attention to how you dress. By the time we get there, we paid ticket 10 Baht per person, but we were not told that there is a museum that can be visited by paying the ticket. As a suggestion, if you just look at the temples and Buddhist statues, do not buy a ticket.

Lucky visit. Ours was lucky coincidence. On the day of our "Temple tour", this temple was off limits due to visiting royalty - but on the day we had set aside for Chinatown, we were able to visit this place for free - that too at 6PM (temple usually closes at 5PM) - because the monks were performing some chanting (apparently happens every Monday). So, there we were, enjoying the glorious Golden Buddha in the background of golden hued sky and with hardly 10 people in the building. It was magical.

Well worth a visit. Make sure you bring something to cover your arms. This is a beautiful Temple and it's worth going to see it. We walked out to the temple and it gave us the opportuntiy to see the local culture. Be careful crossing the the only rule on Bangkok road is that there is no rules.
Beautiful piece of history. Amazing place with lots of culture symbols and a perfect description of the beliefs of an ancient nation; beautiful art in all kind of expressions

Interesting!!. Was great to see this place and the golden Buddha!! We went with City discovery for a half day tour and we got a lot out of it!! Would recommend city discovery they are very knowledgeable. The Golden Buddhas history is very interesting!

Worth visiting if you are an "Overseas Chinese"- Hua Chiao. Historical Documentation thru media of the early arrival of the Chinese to Bangkok . A short movie showing the challenges that was thrown to them on the junks they came in. And lots of artefacts showcasing the goods they brought in as exports to trade with Thailand. Their crafts and their food. The documentation was also very informative. I can only imagined it is the same path for all the Chinese immigrants arriving to other South East Asian countries. It actually showcased how my grandfather was strong and determined when he sailed to Malaya.

Nice View. The budha has an impressive view, but I have to say that due the amount of other gorgeous Budha statues in Thailand, this is one of the average images. All of the Budhas visited are impresive.
good. We thought we would not be long here but you will end up spending a lot of time here, it is full of tourists so can be really busy but worth a visit great photos

Huge gold masterpiece. This was amazing, our guide told us the gold alone was worth 69 million $USD and weighed five and a half ton. This Buddha had been covered in concrete for many years, hidden from the invaders.
Huge, impressive Buddha statue. You will be impressed by this huge statue made of gold. One of the temples in bangkok that are less crowded. Enjoy the temple and the surrounding area.
Waste of Time. This is only a must visit if one is interested in Buddhism.We visited on a hot day (is there any other) and may have been a bit distracted by this.

Incredible, must see yourself. We were taken to the Temple of the Golden Buddha by our tuk tuk driver, who recommended it as a must see place in Tailand. It was beautiful, and not overly crowded.The only thing is that there needs to be signs that are more clear. There is a charge to access the top part where the Buddha is, and the museum below. We discovered this once we had already reached the top and removed our shoes, and had to put them back on and go back downstairs to get tickets. Also, there are a few vendors milling about the bottom of the temple trying to sell you little trinkets. They are kind of aggressive, avoid them if you can and be forceful with your NO.

Exquisite !!. Thailand's love for Buddha is commendable and appreciative, the temples are all same but each has a different aroma,flavor and experience to share. The Temple of Golden Buddha, the Statue of Buddha is Made of gold as they say. The very architecture of the place and the Temple's intricately done work is eye catching and worth seeing. The temple is of 4 floors high, with the main deity being on the top most floor, with a fleet of stairs welcoming you at the entrance. The silence and serene environment in the sanctum is exhilarating and makes you forget the chaos outside. The message of Buddha for Inner peace is very well embodied in the temple.

Fee. This seems to be the only temple you have to pay to enter. I was able to see the Golden Buddha and take very nice pictures, of, inside, and around the temple and the Buddha without paying to enter, from the outside.

Festive atmosphere, convenient location. This four-storey temple with a big golden Buddha on the top level after going up three flights of stairs is pretty close to Hua Lamphong (the main train station of Bangkok), so definitely worth checking out if you're at the station waiting on your transit or if you've just arrived in Bangkok by train from somewhere. Go out the side entrance on the right (as coming from the train platforms), cross the canal, turn left, walk a little bit and it's like the second street that you should take (kind of not turning, just bearing right), and it will be on your right.Likely, you'll see tons of tourists like I did when I went there with souvenir vendors selling small Buddha statues on the left as you're going toward the temple, and also on the far right side near the back exit, there's a cluster of more souvenir vendors and what I noticed there was their Thailand souvenir keychains were about three times less (!) than what I had been quoted for pretty much identical ones at the MBK Center where I had gone to just before arriving at this one, so this would be a nice place to buy souvenir keychains if you collect those like I do. Also, there are tons of food places along the street right outside the main entrance.The Confucius statue on the temple grounds near the entrance on the opposite side from the side of the main entrance is also noteworthy, in my opinion, as Buddha and Confucius were from about the same period in history (around 500 BC).

Great to see. Never seen anything like this before, it was huge. You can see the detail on the giant feet at the bottom.
Got in for free because it was a holy day.

Nice experience. The Golden Buddha is really amazing, but we loved the museum too, there is a lot of explanations about the Golden Buddha history, so, I think the visit is better if you go to the Museum too. To see the Golden Buddha costs 40 bath (about 1,2 USD) and to go to the Museum is 140 baths (about 4,3 USD).

Stunning. Took my breath away! I can't believe at one point this Buddha had been covered in concrete and forgotten about till a chunk fell away to reveal the golden statue beneath. The statue and temple alike are works of art that you can't help but appreciate, such craftsmanship, just stunning. Do a tour here for sure!

Sitting Golden Buddha near China Town. The Golden Buddha is made of solid gold weighed approx. 4.5 tons. The temple is small but clean and peaceful inside the temple. Entrance fee is 50bht. Easy to reach. Take the MRT line to Hua Lumpong station which is the last station then walk towards the Chinatown. If in doubt, ask people around. Mostly helpful.
Interesting!. Very interesting temple, well worth a visit to see the budda but besides the budda not much else to see. Would not visit again though, only a one time visit. Entrance fee is THB 40.

Interesting and quick. It's a Thai historic landmark since this huge statue is make of solid gold and it'll only cost you about 15 minutes as there isn't all that much else to see.
Worth the time to visit.
Long live the King

Personal Favorite. I stay in Bangkok each year for a few months. I always visit here a few times. The Monks are very nice, they always teach me something new. The Image is stunning in gold at the top of the Location. They have redone the lower level temple and I am exited to see it in late 2014. Visit the gift shop for really nice bracelets and mini gold Buddhas. You would think you can find these at the market JJ but trust me they are not the same quality. These at the temple are much nicer.

Golden Buddha at Chinatown. Visited Wat Traimit, temple of the Golden Buddha, during our recent trip to Bangkok.Wat Traimit is a 3-storey temple, the lower floors houses some exhibits. It takes a flight of stairs to the 3rd floor, while the Golden Buddha is. The entrance fees is THB 40 per person.Nice, peaceful and pious atmosphere inside the temple, but beside the Golden Buddha, there's nothing much to see.
Very nice. I thought this was a lovely place to go and it is a lovely Budda but I was all budda out in the end ..

A Golden Rendezvous. Imagine a lot of gold, then imagine some more gold and then you get an idea of this statue. Its 5.5 tons of solid gold. There are quite a few stairs to reach the top where the statue is. The temple is located in Chinatown. Its a 3 story building and the temple is at the top. The lower 2 floors have museums/exhibitions about Chinatown and the Buddha. Please be respectful and wear clothes covering your legs and shoulders.
nothing special other than gold. The temple structure is really nice however there is nothing special to this other than the fact the entire Bhuddha statue is made of gold.

Charming place at the end of Chinatown's Yaowarat Road. Wat Traimit is charming place, located at the end of Chinatown's Yaowarat Road, just a few mins of walk from Hualampong Railway Station. The main attraction is the world's largest massive gold seated Buddha measuring nearly five metres in height and weighing five and a half tons. The history says the statue was disguised from invading armies by a covering of stucco and plaster. Very quiet place, deserves a visit, if you are in Hualampong/Chinatown area and have 30 minutes to spend :)
That's a lot of GOLD. This was a very amazing Buddha. Wow that is a lot of gold. We thought it was great. We would recommend having a look!
Many wat. Very nice wat,you can go along the river and check all the war you want,very relax on the river,amazing city with amazing wats,

Interesting but under repair. The place is always packed with visitors and worshipers alike. Everybody is required to dress appropriately and will have to go barefoot to enter the temple. One of the temple is under repair though so there is just one building you can go in to. To avoid heat exhaustion, visit the temple a bit early in the morning because it is so hot and humid in the afternoon.
