Excellent structure. great heritage and cultural monument of buddhism, peaceful and beautiful, must visit the full structure and good view from the up.
WoW. The size of the statue is absolutely breathtaking. It's unbelievable that it weighs 5 tons and how it has been moved from place to place.

Amazing temple.. At first sight it takes your breath away. It is an amazing creation and according to my Thai friend the temple also acts as a training centre for young monks.People apply gold on the Buddha statue to offer reverence and there are many people who sell these thinly pounded gold slivers close to the temple.A must see sight in Thailand.

Totally worth the visit. This temple is a little off the beaten path but so worth the visit. The Golden Buddha is majestic, and coming too see it offers a little quiet time in an otherwise busy street life outside. If you only have time to see the Golden Buddha, then just buy the ticket to the 4th floor (the other option gives you access to a small museum on the floor below)

Better for worship, than tourism. It felt somehow like I was intruding and violating the space with my curiosity and photography, although I'm ashamed to admit that this did not deter me from staying the course, although it was beautiful. I wouldn't do this again though.

Our first Buddha. Wonderful visit and what a story surrounding the rediscovery of this beautiful edifice. Encased in concrete and hidden in the river for so many years and then only discovered by accident. At least that was what we were told.

awe inspiring. Just taking in the size of this statue is mind boggling,trying to take a complete photo is difficult due to the size,the engraving of the story of Buddism on the feet is worth the visit alone

There be Gold on that Buddha!. Its worth visiting simply to see the chunk of gold that went into making this statue. Its a quick visit so I recommend doing this as part of a city tour to see the major temples/palace, etc. It is interesting to find out in the history that this was actually hidden behind plaster for almost 200 years with no one knowing its true worth until an accident exposed the gold..
The Golden Buddha... Wat trai mitr wit tha ya ram.. The Golden Buddha, officially titled Phra Phuttha Maha Suwan Patimakon, is the world's largest solid gold statue, with a weight of 5.5 tons.
A must see. Every time I go to Bangkok I return here. Dress in light clothing in the heat and humidity. I suggest taking a tour
There are better things to see. Too much expecting for such advertisement, worth to be visited but only don't think it's best in bangkok
A 5 ton Buddha in solid gold. This is a must on any visit list, a superb temple in the Chinatown district. Usual rules on dress apply, and there is an entrance fee of 40 Baht.

Incredible. A must visit for anyone visiting Bangkok.The Golden Buddha was so much bigger than what I had anticipated, it was incredible. I took lots of photos as no one particular did the magnificent structure justice. The area surround was one of my favourite places in Bangkok. I like the fountains and the many different things to look at.
The House and gardens are worth it. The compulsory tour by the House Guides is the only way to see the combination of interior Eastern decor mixed with European comforts.
Amazing. We had a private guide take us here and so glad we did. Sloes off of course and arms covered despite the heat.
Very Rich Temple. We arrived this temple on 12 th August. This supposed to be the Birthday of the Queen. It was very crowded. This a very grand temple. You must visit this in Bangkok.

Golden Buddha. Buddha made of 5500kg of Gold. Very grand temple in Chinatown area. Must go for those first time to here. There os a entrance fee of 40baht per pax. Best go in the morning. This temple open until 5pm only
Bangkok, Thailand's Golden Image Buddha. I could not have imagined the beauty of the Phra Phuttha Maha Suwan Patimakon. Amazing history of the rediscovery. Long live King Bhumibol Adulyadej.

Culrurally superb. Such a lovely monument in a beautiful building. With a unique history marked by only recent (in the last 50 years) discovering that this monument is made of 18 karat gold. In person this moment is a sight to behold. A must see in Bangkok.

YOU MUST SEE THIS!!. This is listed in the Guiness book of world records.... A pure gold Buddha that is from the 13th century, that had been covered in PLASTER and then, one rainy night in 1955 as they were trying to put it in a new location, it fell and the next morning they found pieces of the plaster and underneath it was PURE GOLD!It is just amazing! Not only that, but there are two museums that you must see! Do not just go to see the Buddha (It costs 40 baht....one dollar and thirty cents) but go to the museums as well.Here is the plan........Take the BTS to ASOKE station. Then go to the MRT and go to the station for HuaLampong, about 7 stations away.Then walk up EXIT ONE, and then you will see signs that lead you there. You must cross the road, and there will be TUK TUK drivers who will tell you it is closed until 3PM, but do not believe them, it is open all day on the weekends..... and if you take a TUK TUK it will just be about a minute ride...So walk across the street, follow the signs, and it will be a quick zig zag of a walk.When you arrive buy the whole museum pass which includes the two museums and the golden Buddha....Go to the museum that tells all about the Buddha. You will learn how they made it, you will also see photos of it covered in plaster! If you go see the Buddha first you will miss the big build up so try to go through the museum first.Then go up the steps and WOW!!! It is awesome!!!After that you can go eat lunch at a nearby restaurant, or go to a cafe. Then plan on spending an hour or two at the other museum on the first floor. It has to do with the Chinese history in Thailand. It is so cool! It really goes into all the intricate details of how the Chinese came over, and even has some special life like exhibits, like a ship that goes through a storm while people are yelling in Chinese (the Chinese immigrants sailed on a junk boat for ONE MONTH to get to Bangkok, and they each brought a pumpkin with them so they could eat it on the way, and if there was a storm they could use it to float on!)This museum was like a missing piece for the whole Thai culture. You will see why the city has so many Chinese themes, why the gold stores are painted red in Thailand, why the Chinese saved the city,etc..etc..etc....I spent three hours at this cool attraction, and it was a blast!

Simply amazing. We didn't see many temples in Bangkok but we wanted to see this one as it sounded fascinating and it was. There are some people outside selling souvenirs and as you get to the foot of the temple two photographers get in your face taking pictures but after that the experience is nice. It's a combination of a museum, Buddha and gift shop. The Buddha was stunning and local people where there praying which made it seem real. Outside you are presented with a fridge magnet with your image on it with small images of the golden temple surrounding it from those photographers that took your picture earlier. Haggle and you 'll get a good bargain.
Simply awe inspiring!. If you see one temple in Bangkok, this is the one! It is a large sitting Buddha of solid gold. The grounds are beautiful as are the views!
Must see temple.. This temple was truly amazing. It is a must see while in Bangkok. This was our first introduction to a Buddhist temple and I would recommend it to anyone.

Stunning. Beautiful to see this stunning golden Buddha and the temple it is in, the architecture is impressive even the ceiling and doors are beautifully done I enjoyed the visit I feel it was worth seeing.There is a small fee to enter.
Pretty but not the nicest temple. I stumbled upon this whilst heading into Chinatown. It was worth popping in on my way but I would not go just to see this on its own.

nothing special, but gotta see the GOLDEN BUDDHA. cheap price $5.00 to see the golden buddha. outside architecture is impressive. small area to view. u gotta see, but maybe purchasing postcard would have sufficed.
Nice temple. Nice temple. Again clean and neat. Lot places to take picture. The flower decoration was very details and unique.

Must see in a Bangkok. Take the river ferry and double the pleasure of this cultural experience. Agree it is commercialized but we found much of Bangkok and the tourist areas (we also stayed in Koh a Samui) like that. Cheap to get into compared to a North American sites. We zenned-out during our visit which was a nice spiritual break in the chaos that is a busy, noisy modern city.
Very peaceful and magnificent. The place is very peaceful and the place is indeed magnificent. It is worth the visit. Even if I am not buddhist I surely appreciate the place and would recommend.

So helpful to have a guide on your side. Wonderful attraction, we went with a small group (3) & a guide named William, who gave us the history and facts about how they found Buddha and the Temple. I recommend this highly! Very impressive & could not get over the fine hand painted walls & ceiling.
amazing sculpture. I am totally amazed by design and the interior. Unlike grand palace it wont charge you high to see lord buddha.

God is Gold...Oops Great.. Temple is peaceful and the statue of Buddha is quite magnificent mainly because it is of gold. It is huge and I wonder if the devotees really come to worship the god or the gold ?? well it depends on your faith but yes whatever it is it will surely compel you to admire and come again :) Tip:- Thailand memorabilia viz. T-shirts, elephants, Buddha relics etc are cheap and at a good bargain price near the temple gate.

Temple of the Tourists. We have been regular visitors before the massive renovation. We are sure that the current Buddha statue looks different from the original. Post - renovation this temple has sadly been transformed into a tourist attraction with locals trying their very best to relieve tourists of some money.The serenity of this temple has been sacrificed for commercial purposes. We have since stopped visiting this temple.

Very impressive Buddha. Have been here a couple of times last time July 2013 and each time I can't work out if it's the sacred Buddha that impresses me or all that Gold. The statue is large in a small temple. They found it by chance and it was covered in clay to disguise it - only when cleaning it did they discover it was solid gold! What a find. Nothing else here - best to do it as part of a Temple Tour than make a special journey.
Buddha made of gold!. Basically, there's just a Buddha made in gold. It's quite impressive. Also a good place to take photos, since the temple itself is magnificent. A one-time visit will do.

Beautiful!. Lots of Buddhas in this town but this one is real gold. Very beautiful. The walk up the temple is an easy one. As with the rest of the temples, no shoes and ladies knees must be covered. They do have rental sarongs
Spectacular. It is a wonderful temple to see...as part of a day trip it is brilliant. We also took a boat around the canals....by far four best decision for Bangkok sightseeing.
Amazing. Really enjoyed the statues, surrounds and history! The locals are very happy and informative. Be sure to wear clothes that cover upper arms and knees.

Just another Buddha. I would prefer that you just visit Wat Arun and the sleeping budda (or reclining buddha), if you choose go go around seeing buddha's the whole time your entire holiday will just go away before your eyes, every turn you take there is a new buddha to see.
Cool Place!. If your around the area I would certainly recommend visiting. A great place to see, however it doesn't take long to walk around.

Extreme positive energy from the idol. The moment I stepped into the temple I lost myself, I had shivers and felt like I am a battery on charge. I did not want to leave the temple and given a choice would remain there forever, suddenly I felt that I have found the final destination to eternally happiness. I am out of words , you need to experience this yourself only if you have the sixth sense can pick the vibes.

Not to be missed in Thailand!. No matter what religious persuasion (or lack of one) that you have, you must visit this beautiful Thai treasure. I would love to have stayed all day just staring at the exquisite beauty!

Great to see...make sure you are covered up. This is something that you must see when in Thailand, however it is so busy that it did just end up being something we went to and then moved on because there are so many people in the area that you can’t enjoy it as much as it was hard to take photos and walk around with ease. You need to make sure you are appropriately dressed covering up etc, otherwise you are asked either not to enter or to buy something to cover your shoulders/knees. Basically as it is a religious, special temple to them dress appropriately although it was hot it is a sign of respect. Worth going to see as any pictures I have seen don’t do it justice.
Interesting visit. This is also a must see attraction when in Bangkok. It is very interesting to learn the history of the golden Buddha. The place is also very clean and well maintained.

Golden Buddha near Chinatown. You need to pay entrance fee before you start climbing those stairs. We took a while to locate this place when we stepped out of Hua Lumpong subway station. However, once you cross the small river, you should be able to ask your way there. Make this trip together with a tour of Chinatown as it is within walking distance.

The Golden Buddha. Not only did we see the Buddha in this temple but we paid to go in the museum section and read about its history, how it was made and transported etc. This was interesting but we didnt go in anymore museums- just went to see the Buddhas. We took a walk around China Town after visiting the temple and we had learned a lot about it in the museum so for us it was well worth a visit. We walked for hours and just took in our surroundings and the people.

Very strict dress code!. My excitement was dashed after the ticket seller required all types of extra covering for my daughters for which they demanded a fee. I was really turned off by that. Otherwise the place is beautiful.
BIG GOLD BUDDAH. the buddah is unbelievable because it is made of pure gold. be sure to bring your nice camera for you to have a good picture of the golden buddah.
Wat Traimit. Simply majestic! A thing of beauty. The pictures on line do not give justice to this likeness of Buddha. No wonder my mother liked it very much.

Princess Castle. It's like a golden disney castle- very pretty. The inside museum is very informative and a proper golden buddha (as opposed to the gold leaf buddhas found in most temples) was a refreshing change!
early. I went early , a lot of water around , the temple is world famous and stunning , the morning sun made it a magical view .

Over Rated like many so called must see attractions. Best part is that it is basically free, no one asked for our tickets. Ruined by the number of donation boxes requesting money for every possible cause. Nice that it is still a working temple, although the people there to pray must be annoyed at the constant parade of tourists taking photos. At least it is a quick attraction, you can see it all in less that 10 minutes.

Impressive and interesting. Seeing 5.5 tons of solid gold sure is an awe inspiring and impressive sight! Definitely worth a visit for that alone! You can get a ticket for just the Buddha (40thb when I went) and you can get an extra ticket for the exhibition (100thb when I went). There are two exhibitions; one about Chinese immigrants coming to Thailand throughout history (the temple is right next to china town) and another about the construction and history of the Buddha. The later of these was extremely interesting. Both exhibitions were very well put together and had well witted English signs for everything so there was no trouble understanding it all.
amazing place. this is the first time im at Thailand, i realy exciting when came here. There are many people gp around although at night.

The golden one. Situated in an area which is not obvious so get a taxi it saves an hours walk from Khao San in the heat!! I only visited the Buddha and not the museum, was worth the visit when you take the fact that it's solid gold. The building it sits in is worth a closer look as well.

Worth seeing because when else will you see so much gold?. The Temple of the Golden Buddha is a beautiful temple but not incredible, in amongst all the glorious temples of South East Asia. It is not particularly large and it is very touristy. However, it is worth going to for it's namesake. When or where else will you see so much gold? The statue was larger than I expected and charming. Worth seeing but you don't need to spend a lot of time there.

Pretty Awesome Sight. We went here in the middle of the afternoon. Quite busy at that time with school kids and tourists. Still, it is a sight to behold. Climbing the steps up to the Buddah, we were not ready for the size of it. Over 5 tons of solid gold!We were told that we didn't have to take our shoes off before entering. A little lady caught us with our shoes on and shuffled us out the the door quickly. A word of warning, don't believe it when people tell you that you don't need to take your shoes off. We found out the hard way.

Great story behind the Golden Buddha. This was our first template we visited in Bangkok and it was fantastic to see and learn the story behind the Golden Buddha. I won't give anything away but it should definitely be on your list to see

A hidden gem by Wat Pho. Not sure if travellers are just less aware, but I was surprised to this area less crowded. Although this is probably more of a space used for praying, I thought those foreigners lying down were being disrespectful, there ought to be more awareness of ways to show respect in those areas, as people seem to be oblivious. But the Golden Buddha is definitely a hidden gem that is far less spoken about.

Another Amazing Temple. While in Bangkok you need to pace yourself on the temple visits. We visited 7 in one day and got a bit of "temple fever". But the Golden Buddha temple is definitely one of those you should try to get to.
Golden Buddha - Truely Amazing. Huge Huge Huge Idol of Buddha in Gold. This makes once visit fruitful and ever lasting in its memories. This is absolutely a must visit temple in Bangkok.
Awesome!. I had seen a lot of pictures but was blown away when we entered the small building. The intricate detail of the Buddha statue & the building itself was amazing. A great experience.

good for tourists. A very unique attraction that you would not see anywhere else in the world.Be careful the TukTuk drivers trying to rip you off. Try to visit with a thai guide, they are good with local informaiton and great for language difficulties.

Gold as Expected $.$. You get what you expect here. It's physical value is $250M and it's really gold $.$. In the topmost floor, you can see the Golden Buddha sitting perfectly for just 40 baht (Exhibit costs 100 baht). We just came across this on our way on foot to Chinatown from Hua Lamphong MRT station. Before entering though, you need to take off your shoes (there is a shoe rack provided). Also, shorts are not allowed but there is a sarong or a piece of cloth for covering that is available for rental for 20 baht. This closes at 5PM then you can hit the road to Chinatown after! :D
Tremendous. The sheer size of the Buddha, and the surrounding buildings. Beautiful. Shame about the pickpockets.

Amazing site to see. The story that goes with it is excellent. Ladies you must cover your shoulders but you can rent a wrap for 20 baht from the ladies outside. Quite something and a must to see it Bangkok
A must go place in bangkok. I am buddist so I come here for religious reason and i love this place. A bit too crowded but nice architect!

Go in the morning!. Do yourself a favor and see this temple in the morning. It's cooler, and there were very few tourists and touts when I went. I was even able to catch a line of monks coming down the outer stairs of the temple. If you're a woman do yourself a second favor and buy one of those cheap sarongs everyone's selling the first day you arrive in Bangkok. It's too hot to wear long pants, and nearly all of the temples require you to cover your knees, so you can just bring your sarong with you instead of renting one at every temple and realizing later that you could have bought two sarong with the money you've spent renting old sweaty ones from every temple. This temple is gorgeous and compact. The exhibit inside was also very interesting (about how the golden Buddha was created and re-discovered) and is worth the extra charge- for both the education and the exquisite air-conditioned break.

A great tourist visit. Bangkok as many wonderful places to visit on the tourist trail would recommend this one all the palaces and temples are very well done this as the same decorative charm as others have
great. great 5.5 tons of golden buddha , there's an elevator too if ur accompanied with senior travellers so no probs

LOTS of tourists and pick-pockets. Impressive buddha, but the whole experience was ruined by the heaps of tourists and extremely pushy sellers. It was also clear that they "played" the tourists to get money, and charged for every little thing. Sad to see as it is clearly important in the buddhist culture.

50 ways to donate money. Fabulous 3500 kilograms buddha statue with ample opportunity to donate money. It is surrounded by at leatst 32 moneyboxes and the rest of the temple also gives more than enough chance to give money.Pretty decent statue though ;-).
worth a visit. make sure you remember to take something to cover your shoulders if your a female. it can get very hot during the afternoon take some water

Lovely and located in Chinatown. Lovely cultural site, pay the extra or read up via lonely planet to understand the history of the site, best part is located close to the main markets in Chinatown. Please remember to exercise respect and cultural sensitivities and cover up to avoid offending Buddist traditions and Monks!
Beautiful and informative. The back story about this Buddha is very interesting. I loved that this is a real temple with people coming to worship. The aura of the place will envelop you.
Amazing. It is so amazing, still crowded but so many people and coins of money. Buddha is very rich ...it is still amazing place to see. Recomend it

Not so good compared to other temples. This temple is not a place that I would suggest to visit unless you have a lot of time to spend in Bangkok. The price to visit it is relatively expensive compared to the other temples and you need to pay for each floor you want to visit (4 floors but I don’t remember the exact prices). On the top floor, there is a golden statue of Buddha where you can pray. You need to wear clothes that cover knees and shoulders to get there. On the second floor, you have a small museum of Bangkok in the 18s. The place is okay, but for the price it doesn’t worth the detour.
Beautiful temple Must visit. You will be amazed by the golden Buddha statue. So nice and peace full. Absolutely love it. Ticket is required to purchase.

Good to visit if you are in the area. we found this temple hard to find on our own so if you do wish to visit here, maybe a taxi, tour or tuktuk would be best?we got lost in Chinatown trying to find it which in itself was great fun albeit a very long, hot walk! The temple is beautiful but if you are on a limited timescale, I would visit the main temples (Grand Palace, Wat Arun, reclining Buddha) first and wouldn't be too disappointed if you don't make it here.
A must see. What can I say- but wow. It doesn't matter how often I see this I am always glad I do. The colours, the Golden Budda and the size and the people around - incredible

Golden Buddha. The temple was very pretty and the story of the Buddha was very interesting to the kids - they thought it was very cool that the buddha has been hidden in plaster and never discovered until it was acidentally dropped! Cool place and close to China Town to finish the day with a walk through the markets and dinner!

Golden Buddha was a sight to behold. We went there during the buddhist lent (Asalha Puja), the temple was a little crowed. I had a chance to pour hot wax to make big candles and in the process make some donation to support the school. The small school children calling out for people to participate in this activity were very cute! The chance to have a silent moment in front of the Golden Buddha was incredible. It was up close and the presence of Buddha was palpable. Compared to many temples where important Buddhist artefacts are kept high and very far away( e.g., the Emerald Buddha). I am thankful that at Wat Traimit, worshipper are allowed near the Golden buddha.

Beautiful... Beautiful temple but quite a climb up the stairs so not suitable for the less mobile. Members of the Royal Family were expected so the red carpet was being put out when we were there. We used a guide so got all the history and was well worth the money.
wonderful. with so many wonderful temples and buddhas in Thailand, its easy to underestimate how beautiful they all are, this is no exception, stunning!
Urban temple. You can visit this gold covered temple during a Chinatown visit. Check out the indoor rooms for an interesting summaries of the temple and the people who brought it back to life.
One big Buddha. Very crowded when we went, look at the feet they are amazing. the best photos can be taken from the feet looking back.
Great surprise. Unknown to many travelers, interesting history, 5500 Kg of gold in a Buddha image, nice temple hidden in the hearth of chinatown

Great to visit we had a tour guide. Tour guide are best as you learn the history and then you understand the meaning of the culture . The Buddha are massive and have coats for the different seasons . Well worth the visit we saw about 4 different styles of Buddha so after this we were all Buddha out
Nice. This is a curious point on possible temple-visiting route, not the most impressive mayde, but interesting in being nonspottable and simple

Luxorious!. Posh and generously gold decorated!
interesting and tranquilizing point wich can be a good part of different temples tour
Major Landmark. If you are visiting Bangkok for the first time then this would definitely be in your bucket list for places to visit in the city.... Wonderful architecture and rich in history!!

Beautiful - A Must Visit. The temple is a must visit in Bangkok - the grandeur of the temple makes it stand out from its surroundings. The place is maintained very clean. The highlight is the image of the Buddha made of gold, which happens to be the largest solid gold image of the Buddha in the world. The image weighs about 5.5 tons I was really fascinated by the history of the image and its journey from Sukhothai to the present day Bangkok. The experience becomes all the more enriching after reading a little about the image. I would suggest you to do the same. For a little more of my experience, here is a link to my blog: http://nehaslife.wordpress.com/2014/06/20/singapore-thailand-trip-the-bangkok-city-tour/

A must see, one of Bangkok's great attractions. we went by Ferry up to the Temple, arrived early to avoid the tourist crowds, and had a leisuly stroll around the grounds allow a good three hours to explore.

Amazing and a must see. Look like an ordinary temple in Bangkok but the big buddha statue inside the temple is made made of pure 100% gold...Wow...fantastic place to see & take picture. Do not mise it, if you intend to visit China Town, pls drop by this temple which is near by.
Great Temple .. awsome !. The idol in Solid Gold- 4 tonnes is breath taking ! Very good , worth seeing .Quite neta and clean , well organized .
Golden visit. This is well worth visiting as the size and beauty of the Golden Buddha is just breathtaking. Best go outside busy periods as then numbers of tourists can make moving around a bind.

A little bit of Thai culture. It's not a full day venue, probably on an hour need be reserved to visit Wat Traimit, but make sure you do it. The buddha is SOLID gold plus its a working temple so people are lighting incense sticks, making prayers, and donating. very interesting little snippet of Thai culture.
beautiful. Take the time to see this. This kind of compares to the Vatican for Catholics. Wear long pants and be prepared to be overwhelmed with beauty.

Stunning Gold Buddha!. Almost 50 to 60 steps to the top and it is worth the climb. But don't you worry. There is lift available to the top. Almost 10 feet tall the solid gold Buddha is a must visit. The guide told us it weighs 5.5 tonnes. There is nothing else to see but you can just go to see the statue.
Dream. Everyone made sure they didn't bypass the golden Buddha .It was spectacular .I can't find words to describe it.Only my pictures can vouch speak for it .No dislikes
Worth Seeing. Interesting History and the hand painted walls are one of the most amazing things I have ever seen. Beware of the tourist traps outside - don't get ripped off with overpriced trinkets.
Buddha Temple. Good to see, -- This highly revered temple contains the Golden Image Buddha, which is made of solid gold and weighs approximately 5 ½ tons.

The temple with Air-con in China Town Area. These temple was small before did new big renovated and finnished in year2011; The new building has 5 storey; The 1st level is for car parking zone; 2nd and 3rd floor is a Thai-Chinese people historical air-con museum; the 4th floor is the Golden Bhuddha situated; the top floor is for a city view; These temple is easy to visit as it close to Hualumpong subway station.

Love the "new" location. It's been many tears since we last visited Wat Traimit and can only say "WHAT AN AMAZING DIFFERENCE. Loved it. Only down side was trying to get a taxi to use the meter to take us back to the hotel as the temple if off the track of BTS and MRT systems.

Near China town. We didn't expect to see the Golden Buddha. Just saw the temple from the bus (Number 40) and checked the map. We bought a ticket for seeing only the Golden Buddha (only 4th floor which display the Golden Buddha). There was some exhibition on 2nd and 3rd floor, however, we didn't see them.P.s. There was a bathroom and no charge

Completes the Visit to Buddhist Sites. Visited the temple of Golden Buddha. The story behind the deity statue is very interesting and intriguing. The temple gives experience of piousness, peace, harmony and amity. Though the place is small in area in comparison to some other temples but the serenity is exclusive. In addition to Temple of Emerald Buddha and Reclining Buddha, this place is also a must for any tourist or visitor to Bangkok having any religious or academic leanings or for otherwise keen learner.
Nice to look at. This was the second temple I visited during my stay in Thailand. It was very nice to look at. On a guided tour was very informative.
Must see on the list. Was marvelled by the Buddha Statue. Its a must see for all tourist visiting Thailand.Was worth standing in the queue to see the temple.

Peace of mind guaranteed. Not as huge as wat pho but better in my opinion. Doesn't take too much of time, an hour and half will do. Entry is inexpensive, I remember paying around 100 Thai Bhat, There is a lot of architecture on the walls for the eye. The actual Buddha statue is after 2 sets of stairs if I remember correctly. So be prepared for some stair climbing. Sitting for a few minutes with eyes closed gave me a bliss that I had experienced in very few places. I'm not theological or something, it just happened. Try it yourself! I found people smoking inside the temple premises. I am not complaining but it is a rare sight in Hindu temples.We happened to meet someone at the ticket counter, a friend of the guy working there and he had given us enormous and useful info about the temple and Thailand in general. Thai people in general are really nice, chatty and really down to the earth. Just sit at a bar and talk to a few of them and this makes you to really get connected to their world. Wonderful land. Wonderful people. Sure to visit again.

a Must see. Incredible that people who seem to earn and live with less than half of what we are accustomed to, have such a great devotion to their religion and are so generous with their contributions to build and maintain such beautiful monuments.

Beautiful Temple. Another of Thailands fabulous temples and Buddhas, So big and Gold, the walls of the temple are amazing. So worth a visit. Try do a temple tour which takes in the big three in Thailand only 3 hours
Interesting Visit. This was a good visit, Its very cheap, 100 Thai Bhat, and has plenty to see. The actual buddha is huge. Women have to cover their shoulders to go inside, and gowns are provided.

Best Temple Visit in Bangkok for Me. The Temple of the Golden Buddha was such an excellent excursion for me fiancé and I. It was the first temple on our list and I'm glad we started off on such a great foot. After visiting all the other "top" temples, I still stand firm that this was the best. It's so well planned and educational as well. They cater extremely well to English speakers. Because we went around midday in the low season of May, it was very calm and tranquil. I think a key part of enjoying these wonderful places of worship is avoiding the crowds. Highly recommend this beautiful temple. Spend some time in the exhibition areas, there's a lot to learn about Chinatown too.

Must watch in Bangkok. The place is all the worth for a visit... The architecture, the details , the craftsmanship and the history behind it is knowing and admiring.. The Buddha is made of gold... Even if u r not a follower of Buddha , it's a must to be visited once... Loved it...
Worth a look if you are into the Buddha thing. No pestering there, just left to do as you please without annoyances. Shops and services. You cant get a beer....but anything else.

A must visit for the first time travelers to Bangkok. This was the first temple we visited during our visit to Bangkok. It has a 5 ton deity of Buddha made of SOLID GOLD. Need I say more ? How many of you have seen that in real?

Very impressive. We went there with our guide and it was really impressive to see the big golden statue. This temple is in the Bangkok Chinatown district and there are many small alleys around you can discover!

Very nice. An amazing Buddha to see, but the tour would tell us amazing facts like 'all these walls are hand painted etc' and when we found out the temple was only built in 2009, it didn't seem as magical.
But the Buddha is great :)

An image made of gold and beautifully placed. One cannot imagine the value of this Buddha because it is not only very large, but the amount of gold that covers it makes it an invaluable treasure. I recommend a morning visit, as many tourists visit in the afternoon and have trouble entering the temple.

couldn't see. Heard that it's a nice temple with historical significance. But it Closes at 6pm. So even though it is on your way to Chinatown, consider visiting this early and separately since you will miss this if you visiting Chinatown for dinner.

Fantastic cultural experience. I visited the temple on the evening of chinese new year, the atmosphere was absolutely amazing, in the streets it was one big party but coming to the temple was a completely different experience all together, it was very relaxing to sit in the temple with the other people and gaze in amazement at the 5.5 tonnes solid gold buddha

Worlds largest solid gold statue. The origins of this statue remain uncertain. It is made in the Sukhothai Dynasty style, and is thought to have been made during the Sukhothai period in the 13th-14th centuries, though it could have been made after that time. is the world's largest solid gold statue. It is located in the temple of Wat Traimit, Bangkok.good views from top of the temple as well.

One of My Favorites. This must have ben one of my favorite spots in all of Bangkok. There was something about the ornateness of the whole location that really spoke to me, perhaps because I myself am all flash and no substance (just ask the people who know me). Besides the Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha, this is probably the location we ended up spending the most time at, both to marvel at the Golden Buddha and enjoy the views of Bangkok afforded from the top of the Temple.

It's solid gold!. There are many statues to pray and pay respect to in Bangkok but where else can you ask for prosperity from a 12,000 lb solid gold statue o the Buddha in the world? Definitely worth a visit, it is walking distance from Chinatown so you can stroll over after a nice meal.
Awesome Place. This was quite an experience. The enormous structure of Lord Buddha sleeping did sweep us out of our feet :-)

Must see. Between this, the reclining Buddha and the grand palace these are the must see sites in Bangkok in terms of temples. Cheaper to visit them without a tour guide but we had a private tour which meant we saw all of it without fighting our way around the city

golden buddha temple. The head of the statue is egg-shaped, which indicates its origin in the Sukothai period. Sukothai art had Indian influences.Metal figures of the Buddha made in India used to be taken to various countries for installation. So the Golden Buddha statue may have been cast in parts in India

Place with history. Besides nice view from the top, the temple has a very good museum, exhibiting the history of the gold Buddha and part of the Thai/Chinese history. The Gold Buddha was hidden in cement during Burmese war and it was accidentally discovered during the temple renovation.

A treasure. The largest gold Buddha in Thailand is housed in this temple. Mount the stairs along with pilgrims and tourists alike and take in the beauty. While you are here, make sure to visit the Chinese Buddhist temple across the street. It is colorful and beautiful and you can watch as the faithful come to throw yarrow sticks to have their fortune told after the ancient practice of I Ching.
Must - place of interest. My tip - you should go early in the morning, when not so many tourist in that Wat. But this place is very imposant and a must !

A Must if not already done!!!. It is Culture to not be seen in the western world.Lots of great pics to be taken here.we did Lots of different Temples it can be a bit Much, but this we Liked and also the Elephant Temple we thought worth a Visit.
Interesting visit. Lovely temple with a Buddha holding an interesting story...Also it is very nice to combine it with visit to Chinatown. All in all a must see in Bangkok!

Worth a visit. The temple itself isn't that grand from the outside, and apparently, it's not that old as well, but the golden Buddha itself was very impressive- can't believe it was made of solid gold. We visited this as part of a half-day temple tour and we were glad we saw it, and equally glad we saw it Before the Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha, as it would have been very underwhelming if we came here after those two places.

Must see....the world's largest gold idol!. We visited on a sweltering day in May. A flight of stairs took us to the top of the wat where the 5.5 kg gold Buddha is housed. We didn't stop for the museum on the 1st floor. The Buddha statue is huge but serene. It wasn't particularly crowded so we sat inside peacefully for a while. Don't forget to circumambulate the statue. There are other statues behind the mail idol. Sit down, say your prayers and meditate for a while. The top if the wat also has a great view of the Chinatown area of the neighbourhood.

Gold Buddha. Huge statue of Buddha made of pure Gold. It glows like Yellow fire !!!. Again a must see place in Bangkok. One has to climb up 2 - 3 floors (steps from ground) so, be prepared, but it is worth going up and having a glance of Gold Buddha.

Famous Golden Buddha Temple in Bangkok. Well worth the visit to this famous Bangkok temple as part of our city & temple tour which housed the awesome 5 1/2 tons golden statue of the Budhha. The temple complex is located in a congested locality of the city and we had to climb a flight of stairs to the 4th floor to see this golden Budhha statue where devotees thronged to offer their prayers. The temple complex also houses a museum for which there is an entry fee, unlike the free access to view the golden Buddha. Definitely, one of the main attractions of Bangkok.
gold!. biggest gold buddha in the world. musuem about chinatown in bangkok a good informative place to visit too in my opinion. make time to visit if you can afford to.

The Golden. I was very much astonished by getting to know from the guide that the statue is of pure solid gold of 5000kg and the whole statue was excavated from some ruins. It was a delight and you can see the image without blinking for hours. It's awesome.
Amazing. Buddha statue made of pure gold. 5000 .Good starting point for a walk true Chinatown. Visit the museum as well, it os worth it

Solid. Went there as part of a half day temple tour - others being the Reclining Buddha and the Marble Temple. The most impressive thing about this Buddha 1. it is the largest solid gold statue and 2. it was plastered in stucco till the 1950's - to safeguard it against the enemies. One doesn't need to spend more than a half an hour here. For the picture of course!
Beautiful. Awe inspiring Free water and 1hr wifi. Most women will have to wear a gown but a bright green one is provided.

Golden Buddha. Nothing much to write. Its made out of gold and the sheer amount of gold that had gone in its creation is something I cannot even fathom. It seems that it was covered in plaster possibly to save it from conquerors and while it was being transported here, it fell and the plaster cracked and they saw that there was gold inside. since then the plaster has been removed

Nothing much to see!. This is the first temple I visited in BKK. After getting to the top of the temple you would see the biggest buddah in the center and different buddha images around the inside temple. They will require you to remove your shoes upon entering their sacred house of worship. Souvenier keychains with your own photos taken are available by asking these photographers usually located on the temple ground .
The Largest Golden Buddha Image. The World's Largest and most Lustrous Golden Buddha Image. Probably one of the luckiest fellows in the world was a 1950's era crane operator from Bangkok, ..

Not a lot to see. Apart from the golden Buddha which is grand in its built quality, there isn’t much to see around the grand Wat. If you have lots of time on hand, then this may be another place to visit.

Interesting Buddha - Not a Lot Else To See. It is an interesting Buddha - But there is not much else to see! There a a number of temples with Buddhas that are similar. The statue itself is very nice and is solid gold. If you have already seen dozens of Buddhas in other temples, I am not sure that I would go out of my way to visit.
Fascinating. We were taken there by a Tuktuk driver as part of an unplanned "city tour", but after arriving there we were very glad to have come. The Temple and the Statue were fascinating.

Stunning. Well worth the visit just to see this solid gold Buddha. There is also a museum incorporated however the Buddha is four floors up and I am not aware of a lift. Not for the faint hearted especially in hot weather.
Golden Budda. Nice to see, dress appropriately ( otherwise no access or you have to "rent" a sarong to cover your legs) and go early morning to beat the rush.

Bigest Gold Buddha in the world. I visited this place on 04 May 2014 and take time at this place around 1 hour.Hilight of this temple is Bigest gold Buddha it's very amazing that you had never met any place before!All of body of Buddha made from real gold and look very nice with faithful so you can read the history from the museum inside the building. Don't miss this temple if you visit Bangkok!

Spiritual place. Even though not a Buddhist this is the most calm spiritual place I have been. Too see five and half tons of gold in the shape of a seated Buddha is breath taking, this temple is very strict on dress for both men and women.
Another awesome place. This is a great site because it is only one budda on her side but this is a must see experience. Again it is a place to reflect on gratitude.
interesting. I loved the whole spiritual side to Thailand, and this temple really just personified it. I really enjoyed it.

Temple tour. We visited three temples this one was the first very big. We visited the flower market first where we bought garlands to give to the Buddha even though this is not my religion you could see how much the people worshiped it

Stunning!!. A 'WOW' escapes you when Wat Traimit comes into view, awesome building, which is amazing considering it's historicall speaking 'new', It is interesting to read about the events leading to the discovery of Thailands Largest Gold Buddha in the exhibition, (you pay seperately for this), Up the stairs, lots of them, floor gets VERY HOT when foot wear removed, so do it right up close to the door entrance!! Eventually, on the top level of this Wat, you will be in the presence of the GOLD BUDDHA, it is very awe inspiring, gets busy up there, with many people of the world doing exactly like you are, don't feel rushed to go, have a little sit down in a 'quiet' corner and just 'be', its great, moving and worth it
beautifull Buddha. The temple itself is not that impressive from the outside and looks quite small but golden Buddha statue is very impressive!

5.3 tons of Gold Bling. Quite a mega Buddha to see with the wow factor!
Easy to access, remember to bring something to cover your shoulders.

Stunning Five-and-a-Half Tonnes of Gold. Stunning Five-and-a-Half Tonnes of Gold, yes that's what this temple is. Its legend, about being coated with plaster to escape the attention of marauding invaders and the eventual accidental discovery of gold inside the plaster by later generation Thais who themsleves were unaware, is wondrous. Never seen so much gold at one place! As with most other attractions of Thailand, photographs fail to capture the beauty that you experience when you see it first hand, in person.
famous. A trip to bangkok would not be complete without seeing the golden buddha temple , simply stunning , a famous iconic world class place .

Impressive Temple close to MRT. The Temple of Golden Buddha is impressive to view (inside and outside) with its gold. On this Thursday morning, we took the MRT and walked about 10 minutes. (The heat and humidity did not bother us.) The entry cost for the Golden Buddha on 4th floor is 40 Baht. We skipped the Exhibition on 2nd and 3rd floor (100 Baht). It was not crowded and we saw everything we wanted in 30 minutes. We have other temples and Grand Palace to visit.

Very Nice. If you have some free time it's worth the trip. I would say make sure you take water and dress appropriately. Staff are friendly to help you around. I would add this on the other Buddhas - make a day of it.

If you like gold. It's a massive gold Buddha in an awesome white temple layered with gold. It only takes about 30 minutes to visit and there were no guards enforcing the no photo rule. Everyone got their picture taken with the Buddha. Goldfinger would have been envious. The best part it's only a few blocks from Yaorawat Rd and the gold shops. My wife bought a 23 karat Baht necklace at Hua Seng Heng. Wait, why was that the best part?
amazing. This incredible statue in an otherwise unremarkable temple is well worth the hunt to find. The story of how it survived secretly for so long is fantastic.

Solid Gold !. Thailand is a place where you can find many beautiful temples. This one also one of them . Surely , if you want to see Beautiful Idol of Lord Buddha made of Solid Gold and weighing about 5.5 tons , this is the place. Make sure you visit early morning for a wonderful environment as it can get unpleasantly hot during the day time.

very very impressive. I'm working in a 5 stars cruise ship and we stopped 2 days in Bangkok. It was last march and it was like 45°C so kind of very hot for europeans like us and even more for a guy like originally coming from Brittany in France. This temple was the first I visited in Bangkok.... just wahouuuu... We were there with a collegue barman like me and 4 dancers... And we all couldn't speak while inside the temple, the statue is so big and the doors are so massive might be like 4 or 5 meters high... and all the drawing you have on the doors and all around the place... this site is very very particular ... If you stop by Bangkok you must see this temple
Beautiful. Its is beautiful outside, coulnt get in because it was closed the day i was there, but all the around the temple was amazing.....

Breathtaking!. This was our first visit to the temples. Learned we were expected to leave our shoes outside. Note to self: bring flip flops for easy removal!!!
Temple is beautiful, I can't enough of all the work you get to see around it.
It's just beautiful.

Worth visit place. Temple of the Golden Buddha will give you a very nice experience . There are a lot of gold budda statues here .It just amazing and definitely one to visit when traveletr come to Bangkok
Wat a Temple. If you like gold this will give you your fill but it is in very stark contrast to the condition a lot of Thais live in particularly along the canals.
Beautiful Buddha. The Golden Buddha is truely beautiful and a very popluar tourist destination. Easily accessible and situatied in a striking temple.

Nice visit. Great to go and see the Golden Buddha in person it is quite surreal to see. Area around the temple itself is a little to touristy however overall experience is quite good for a quick stop off whilst touring the city.

I'm not religious but it was okay. I like the idea of buddhism and very much appreciate it's modesty but what I dislike is the prices and overall attitude towards travelers and tourists. I really wanted to know more about the temple and the teachings but the monks and scholars didn't seem to like to answer my questions. Also it was quite expensive just to climb up stairs and gaze upon a golden buddha statue.
good. this is a very simple temple if compare to others around bangkok. the structure and culture here bring freeness to people.
Very impressive. This was the first Buddah we saw in Bangkok and it was very impressive close to china town which is also worth a visit

Definitely worth a visit. Whilst in Bangkok on a 3 day visit we booked a trip with our rep for temple visits - one of which was the Golden Buddha - just amazing and definitely one to visit when in Bangkok

Quick stop, but worth it. There is not much to see at this temple, except for the Golden Buddha. The Golden Buddha is huge and extraordinary. I stopped at this temple for probably 20 minutes and it was well worth it. If you have time I would recommend a short trip to this temple while you are in Bangkok.

Used to be better. The Buddha itself is quite extraordinary, although I am not convinced that it is a solid mass of gold of around 5 tonnes. Now that the new Wat for the Kings Birthday three years ago has been finished the site is extremely commercialised. The older, smaller, individual temples on the site are a much more authentic experience. That is where the local people place their gold leaf and you can get an instant horoscope from a multitude of gods and abbots.
Beautiful and serene. The whole temple is dazzling, but nothing comes near to eclipsing this beautiful golden image of the Buddha. Put it on your Must-Do list.

Lovely to place to visit. We went here as part of a city and temples tour. Facinating place to see, would go with a guide as you may miss the meaning of what different things mean and details that arent obvious such as the hand painted walls made to look like wallpaper. You dont have to stay long but is interesting..

A lot of gold and an interesting back-story. This is the only thing to see at this temple. The structure is relatively new but certainly elaborate and intricately detailed. The Golden Buddha is huge and well worth seeing but seemed to be the only reason to stop here.

Superb. Had a quick 1 hour visit here and it was really good and well worth the visit. As always ignore the guys outside telling you it's closed today as they just want to give you a taxi ride somewhere else. Nothing malicious as they just want a fare in their cabs or tuk tuks. No need to wear long pants here.

Wat is the fuss about?. Wat Traimit (or the one with the Golden Buddha) is located near Chinatown in Bangkok, and is famous housing the world’s largest golden statue, weighing in at 5.5 tonnes. The origins of this Buddha statue are unknown, although now they are a highlight for any backpacker’s itinerary while in the city. It will cost you 40Baht to see just the Golden Buddha, and a further 100Baht to see other areas of the temple. If you have seen the Emerald Buddha at the Grand Palace, then there is not really any need to come and see the Golden version. I was not too interested in Wat Traimit, although I have given it three stars because of its Buddha. The temple compounds are really nothing special.

Really worth seeing - Can't believe it's solid gold!. I saw this temple as part of a tour and was really glad I managed to see it. One thing that I didn't realise: In a temple you have to take off your shoes and socks before entering! I had no idea about this, therefore stupidly was wearing trainers and socks which meant a lot of faffing around, therefore I would suggest sandals or some footwear that is very easy to take on and off.The entry was only 20 Baht so if I wasn't part of a tour it was hardly expensive. The Buddha was amazing and apparently is solid 18 carat gold and weighs over 5 tonnes. It's not a massive temple, but just an amazing experience. China town is quite near by and if you have finished in the temple, just go down the steps and make a left and go out the back of the temple and cross the road - you may think you've found China town straight away, however that's a Chinese temple, you need to walk further up the road :-)Certainly worth a visit, just a lovely example of a temple.

Important Temple to visit. Inside you will find a 5 tons Buddha, is very important for buddhism. It's very nice outside either, you will climb two big stairways to get inside, there you feel a nice vibe to have some meditation time. Outside you will find a lot of metallic hearts hanging and behind a huge vessel. People throws some coins inside if you are success you will return to Bangkok. Be sure not to show your legs and arms inside the temple, they are estrict with that. This temple is near Chinatown you can reach it walking or taking a tuk tuk. Be carefull to agree the price previously, otherwise you can have a bad experience. More of the time they cheat on you, they tell you ok, and when you get to the place they say that the price was for each person,

Beautiful Temple. I was there during meal times and wasn't allowed much access. I was able to see the inside of the temple from a window and did manage to get some decent photos. There was a friendly and knowledgeable tour guide to show me around.

Can be skipped unless visiting nearby Chinatown. The temple is located on a small hill, reachable by climbing through steps (not too much). At the upper level there is no special view but to enter into the small temple. You cannot evaluate its ancient esteem since it seems, for foreigners, as other golden Buddha statues. Sorry for not being so impressed. The is a small fee for temple access and increased fee if it is including a museum.The closest station is Hua Lamphong railway station. Beware of those "guides" which will try to lead you to an another Buddha using an opportunity of nearby taxi. An ugly local habit to cheat tourists nearby almost every famous temple in Bangkok.
Solid Gold. Interesting to see temple with a solid gold Budha about 4 metres high. Worth a quick visit. We got there early and there wasn't much of a crowd, entry was cheap.

Stunning. Was a beautiful statue, a little over rated nothing else there. Women must wear something that covers their shoulders (shawl). Your expected to leave your shoes at a designated area and walk up a couple of steps to the temple, on the day we went it was 42 degrees so our feet just burned.
Can not be missed. Probably all tourists like us will never skip over this very interesting travel site named Temple of The Golden Buddha once visiting Bangkok. We do vote for this place

Feel like a celebrity. As soon as we got to the site a bunch of photographers jumped out to take our photos. It was like being Beyonce! Seeing the Golden Buddha was interesting, but be sure to wear socks because the ground was burning hot. when we came out the photographers had created buttons with our photos on them.

Not to be missed, 5 tons of gold!. Located at the corner of Chinatown, Wat Traimit for some reason is not as well known as the other major temples in Bangkok. But it is well worth the visit. If your sense of direction is weak, plan on taking a taxi to get there, as the surrounding roads were rather oblique to me. The temple itself houses a magnificent 5 ton gold Buddha, a quantity of gold that one is unlikely to see in one eyeful anywhere else except a gold depository. The surroundings are relatively quiet and unhurried, so take as much time as you want.

Simply beautiful. We took cab to golden buddha. Bangkok has most of its attraction within 10 kms and most of the cab drivers ply on meter. The golden buddha was awesome. Its so peaceful just being in that place. "Amazing". On our way back one tuk tuk operator offered to take us to wat pho. but he took us in wrong direction and entered a deserted street. I stopped him and demanded his license and he just drove off. We walked appox 300 mtr to the main road and took a taxi and gave up the idea to go to wat pho that day. Take only taxis. Tuk tuk is a bad experience so beware.
A Magnoficent Home for a magnificent monument to Buddhism. This solid gold Buddha sits in the midst of a hall of a marble building that is exquisite in every way.
Golden Buddha. This was amazing! 5 1/2 tons of solid gold. The history of this Buddha was very interesting. Having a guide to explain the significance of each Temple helps.

Located at Grand a Palace. The President changes his dress 3 times a year to fit the season. However he is 87 so very unlikely he performs this ceremony. Very small Buddha, almost like the little mermaid in Copenhagen. No pictures or shoes allowed.

Worth the trip. Great place to visit for the day, make sure your covered other wise they will give you some clothes to wear
Take a camera some great photo opputunitys

Wat Traimit. Solid gold and worth billions by now, but beautiful and only discovered fairly recently - was encased in concrete. Great Guide too from Experience BANGKOK and thanks to Toowee, our guide.

New temple, old Buddha. The golden Buddha (reputed to be solid gold and weigh about 12 tons) is a must-see in Bangkok. The story of how it was discovered and found to be pure gold is interesting. This was the first Thai temple we saw, so we were duly impressed. We saw several other temples after that, and they got better and better.
Worth a visit, well £250m says yes it is!. 3 meters tall and solid Gold, weighing in at 5 tonnes plus. A very tranquil Wat despite the value in view!

Golden Buddha and Heritage Centre. Another impressive Buddha which is a must see. Coupled with this one is the Yaowarat Chinatown Heritage Centre which is worth visiting. Get your tickets at the same time they are very cheap , it's air conditioned and won't take too long. Ladies wear a shawl and all remove shoes.

Important temple, less tourist.. Pro: 1. Situated the biggest gold bhuddha statue in the world 2. Near MRT. (Hua Lam Pong Station)3. Close to China Town: 4. No tuk tuk scam (so far)5. Not much tourist. So it is quite peaceful. Cons- There are major subway construction in the area. Very bad traffic. So please understand if taxi refuse to take you there, take short cut, or take you to longer journey as they try to avoid traffic jam.Tips:- There is elevater in the back of the main building.
Third temple in BKK you can't miss.. Together with Wat Pho and Wat Arun, this temple makes your temple visits in BKK complete for a good idea of Budhism and itculture.
Superb temple with great art work. the art work inside the temple and the maintenance of the golden buddha. Also the information center available in the premises of the temple

Simple, short and not boring. Not being an avid 'tourist' who likes to spend whole days visiting sites this was great. It's 200 baht all in to see the golden Buddha and tickets to the exhibition - which told a really great story, was air conditioned and relatively short. The Buddha was impressive although ladies will need shoulders covered (pashmina etc). You also have to take off your shoes.
Gold Buddha. You can just spent half-n-hr or so at the max, except the Golden Buddha no other excitement. I felt its just like adding one more point in your sight seeing that's it...
Very pretty. Loverly we'll worth a visit I really enjoyed walking around here.its easy to get to by taxi or tuk tuk deepening on were you are staying.
interesting. Another temple on the must see list , this was a great view in the morning with the sun shining on the temple roof , looked awesome , worth seeing .
Bigger than expected. very impressive. again shoes removed and knees and shoulders covered. Not busy. Very impressive and much bigger than expected.

Fabulous place. A beautiful building, with a very large gold Buddha. The entry fee is very small, be forewarned that the Buddha is located at the top of the temple up a couple of flights of stairs. Worth the effort though. Amazing craftmanship in the temple and decorations. Visited this temple on a day tour. Was beautiful and well worth a visit when in Bangkok. Be prepare though it gets very busy during peak time. The histiory behind this Buddha is amazing. It was once covered in plaster and discovered by the swedish people. On a flood event, the plaster came off in some parts revealing the gold behind the mask! It is beautiful and big.
Nice Place... A complete Golden statue of Buddha..nice temple but in a crowds location..One time watch..If you have time..Standing Buddha also nearby..It's an average attraction..

Solid Gold. Close to the Chinatown Gateway, this temple is certainly worth seeing. You have options of seeing the Golden Buddha, the relocation of the Buddha and discovery of it being made of gold exhibition and another about the Chinese in Bangkok. The entry fee is modest so you may as well see them all. The temple is an active temple, leave your shoes on the racks and people are there praying - so be thoughtful about taking photos and respect privacy.The entry token is a small plastic affair that has a photo of the Buddha and makes a nice souvenir.

Really nice. A beautiful building, with a very large gold Buddha. The entry fee is very small, be forewarned that the Buddha is located at the top of the temple up a couple of flights of stairs. Worth the effort though. Amazing craftmanship in the temple and decorations.

Good for a quick stop.. Hau Lamphong MRT Metro Station stop on blue line. Exit station, cross street & bridge, follow white signs marked Wat Traimat.Temple is across the street from Chinatown's big entrance. No shoes at Buddha entrance. T-shirt/long pants good. 40 baht for 4th floor entrance only (Golden Buddha). Ticket booth on side of temple, just past large steps in front. Can't miss.

Beautiful Religious Place. It is such a beautiful place just a short walking distance from Hualumpong railway station, and the China Town. The architecture is just wonderful. The parking space is limited, and I dislike the double pricing here. It would be better they just charge a small amount equally to Thais and non-Thais.

Amazing story. The story of how this enormous gold buddha was discovered, covered in concrete, is really interesting. It was one of the most beautiful temples we visited. If we had to chose this over the Emerald Buddha (we visited both temples), this one was our favorite.
Beautiful. Visited this temple on a day tour. Was beautiful and well worth a visit when in Bangkok. Be prepare though it gets very busy during peak time.
Gorgeous!. I was moved to tears by the humble placement of this gorgeous buddha and all the other statuary, including the Wat Cats! :)
An amazing site to behold. The history. I was in awe of the aritistry and the religious significance of this great symbol of Buddhism.

Well kept and renovated temple in China town. it is a secondary sight and after seeing Wat Phra Kaeo, Wat Pho and Wat Arun it is not as stunning. However the temple is freshly renovated and well kept and can be easily combined with a visit to China town

Simply beautiful. The histiory behind this Buddha is amazing. It was once covered in plaster and discovered by the swedish people. On a flood event, the plaster came off in some parts revealing the gold behind the mask! It is beautiful and big. The temple is very nice and the walls painted by hand. Amazing! You have to walk up sets of stairs, so be aware!
Good. Hi, One of the sightseeing place in itinerary and was good like many temples that we visited. day trip will cover everything but must visit is the Grand Palace.

Temple with Solid Gold Buddha. This is a beautiful Temple with a large solid gold Buddha inside. The Buddha is extremely shiny and the story of it being covered was very interesting. The Buddha was covered in plaster stucco at some time and when it was moved in 1930 or 1950 depending on source. some of the plaster fell off and the true golden Buddha was revealed. The Buddha is 5.5 metric tons and stands an impressive 3 meters tall. This was the first temple I visited in Bangkok and was very busy with tourists. One of the young woman in our group had her flip flops taken while we were inside.

Large and gold. By the time I got to see this buddha image I had already been in SE Asia for three months and had seen many images, however the fact it's solid gold and so large still is very impressive. I didn't get to see the museum as it was closed however its still worth checking out.
Great Temple. We got there accidentally while walking from Hua Lamphong station to Wat Arun. There is small fee for entrance but place is definitely worth a visit.

Shiny, Golden Buddha with Blessings & Money Exchange. We stopped at Wat Traimit, home of the Golden Buddha in the morning as part of the SmarTours Amazing Thailand group. This was our first temple of the trip. We removed our shoes as we went inside. The Buddha was almost 10 feet tall and very shiny, made of solid gold. The story is interesting. The statue had been covered with plaster to hide it from thieves. It had been discarded, until one night a monk had a dream that the lump of plaster had important value. As he looked through one of the cracks in the plaster in the light of day, something shiny appeared. The statue was recovered and now on display here. Five tons of gold.I also love the story of the position that Buddha sits in at this temple called Calling the Earth to Witness. It was the position of his last temptation right before his enlightenment.We got a new year’s blessing there from a monk. They were sitting at the foot of the stairs to enter the temple. We weren’t sure how it worked. Our guide told us what to do. We gave a small donation, 10 baht, by putting it in the donation box, and sat down in front of one of the monks. He looked very jolly, almost like the Buddha himself. First he doused us with water, shaking it from bamboo sticks on us. It was a very hearty blessing. The he let us pick out a bracelet, color of our choice, and he put that on our wrists. It went on the left wrist for women and right wrist for men. It was a highlight of the day.We exchanged money here because the banks were closed for the New Year’s holiday. The exchange rate was comparable to what we found at the banks so it was a convenient and good place to exchange money.There are vendors outside the temple selling various items from food to trinkets. As you enter, there are vendors selling on the inside as well. Our admission was included as part of our tour so I don’t know what it cost. There is no shortage of tuk tuks outside so it would be easy to get a ride here and find a ride to your next location if you weren’t on a tour.

worlds largest Solid gold statue of Buddha. Nice place to visit. It is located at edge of china town. It has a solid gold statue with many other artifacts. Very crowded place. You can donate some money inside and take 1 holy water bottle.People need to be alert as there are frauds, cheaters around where there is too much crowd. For INDIANS : One person may approach and say he is from Bahrain and use word Masha-allah again again during conversation. He would say he is planning to visit India (will talk about his sister in Delhi and wife wants silk saree and some blah blah...) and wants to know which dollars are accepted in India and WILL ASK YOU TO SHOW YOUR DOLLARS. Which he will take in his hands to check but will take few from them in front of you and you will not get to know. Very good hand work but you may lose some money. :P DO NOT SHOW HIM YOUR CURRENCY NOTES. Later when reported security says they know about him and he is from Iran. He targets Indians.
The Golden Budha is an amazing piece of art.. The statue of the Golden Budha is not only of solid gold but also a great piece of art you really must see.

Astonishing golden Buddha. The astonishing vast golden Buddha is the largest solid gold artefact in the world. It indicates the extraordinary wealth and taste of the early Siamese civilization at Sukhothai. It is now beautifully displayed in a modern temple (Wat Traimit) on the edge of Chinatown.

The gold standard!. Wat Traimit is walking distance from the Hua Lamphong station which is the main railway station in Bangkok and connected with buses, MRT, tuktuks, taxis and every other mode of transport possible. You can even come to the Marine Department ferry stop and walk down. The temple itself or the Buddha statue it houses easily boggles the mind with the sheer extravagance of gold thats gone into making it. Be careful of the tuktuks outside offering ridiculously low fares for hiring them for the whole day or several hours. Avoid them for your life!
Must see the exibition and Buddha. If you are buying tickets, buy whole package, because, it very nice and good exhibitions below the Golden Buddha floors.
Bit disappointed. Buddha is a must see, location was under development with a lot of scaffolding. Overall was a bit disappointing and not as grand as expected.
Too many tourists. Too many tourists, so it's difficult to see temple in details. I understand, that this is not a characteristic of the temple itself, but as attraction place - 4 stars of 5.

Maybe better than the Reclining Buddha. Nice view from the top fourth floor as I recall. Don't believe you really have to pay to go to the top. But you do have to pay to get into the museum on the lower floors. Short 5 minute walk from the Train Station and Subway but a bit confusing -- look for the signs to the Golden Buddha, and also note your are right next to China Town entrance Gate.

Right in China Town. Seems like there is a china town in every part of the world and temple of Golden Buddha is located in Bangkok’s china town and the temple boasts of a 9ft tall Buddha all covered in Gold and while Bangkok is bathed in statues of Buddha in every possible pose and size this one is equally breathtaking as the other and comes with a strict warning to be not missed at any cost for its sheer beauty. The entrance is around 20 baht and for that the experience is priceless Wat

Must see this Wat. A temple worth seeing...despite many tourists milling round there is a calmness that permeates evey corner. The faithful locals, praying to Buddha, sit serenely oblivious to the interlopers. Try the river taxi (dont get coerced into a private boat) and get off at stop 4. Have a look at some of the stalls in the side streets. When you need to cool down try coconut icecream from a local vendor.
Golden BUddha. There are Buddhas everywhere...some big some small, some in gold some marble some sitting some sleeping...various styles

Good visit. Worth a visit to this wat, located in Chinatown. The wat itself is impressive and then you can walk into the heart of Chinatown to roam the alleyways and streets and take in all the sights of the food stalls.

Dazzling!. We went at night on Chinese New Year so the experience was multiplied. Try to see it at night but ask if it's open before you go. The contrast of the black sky with the hold and white is seriously breathtaking. This is a grand structure with lots of stairs, leading to one of the most lavishly decorated temples i have ever seen. Built in Thai traditional style stressing gold as the main color. Gold being a symbol of untainted purity, like the lotus, growing out of mud but unsoiled by it. Lovely place, calm and refreshing, in high contrast with the bustling china town around it. Don't miss it.
viewing of the golden buddha. only viewing and praying to the Golden Buddha. We also got blessing by the local monk. Expect lots of stairs climbing.

Buddha makes a miracle. We were famished by our Wat tour, and while searching for somewhere to eat discovered "Thai Bavorn". This restaurant serves good Thai food. The Roast Duck was amazing. MUY, the cook, is generous and speaks fantastis English.The restaurant is located 50mts approx.to the left of the exit gate.
incredible buddha. Very nice place to visit. The golden enormous buddha is really worth seeing. Would be nice with some more info around the premises.
biggg... its worth a visit for some photos.nothing else..made of pure gold as told by guide..nothing else to see around

Smaller temple (compared to all others in Bangkok!), but a good one. As we were using mrt/skytrain, finding this place took some time.. there were directions/boards, but I guess, we got lost thanks to a "guide" whom we ended up asking directions.. he said the place was closed & we should instead be going to some other temple!.. we said thanks & ignored, walked about a mile, to find the place actually very close the MRT station (walkable). It was open, except for the museum. But the Golden Buddha is just amazing, you can actually feel the peace & warmth (provided there is no crowd). Since its very a small temple, you wouldnt need more than 30-40 mins. strongly recommended & worth the visit. Its next to the China town.. you can plan both the visits same day/evening. There are some good/really good local restaurants on the way back to MRT. We had one of the best meals there (corner one). I really dont remember the name, but there was only one decent sit/eat restaurant & you should be able to find it easy. I think it was right opposite to a 7/11

Amazing Buddha in Gold. Overall, this place is not majestic....till you climb up to the 4th level and come face to face with the Gold Buddha. It is really amazing also to see how peaceful this place is once you get up there. We took the full package including tickets to see the exhibits. For historical and understanding purpose, I think it is really worth it.  NOTE OF ADVISE: Careful of the tuk-tuks around the area. They are all out to make a quick baht and cannot be trusted. Walk to the MTR as it is a lot safer.

Stunning gold Buddha. Well worth the climb in sweltering heat. Ladies need to cover knees and shoulders out of respect. It was nice to see so many Thai people there burning incense and praying. It almost felt wrong to be there as a tourist, but they were never in any way unwelcoming. Definitely go see this magnificent Buddha and the reclining Buddha - both are amazing.

wow. made of solid gold. it was a different experience altogether. however, the maintenance outside the main temple wasnt great. It could have been made more tourist friendly place. All in all a place to visit only for religious purpose and to see a solid gold idol.

Golden Buddha. Brilliant, and it is in the China town area of Bangkok. We saw the Buddha with open mouth and it looks as if there is no security, but you cannot identify them. Hats of to Thai people to preserve and saefgurad such a treasure

Bright and Beautiful!. Not to be missed if you are in Bangkok. Some of the gold (top of the head) is 99% pure, and the statue weighs over 5.5 tons. Current value as scrap? - maybe around £150,000,000. Fabulous.

The story about the golden buddha. Back in school I actually remembering one of my friends telling this insane story about how they found a golden buddha hidden inside a "regular" buddha, by accidentally dropping it and its inner secret being revealed.Quite a few years later, 25 or so, the story comes back to me by accident. Hadn't done my home work properly and by chance visited this temple as my last one in Bangkok. And there it was, the story from childhood once again. It really is nothing short of a crazy story of how they find this gold buddha in whats seems to be a quite good "regular" buddha, but here it is. The buddha it self is really great, the fact its being in gold sets it quite apart from the rest of them, doesn't it? On the temple grounds you'll also find to exhibits, one of the story behind the buddha and how he ended up where he did and on the Chinese community here in Bangkok with has its bearings on the buddha as well.

Beautiful Temple. Easy visit if you are in the area. Beautiful building and an amazing Buddha sculpture. Be sure to read the story behind it as it is very interesting. Make sure you are dressed appropriately with shoulders covered and at least knee length shorts. If you not, you can always purchase a sarong right in front.
Pride Of Thailand. Great place to visit and see a unique Golden Statue. This can be called the Centre of Attractions of Thailand.

Will take your breath away. At first sight this Buddha will take your breath away, the sheer size and its magnificence are fantastic. Make sure you spend 1-2 hours visiting all the sights, also must visit the Museum in the complex.

What’s attractive in Bangkok. The first tourist attraction we visited on my second trip to Bangkok was the Temple of the Golden Buddha. Some of my colleagues have never been to any Asian country and they were really interested with what the culture could have offered. The interior isn’t that much attractive compared to the others but the Temple of the Golden Buddha is said to be the most famous. The business and market research tour that we had in certain Bangkok attractions helped a lot for us to understand our target market even more. The culture may vary but the feeling of putting the importance of history is both practiced by my home country and in Bangkok. The thing that I didn’t like though, was that there was a ticket entrance fee.
