sights to see. another example of thai tradition and culture that is worth visiting.shopping is good but you can shop anywhere. this is culture.

Temples everywhere. On the way to china town we stopped by this temple. Very glittery temple and lots of people in and out. Great photo op. Dress appropriately. If you visit this as part of the boat tour, take a tuk tuk as it is a far walk from the dock. They will ask for the fare and if you want to go cheaper they will want to take you to a business so you can browse. That way they get a little less money from you and money from the business that you have to stop at. My suggestion....pay the full fare unless you want to buy a custom made suit along the way.....which I was not planning to do. Plus if you go directly to the temple it is a much shorter tuk tuk ride.

Amazing Golden Buddha. To think about the size and weight of this solid golden Buddha statue is mind numbing.It is not as crowded as the Wat Phra Kaew, Wat Pho or Wat Arun but still provides and excellent view. We visited this place via the Hua Lampong MRT station. Once you are out of the station cross the bridge and look for the sign that leads to Yaowarat Road. Best time to visit is in the afternoon after which you could go to Yaowarat (Chinatown) and enjoy the various street food there.
Worth popping by while visiting ChinaTown. Dropped by when heading to ChinaTown, very nice temple. Remember to dress appropriately when visiting the temples, if not robes can be loan at each temple.
Just about average. The statue is very calm and beautiful. Just a 5 min walk from the Hua Lampong MRT station. Can visit once.

Beautiful. Set in a beautifully decorated temple, this golden Buddha sits serenely meditating over the city. For such a valuable item it is open to visitors and not sealed in a Perspex box or the like. Thai people were meditating at the foot of the statue as we walked around and life seemed to continue oblivious to the intrusion of a stream of tourists.

Massive solid gold statue. Although I live in Bangkok, I had not been yet to Wat Traimit. The Buddha statue is the largest gold statue in the world. This temple is close to the main railroad stain (Hua Lamphon) and Chinatown. It is a revered place for Thais as it dates back to the Sukothai period in the 13th-14th century. The shrine that holds the golden statue is beautifully decorated. There is a nice view on the surroundings from the platform, where you enter the temple. Really worth seeing in Bangkok too.

golden buddha. It was amaizing to see the image of the largest Golden Buddha in the world.It is a Buddha image in the mara conquering attitude,the typical artistic style of the days when Sukhothai was the capital of Thailand.It was made of pure gold.

Amazing!. The true beauty of the Thai can be felt here. We're dealing with a 12 tonne status of the Buddha....made of solid gold!! Amazingly enough, the Thai people are so trusting that they have no cameras, security checks, no screens, and no doors keeping us away from the majestic statue of the Buddha! We could even take videos and pictures at no extra charge. Talk about trust.......it was such a humbling experience, being so close to such a historical statue that has been there for centuries......it's amazing how down to earth the Thai people are to keep such a lovely work of art in such good condition, and in such close proximity to the public. The temple is intricate and charming. Places like this are a symbol of peace and unity throughout the world and remind us of the beauty that this world is filled with!
Magnificent golden Buddha. It is a magnificent sight . It is well maintained. The surroundings are clean. A visit to the museum is must.

What can you say about a six ton golden Buddha?. It is one of the more delicate Buddhas. To think it had been hidden in plaster and no one knew about it being gold is hard to believe. It is just plain beautiful.

Off the beaten path, but worth it. There is one point to this temple, and that's that is contains a rather large Buddha made of "solid" gold. It really is a pretty spectacular sight to behold. It's also set in a really nice terraced temple. I recommend buying the ticket that includes the museum. The top floor of the museum is actually pretty good and puts the Buddha in a very nice historical context. It also gives some context to some of the other religious sites you see in Thailand. The lower floor with an exhibit and movie on Chinatown is totally skippable. This temple is slightly out of the way, but not all that hard to get to from the MRT and totally worth a detour. If you're in Bangkok when the tourists are slamming the Grand Palace and Wat Pho, this is kind of a nice respite where you're likely to see as many Thais as Farangs.
Impressive. This is a very large Buddha and of course the place is crowded. Taking photos is a challenge due to the size and the crowds. The grounds around the temple are beautiful too.

Intriguing history, well-housed with galleries. Not much more can be added here to the amazing story of how the solid-gold Buddha figure was hidden under a coat of stucco for hundreds of years. But that story is well presented in the gallery below the statue. Also noteworthy is the gallery in the temple that explains some history of the Yaowarat area -- Chinatown; it's well worth the nominal fee to see the dioramas, short film, and exhibits. When visiting the temple, try not to let your picture-taking and gawking interfere with the worship and prayer rituals of the Buddhists there.

Crying all the way. I went alone to the Temple of the Golden Buddha. I purchased my ticket and climbed the stairs to the top of the temple (5 minute walk) I purchased some flowers as an offering to Buddha and was instructed to site right in front of the Buddha (I am guessing I purchased the front row and center ticket of sorts) I sat down and started to cry, I felt so at home here in this place and sitting in front of this buddha made my Heart feel open and happy. Sounds so corny but was very real for me. This attraction is worth the visit the temple itself was stunning and the views from the top are priceless

FULL OF GOLD GREAT PLACE.. This temple is near the china town. Must visit in the early morning because in the afternoon it becomes crowded. You get nice & knowledgable books on buddha and worth visiting the temple.

HIdden for centuries, now on display. This Buddha was covered in concrete hidden for centuries. It was discovered in the last century as they tried to move it. It fell off of a hoist and the concrete cracked revealing the gold. It's now in a beautiful temple and is on display.
Great. The Buddha was beautiful. Must see. And easy to combine with a tour of Chinatown. Be prepared to climb some steps though!
intriguing. intriguing. amazing. must visit. can get crowded, but worth the visit. try going early. a must see for sure.

Great place. Bangkok is full of great temples and this is one of them. Not the biggest, but it was nice to see the Golden Buddha. Go there first thing in the morning, because can get crowded. It was nice to see monks outside of the temple

Gold Buddha. Bangkok is full of great temples and this is one of them. Not the biggest, but it was nice to see the Golden Buddha. Go there first thing in the morning, because can get crowded. It was nice to see monks outside of the temple
Worth Visit !. This temple is located near the china town. good place to see as it is less crowded. The souvenir shop is very nice and offers much variety !

massive big lump of gold. massive 5 ton gold buddha at one end of china town, good for a vist, passes ten minutes, inexpensive entry fee, if you are a lady be sure to cover shoulders, take a shawl wth you everywhere you go, to all attractions like this, or they make you hire one.

Golden Budha. This was my last site on Wat visits. It is quite impressive and beautiful . Compared to other sites this is less crowded and taking pictures is allowed. Nice souvenir shop . Worth making this visit as part of China Town tour which is just around the corner.

Real Gold Buddha. This was the first place I visited in Bangkok and it was too good. This is a must see along with the Wat Pho and Wat Arun. Try to spend quality time here. Sleeveless and shorts are not allowed, so try bringing a shawl or something to cover up. Otherwise, you can rent a shawl outside.
Real Gold Buddha. It is very pretty to look at the temple. My first temple in Thailand. I enjoyed my visit. Loved the details everywhere. Worth the visit.

Not much to see. One of the smaller temple, has an entrance fee, u'll spend less than an hour here perhaps less than 30 mnt plus when i visit the toilet was closed (it was noon ard 1 pm), a bit ridiculous.

Most valuable religious relic worth a see. Buy the ticket to see both the Buddha and the museums. Guinness Book of World Records holder of must $ valuable religious relic. Pretty impressive sight knowing it's real gold. Lots of history to learn. Grounds also sell souvenirs.

Very impressive Buddha and temple. Less crowded and much more enjoyable than the grand palace. Remember to wear 'respectable clothing' in Thai standards including covering shoulders and knees (goes for both men and women) and easy to remove shoes as you can't wear shoes inside the actual Buddha temple.

A quick visit if you are passing by.... I guess if you are visiting the near by china town... you can have quick pop into this temple... it will take half hour max for a complete visit. The temple is small and cute with great marble architecture (check out the roof inside).

The essence of Bangkok. Maybe I was just exaggerate it, but when you set your foot here, you know that your visit in Bangkok is officially legitimized. The Temple itself, is a part of the Grand Palace Complex, full of details, you will find too many spot to shoot pics here....be there in the early morning, and beware that the place could be very crowded. I really like the architecture, the ornament best. Bring your camera, walking shoes, proper but light and comfortable dress. Dont forget to bring bottled water. If you like taking pics, you could spend 1-2 hours here. The charge has been included in the Grand Palace ticket ( 500 THB each person per November 2013).
Great temple. A must see, great temple! can get very busy so go early. This area can been done in about an hour. Don't forget you will be more covered up then normal so you can get hot quickly

Definitely stop and see it. Very cool temple right near Chinatown in Bangkok. You could probably include it in a walking trip of Chinatown. Don't bother to pay if you don't want to, only tourists are expected to pay. Be respectful, wear appropriate clothing. Remember that for many this is sacred and there are many here that are worshiping. It is something to see, very impressive. A highlight of things to see in Bangkok.

Artistic, serene. To cut out a serene temple in the midst of clogged streets is something. The beauty of the architecture, the calm of the main temple and the magnificent golden Buddha - it summarises the temple. It does not span over a large area, but the architecture works for it. Once you must!

Over 5 tons of a solid gold Buddha. Near the China Town gate, the temple is rather small, but the solid gold Buddha is impressive. The temple lacks the space of other temples, but this is worth the trip to be dazzled by so much gold. And you can then tour China Town.
Best golden Buddha you will ever see. Very nice temple, with a huge golden Buddha located just next to the China Town. Please follow the dress-code for all the temples in Bangkok.

Worth visiting as part of Chinatown trip. We went down on a Monday, which is when the exhibition is closed, so can't comment on that. The Golden Buddha is beautiful, and the story behind it is worth reading. After that, Chinatown is less than ten minutes away, so it's easy to combine the two sights in a morning or afternoon.

Combine this trip with China Town visit.. It is another big Buddha that you can see in Bangkok. I did not see anything special. As a non budhists all the Buddhas became somewhat similar to us so this visit of Golden Buddha was not that exciting to us. You can skip it if you have someting better to do. We enjoyed the most the china town which is near by wat traimit.
Impressive. Despite thinking that I wouldn't, I nonetheless gaped at the Buddha along with everyone else. Lots of the other areas in the compound are beautiful or at least, interesting.
A temple you must see.. Probably one of the best temples I have seen and a beautiful Buddha .There were a lot of people there but that is normal for Bangkok.

Enthralling visit. I was fascinated with this temple, and the delicate artwork surrounding it. The Buddha itself is stunning. It helps to visit with a guide, so they can tell you all the history and features surrounding this temple. The more you know, the more appealing the temple becomes.
Just a temple. Just a temple as many others. We found nothing interesting here. Ticket price is around 200B for a person. Temple of Dawn is better)
2 and a half tons of solid pure gold, is what you are seeing.. I have only great things to say about the presentation of this, the biggest solid gold buddha in the world.

Very Intersting . lots of people. we went there after a trip to the grand Palace . Probably too much temple in a short time . Very busy. Worthwhile visiting as the Buddha is stunning . Lots of people though -seemed busier than the Grand palalce
gold buddha.. amazing ton of gold to make buddha.......its good to visit on evening time....coz day time too much rush and many tourist.

Impressive. This is the biggest golden statue in the world with a very interesting history.
It gives out a lot of energy and it's one of the many remarkable places in Bangkok
A Must see. It was amazing to see the Golden Buddha and learn the history of how the golden Buddha was found. It was breath taking and in an amazing temple.

Impressive amount of gold. We had quite a while in Bangkok (in total we were there for about 8 whole days) so decided to visit here even though it hadn't been on our original list. Glad we did as the solid gold Buddha is pretty impressive. If you find yourself with a spare half hour or so I'd recommend a visit. It's not everyday you can see quite that much solid gold.

Its In the centre of Bangkok. A spectacular temple. AS you walk up to it you need to crane your neck to see the top. The budda is the biggest ever seen and shines out at youin gold. A busy temple with many visitors. Was lovley to see so many monks around the temple. Wear clothes that cover you up.

Top 2 temples to visit while in Bangkok. Excellent temple with some interesting history, enjoyed it during the 3 temple tour. You can get the ticket for 100 B and receive a pamphlet that describes the history so you may not need a guided tour. Suggest you take a tour than travelling yourself unless you are sure. this place is not connected with the MRT

Gorgeous But All Blur Together. On our Bangkok trip, we visited many temples and while they are all indeed impressive and dazzling, etc - I hate to say it, but after you've seen a few, you've seen them all. This may be very different for a Thai local or a practicing Buddhist, but to this particular tourist, they lost their luster after the first four or five. They are all impressive and gaudy and have great dragon and guardian statues, but they do all tend to blur together pretty quickly.

Spectacular. This is a must see, with breathtaking craftsmanship of the pillars, paintings, and stones. The size of the buddha is awe inspiring, and every step of the way is paved with fascinating artistry of buddha's life. There is a row of wooden bowls, where people put in coins. This was a beautiful temple to visit.

Go by yourself.... ...and go directly for the visit of the 4th floor where is the golden buddah and this for a small THB 40 per person. You have to trust that it is massive gold as it look like many other golden buddahs which are gold plated or similar.
Iconic monument. Located close to the center, this Buddha temple is a magnificent spot. The statue is beautiful and immensely popular amongst tourists. A must visit.

Impressive. Check out this Buddha temple when you're in China town as it's right there. It's pretty cool to see as it's a fairly large Buddha. You have to walk up a large amount of steep stairs but for children, elderly and handicaps, you can take the elevator.

A magic monument. Great spot in Bangkok. a lot of tourists(like us all); avoid the 1-2pm hour since most Monks are praying.Come with a guide from the hotel or venture yourself in a tuk-tuk that will take you to all important spots and will add a visit to a "minute" Tailor that will put you in a suit before you get 10 dollars to pay for it...
Wat Traimit combine with Chinatown. Take taxi to get there. Important place to visit to get more about Temples.I'm recommending you to walk around to chinatown after that.
Iconic. A lot of trouble getting there but worth the effort , this is a magnificent historic temple , best to go early morning to avoid top many tourists .

Golden Buddha. Great place, explore the surrounding area to golden Buddha, once you get in its a brilliant place to walk around sit in one of the gardens and just watch the world go by. Busy but worth a visit. Remember to have your shoulders covered girls. long pants boys in these place require a dress code. The way I see it is if you go to the Vatican you cover up, same goes here. Enjoy the experience.
Underwhelming. It was unfortunately very commercialized. Lots of people hanging out near the temple trying to get them to buy into something they didn't need.

Sitting Golden Buddha. Very peaceful and serene holy temple. Make sure you get the blessings of the monk sitting outside. Could not find cabs to take us back to Sukhumvit,this was probably due to the rallies on that day.
A great place!. this temple is one of the many temples around bangkok, definetely worth a visit strolling around town.Every temple has something nice and unique.

Absolutely fantastic!. Amazing place but I do not agree with Lonely Planet that it is the "highlight of Bangkok" (don't know what they are on really) The highlight of Bangkok it's Wat Pho, period. But this place it is also very beautiful and less touristy so it is nice that you can walk and check out all things with no loud tourists... :)
Exceptional place. The main shrine has a lot of holy vibrations.Good place to sit and meditate.Located in China Town, very close to MBK.
Worth a visit. The building was much more interesting for me rather than budda. It. is totally colorful with different architecure.It really worth to see.
A golden trip. It's defintely one of the biggest temples I've ever been to. Strongly recommend it for those who are interested in exploring others' religions.

A Golden Experience. Being an Indian, the first thing that hit me about the Temple of the Golden Buddha was that the idol is made of; hold your breath, a few tons of solid gold. That is a lot of gold. The temple is worthy of a visit definitely but with some precautions. Take plenty of water, cover your arms with full sleeves shirt, take a good guide to ward of pesky hawkers, and try to make it in the cooler mornings. The entrance to temple reminded me of the Chamundi Temple in Mysore, India. There is a lot of history to be learnt and the guide adequately transfers the knowledge. Did you know that the solid gold idol was covered with plaster to dissuade marauders from taking away the gold? The original plaster is displayed for us visitors.
Love It. A beautiful Wat with a very impressive Buddha image. This is a busy tourist attraction and we found it more pleasant in the early evening. Getting a taxi from the Wat can be a problem.

Temple of the golden Buddha. The Golden Buddha is in walking distance to the Grand Palace, Emerald Buddha, Chinatown is a bit further but easily assessable by ferry! taxi or a longer walk. Temple of Dawn in just across the river, a ferry cost of about five Baht to get there.The entry fee to see the Golden Buddha is 100 Baht if you are a visitor, Thai visitors and monks in dress do not pay entrance fee. There are bathrooms and a free 250ml water bottle is available for visitors.Ensure that you are appropriately dressed. I wore a t shirt and long short reaching below my knees and that was even suspect, if they do not believe that you are dressed appropriately they will give you coverings to wear. Upon entrance to the temple housing the. Golden Buddha you will need to remove your shoes. If you would like to avoid getting planters warts or athletes foot bring socks to wear!The Golden Buddha is simply amazing! To think that it is made from real gold (and there was no visible security?) was incredible. This was definitely a temple (What) worth visiting. There are many other shrines that can be visited and many, many other golden Buddha images at this location.There has been cases of pickpocketing in he area so be aware of your belongings at all times, especially when taking photographs or praying.

Well worth a visit. If you are travelling to Bangkok then this is a must see on your tick list. Ensure you have a good guide so that he/she can inform you of the history to make this visit really enjoyable. We did.
Interesting. You must respect the tradition of removing shoes before entering the temples , and wear suitable clothing ie, no short skirts or shorts and shoulders must be covered.

Serious gold. Superb Buddha, difficult to imagine that amount of gold. Small but well worth the visit another fabulous building in busy Bangkok, did not spend massive amount of time, but we'll worth the stop

Nice temple. The temple has a very huge buddha statue made of 800 kgs of gold....simply brilliant.
You can visit this temple which is situated in the middle of the city. You will get restaurants, shops, malls nearby. A 2 seater taxi is the best travel mode in city.

Excellent Gold Buddha!. I visited Wat Traimit during the city tour. Let me tell you that it is a beautiful and unimaginable sight to see a Buddha made out of 5500 Kgs of Gold. Its a small temple but worth a visit when you are in Bangkok. The history of this place makes it more interesting. Thai Architecture is beautiful and made to perfection. I visited this place around 9.20 am and due to which I faced a lot of crowd. This temple is close to Chinatown area.This place is truly magnificent. Dont miss it!

Quite Commercial but interesting. The golden Biddha is a beautiful Buddha, but not overly interesting in the sense of providing a different perspective or presentation. It is at the top of 3 flights of outside stairs and there are the multitudes of offering boxes throughout the inside room housing the buddha. We walked around it for 3-4 minutes and left the temple.
That's a lot of gold. A Buddha made of gold. Not something you see every day, especially one that weighs over 5 tons. Close to Chinatown, so it's worth planning the two together.

Amazing gold Buddha. In case you don't know the story, this Buddha statue was being moved when a piece of plaster fell off and revealed a solid gold statue on the inside. The Wat is fairly small and far less ornate that others but still worth a visit. The Buddha statue almost has a liquid appearance to it and is unlike others I have seen. Add this one to the list after visiting the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Worth seeing.

Amazing and spectacular. its really overwhelming to see a gold statue of this size gleamin right before you. The temple is a must visit when you are here. I wonder where did these guys get so much of gold !!!!

Gold gold gold !. Massive gold buddha in Chinatown. The story of how it was hidden under plaster is pretty interesting. You have to climb quite a few steps to get to the top so not for handicapped people. It is not my favorite temple in Bangkok but it is still fascinating to see.

Golden tour. To see so much gold. Impressive to say the least. And I never saw any security of any kind. The history even makes it even more special. We hit it at the perfect time and there was virtually no one there. We chose this over the palace and I am glad we did. It was mellower and less hauling around for the kids.

5500 kg solid gold Buddha statue . Unimaginable sight to see a shining real gold statue weighing nearly 5500 Kg, apx, and apx 15 ft in height, valued at over 50 million USD, right in front of you in present times. Surprisingly,we couldn't find any visible security for this great temple.History:This pure gold statue was made apx 700 years ago. Then it was covered with plaster to fool foreign raiders. When in 1955, the King decided to put this 15 ft high Buddha in a new temple, the plaster cracked while shifting. It was then realised its value was more than 50 million USD.A new temple was built in Bangkok to install it on the 4th floor.The temple is called: Traimit WitthayaRam temple.A not to be missed attraction when in BKK.

Stunning. The Buddha is small but absolutely beautiful. The lighting makes the display striking. Try to get to the palace at opening because it gets crowded after the tour buses arrive. Make sure you see this one.

Worth it if time allows. Definitely a magnificent structure. Our tuk tuk driver took us on way back from another attraction and I think we actually arrived too late. Pro was there was noone else around. Con was we couldn't climb up and see the view which had been recommended. Make sure you go before we did (I think it maybe closes around 6). We still got some fab pics!!

Have your Fortune Told & Visit with a Monk!. We beat all the tour busses and got there early in the morning. We took great pictures, and had the temple astrologer tell our fortune; I am to live up to age 100! We also provided a gift of food to the head monk, who blessed us and prayed over us.Great place to go, but early, before the tour buses arrive.

Beautiful temple. The temple is simply stunning and often it is not seen by tourists that are in Bangkok.The Thai architecture is something that is out of this world! There is gold everywhere that you look, including the gates and doors of the temples. You are able to pay a small fees as offerings.I spent less than an hour here but was glad that I visited.

Jaw Dropping. You will probably never again see so much gold in one place, so yes go check it out. Out of all the Buddhas we seen throughout our trip in Asia this is the one that we enjoyed the most. The history, the story, the value. Its truely jaw dropping. The story of this Buddha is one we have told and told again when recalling our adventures. It is a must see.
Very impressive. Stunning temple with fabulous exterior and interior features. All our party were impressed by the whole place and the Golden Buddha just added to the occasion. Well worth a visit.
Superb. Amazing temple with a very big gold Buddha . Again a must visit. You can purchase the ticket for the museum too. I definitely recommend it. Very well kept, displayed and informative.

2.5 tons of gold. very beautiful temple, white, very rare.. 2.5 tons of gold ! ! very very impressive. at the entrance if Chinatown. Not a lot of tourist ,ignored by tours. A lot if people praying. and more religious ambient. So massive gold with a strange color, different of slight platted gold. So you go to pray too and dream of a part, a small small part............"I have a dream, I have a dream that a part of Buddha change my life ............." Wellclose at 5pm.

World's largest solid gold statue. The temple is a good visit when going to Chinatown. I skipped the museum itself and went straight for the Buddha at the top of the temple (they close early!) and was not disappointed.The temple is nicely decorated, the people devout, and the statue well sculpted but, additionally, you just have never seen so much gold together anywhere else! Be respectful, but do pay it a visit.
an icon. well worth the visit , it is a stunning structure with great thai architechture , easy to understand why it is world famous
still my favourite. Wanted to visit to get some personal Buddhas. Not disappointed.New site is far bigger than the old site. Still my favourite Temple.
Average. More of a local prayer temple than a tourist attraction. The Buddha was massive and very tall but not very impressive. Ok for a visit if you have lots of time

Less ornate, but still impressive. If you don't know the story, this Buddha was covered with plaster until a chunk fell out. Inside, the statue turned out to be made of pure gold! A smaller and less ornate temple that others in Bangkok, but unique in its own right. The Buddha appears to shimmer as if just dipped in liquid metal. It's worth the effort to see this one after you have done the main sights. Add to the list.

Unique experience. It is very big Buddha and of course a golden one. The temple is full of shiny buildings and awesome paintings. Like other wats, you will take off your shoes and no photos are allowed

Golden Buddha and Bangkok. Golden Buddha was right next my hotel, Centra central station hotel. I went first thing in the morning and avoided the crowds, it was nice. There are different prices for what you wanna see, kind of odd, also lots of stairs for an older person and don't forget to cover up a bit and remove your shoes. This was the only thing I saw in Bangkok, as a taxi driver, should of taken his car no, but it's pink and on the inside of the roof he has a bunch of different currencies taped to the roof of his car, he drove us in a circle, charged us $150 baht, took us to a boat near the shangr-la hotel, where this couple ripped us off $1500 baht, took us down the river to wat phra kaew, then the worst part when they dropped us off, this thug demanded $20 baht as a fee for docking. Beware when traveling in Asia,

Amazing...Very shiny!. When we walked in, we were amazed by this solid gold Buddha. It has an interesting history to it too. You should ask your tour guide how they found the Buddha was made of gold. Different from the Buddhas we've seen around in Bangkok!
Nice Wat. The temple is just behind the Centra Central hotel. 3 min walk from hotel. The budha is said to be the biggest golden budha in the world. Weight alsmot 5 ton. Ticket is just 50 baht.
Pretty cool. Another Buddha not to be missed. This was one of the best Buddhas we saw on a trip around Bangkok. Quite amazing the history behind it and that it is solid gold.

Impressive and completely different.. It's a must see with completely different architecture and of course. It's so interesting to see the Buddha and culture around it. Make sure you wear something cool on a hot day.

It is what it says. A solid Gold Buddha that was only re-discovered about 60 years ago as it had been covered in plaster to hide it from invading armies. Now restored to full splendour, but it is a bit of a climb to the top on a hot day

Nice temple. Its very near MRT Hua Lamphong, walk 10 mins to the temple. after that can pay 20 THB for tuk tuk go to river and catch a boat for a tour to Grand Palace and Wat Arun. The temple is small but beautiful, lots of visitors.
When in Chinatown, don't miss it. The place is very interesting and is in the middle of the amazing Bangkok Chinatown. Just get ready for the heating inside the building.
Another important place to visit. On the list of most tourists. Beautiful huge Buddha. Have to climb 2 fleet of stairs. Very well maintained. Located near china town, which is a good market to visit.

Tranquil place... This is one place I recommend all tourist to visit, maintain silence, please :) ..
A place of worship, peace and tranquility with a touch of grandeur. Golden Buddha is a visual treat to eyes, made out of gold, temple and the surroundings are so colorful and refreshingly good..

Pure gold that is worth seeing.. Located at the end of Chinatown's Yaowarat Road, near Hualampong Railway Station, Wat Traimit houses the world's largest massive gold seated Buddha measuring nearly five metres in height and weighing five and a half tons. In the past, artisans crafted the Buddhas in gold and disguised them from invading armies by a covering of stucco and plaster.Pay 40 baht at the ticket counter and climb up to the 4th floor where the golden Buddha sits.

another wat. another wat in the heart of chinatown,it´s special due to the golden budda,all made in gold !!!It´s near hua lamphong railway station,you have to go upstairs a lot....un templo en el barrio chino,aahi se puede ver el buda de oro,todo macizo....esta cerca de la estacion del tren hua lamphong

The Golden Buddha. This was my second visit to Wat Traimit and it still remains as fascinating as it was the first time. The mere fact that a hug sculpture made of 5.5 tonnes of solid gold is before you is reason for amazement enough. Anywhere else in the world a structure of such high material value (let alone the spiritual significance) would be under real heavy guard. But apparently honesty still rules Thailand, as a consequence of which one can find very modest security around Wat Traimit. It is incredible.

Exciting accident story of statue. I liked the way people are worshiping regularly there, although it's a very very touristic temple. You might see Thai tourists from other Thai cities who came for praying and worshiping
Buddha. A popular must-visit temple that brings peace to your mood. Even tourists don't spoil the impression.

An intriguing story.. A rainy day outing. The unexplained disappearance of this American is Agatha Christie-like. The house is interesting for its' American/Thai décor. Remember though, the aim is to sell you silk.

Quite beautiful. Go or not, it deppend on how much you like Thai temples: this temple by itself is very, very beautiful, with a big, beautiful Buddha on the top. But I heard many people boring of visiting a lot of similar temples.I liked it a lot

Wat Traimit (Golden Buddha).Bangkok,Thailand.. The first place we visited in Bangkok,just within couple of hours of arrival in this city on 7th Sept 2013.In 1987 one of my friend visited this place on honey moon with his wife ,both doctors & I saw & knew about this place.It was raining when we visited this monastery & paid 5oo Baht per ticket.We had to climb upstairs to this shinning Golden Buddha in his sitting posture.On ground floor we viewed other statues of Buddha.Interesting place but too high price for ticket.

Solid gold Buddha Statue is a treat for your eyes.. It is a must visit temple. The Buddha shrine and the main hall is a treat for the the eyes. There was an entry fee of 20b per pax, but there was none to check the tickets and we entered without tickets. It won't require much of ur time and very close to Hua Lamphong MRT station from the EXIT 1.

Visit the museum too!. We visited here, unaware that there is a museum as well as the temple. The museum tracks the history of Chinatown, and is very well presented with many interesting multi-media exhibits. The Golden Buddha is, of course, impressive, but the museum ticket is well worth the additional 100 Baht or so, and adds considerably to the value of the visit to the temple.

Very impressive. The entry fee to get in is about 60 cents US. The building is very cool from the outside, but the star of the show is the 6 ton solid gold statue inside. It is very impressive and just cool to look at for a while. The craftsmanship is amazing, and the back story is fantastic. Did not do the museum, as that looked pretty boring.

Well worth a visit. Solid gold Buddha a must see. Easy walk from China Town MRT. Don't listen to tuk tuk drivers waiting around who will always tell you it's Buddha day and the temple is closed. Great to see recommend

Just amazing place, the most expensive, but the most amazing. One of 3 places you should definately visit when you´re in Bangkok. They want 500 baths, but you´ll be satisfied with paying it and seeing all the temples there.. It´s really good to go there in the end of May, when they have some Buddha´s celebrations.
Gold and the sense of luxury. Amazing. This may be the largest piece of gold that I've ever seen. I love this experience and truly cherish this experience.

A quick trip. I'm not a religious person, but had been having lunch in Chinatown to thought we'd take a look. The Wat is an impressive structure, with many steps to see the Buddha. We chose to buy tickets for the Buddha only at 40 bahts each. At the ticket office they suggested my tshirt was showing too much arm, so you can rent a scarf there for 20 bahts which was ideal. It wasn't too crowed and no queue so we were straight in. It was nice to see, but after 60 seconds I felt we'd seen it and that was that.

Super bling but still impressive. Select carefully the timing of your visits as it can get very busy during Chinese holidays. The ticket is just on your left at the entrance so do not get enticed to pre-book tickets with agencies for various places in Bangkok as it's a waste. Remember where you left your shoes when you enter as it may get very busy by the time you return. If it stars raining it gets very complicated to get taxi so start walking away from the temple for a few minutes to beat the crowds.
good place to be. all templesa in thailand are now commercial. one thing interesting i noted was that bird cages to buy for 100 baht and then yu have to free them . sounded sensible and i did that

AMAZING PLACE. If you do not visit this Wat you are missing such an amazing place.
Dress appropriately and make sure you have plenty of energy and water for your trip
Golden Idol. The idol was really fabulous and breath taking. Very much crowded . U can see your face on the face of the idol. Great work , really appreciated

Fantastic. This Buddha is made of 5.5 tonns of real gold. Worth seeing just for that alone. Just avoid the hawkers outside, they dont take no for an answer, even leaning into the tour van as we prepared to leave!

Huge and Aweinspiring. This Buddha again has a story. the unknown creator of this 500kg Buddha, had plastered the statue to keep it protected. it was only 50yrs ago when due to an accident a part of the plaster came off and people realised that its actually a Buddha made of Pure Gold....!!!! experts estimate the statue to be atleast 700 yrs old if not more. the Statue has recently 3 yrs back, being shifted to a new building and is housed on the 4th floor. 2nd floor has chinese history museum and 3rd has buddha statues
Nice place on your itinery. Good place to visit along with other local attractions . Nice pictures possibility. Clean and well mantained.

5500 kgs of solid gold Buddha!!. The statue here is 5.5 tons of solid gold and very beautiful. Temple premises are kept exceptionally clean. There is a god story behind this as to how they have discovered that the statue is made of gold. The pamphlet will be provided to you while buying ticket.shorts and short skirts are not allowed. However, jeans are permitted.Do visit while at Bangkok. You won't regret.

Awsome Buddha made of pure Gold. The temple and arrangements were good and the Buddha is awsome to look at. Parking is a problem. The prayer area should be cordoned off from tourists who stand and gape.

devotion to the buddha. there is a 3 meter tall golden Buddha,which gleams made of solid gold.all the temples we saw in Thailand were clean ,tourist friendly and serene.there is also the engravings of the thai massage school.you can pick up art and artifacts from the shops outside.
Good place to visit. If you looking for visit a temple in Bangkok, but less-crowded. This will be a good choice. Praying of Buddha, Buddha Gallery, Buying of souvenirs are all available here!

A little so-so. I liked the experience this site offered a lot. It was cheap and really neat to look at some of the exhibits. Unfortunately while I was there, they had closed parts of the site so I couldn't see all of it. It is also a bit small
Golden Buddha. This place was phenomenal. Do not miss looking at the ceiling of the temple with such intricate carvings. Word of caution - Our guide told us to be careful of pickpockets out here!!
Is it real gold???. I dont belive that it is real gold. They just polish front side of the statu back side it has black stains on it. Just same as the others. Have a nice trip.

Beautiful. The buddha in this temple is the heavist gold budha in asia. The temple was easy to access from our hotel just took underground from sukhumvit station to hua lumphong & than just a short walk. It does not take too long to see this place as its small. Its just a short walk from china town where is so good seafood.

Impressive in scope and history. Worth the stop with a tour guide to learn about the history of the Golden Buddha and seeing the massive statue in person - observe the handcrafted details as you walk around. Major elements such as the head, arms, and legs came apart for travel south to its current location.
solid gold buddha. located near chinatoen within Yaowarat. now undergoing a major renovation to house thesolid gold buddha. entrance fee of 30 baht applies.
Stunning - and next to China town. Historical additions on the lower levels were somewhat interesting. Make sure you visit China town next door for the great food stalls.
Golden Budha - actually made of gold.. Very impressive Budha some 4 Tonnes of gold with a scrap value of $260m actual value probably incalculable. Worth a trip and also near to Chinatown

LOTS of visitors, and still worth doing.. It's a little tight when you get in the shrine with so many others, however, it is worth it. Make sure to visit the other shrines. The whole place is over the top decorated and well worth the admission fee. Make sure to wear long pants or long skier for women and for women, cover your shoulders. A shawl won't be sufficient.
Nice temple. there are certain places that need to be experienced than just try to fill 50 characters in this box :) ... the temple is good and has history to it.
Beautiful temple! Even when templed out.. Beautiful and very interesting. We were very hot and it takes a while, but much was air conditioned!

it's a great story. We had a good guide, Mr Onn, who told us the story behind the golden Buddha. Apparently it was covered up with plaster for centuries. Was sitting in a fairly ordinary wooden temple until the plaster started to crack. Now it has a very grand home!

Solid tons of gold. Went to Wat Traimit on a part of our Bangkok temples tour. The temple itself was not much to write about, comparing to other prominent temples in Bangkok (Wat Pho, etc). But the highlight was, of course, the golden buddha statue. And what a sight it was, sitting there gleaming at solid 5 tons. Wow. How the ancient Thais came up with such amount of gold and how dedicated there were in making such perfect worshiping object is intriguing, to say the least. Well worth a visit

Optional to go.. A giant golden buddha in the temple. Just a small and simple temple. Nothing much. Perhaps pay more attention on the architecture? Walking distance from Hua Lampong MRT. nearby Chinatown.Don't anyhow trust people when you are told that the temple was closed for the day.

Quiet temple awesome statue. A little bit off the main tourist route. Found this by chance when I had time to spare while waiting for the train. 40 bhat entrance is worth it to see this solid gold statue. Very helpful and friendly staff around.

Nice Place. Even if there are a lot of Temples and budas in Thailand, you should visit this place, it's quieter than others temples and you can see monks there. On the main door there are people selling animals and flowers for offerings

So much $$ in a small spot. The Golden Buddha is just that, solid gold; 2.5 tons in a statue 4 meters high. Amazing grounds within the Temple complex, with shops and snack bars. Photo opportunities abound at this Temple so just take your time and wander about.
beautiful. The image is beautiful. Holy and blissful. I liked the holy water i got to take home. Blessing from the Golden Buddha.

Golden Buddha Statue. Near City proper and Chinatown. Only paid 40baht (just to see the 4th level) where the Great Golden Buddha was located. (3rd level is museum and ground level about Chinatown) If going to see all, fee is 120baht. From where I was staying Bangkok Centre, 10 minutes walk and went early so not too much visitors yet. There is elevator at the back for wheelchair access.

The Idol of Lord Budha having 5500 Kg. of Gold.. It was indeed a great visit to this Temple. The solid gold idol of Lord Budha weighs 5500 Kg of Gold and looked superb. The idol is huge and shining, a feast to our eyes. A must to see place of worship in Bangkok.
Gold. Really nice Buddhists place. Golden statue is amazing. Lost of Load Buddha's statues can see. Crowded in eveninngs
Best Buddha. Worth a visit if you haven't experienced Thai culture and want an understanding of religious views. Crowded on busy days

Very impressive. Visited on 21st September. We went first to snake farm on Rama IV Road. and then took a TukTuk for around 40 Baht. The temple and the Golden statue of Buddha are impressive. There is also a museum, for which you have to pay separately. We did not go to the museum. One can go from there to Oriental Pier by tuktuk for around 40-50 Baht. and then take a public boat for 40Baht to go to Sleeping Buddha, Palace and Wat Arun. You may spend around 30 min in this complex.
Amazing. A must see if you visit Bangkok. Lots of tourists but well worth the queues. You need to cover up bare flesh if you are a woman and take your shoes off!

5.5 ton of solid gold buddha. In Chinatown, the temple is rather modest to house such a majestic image of buddha.You will have to all the way up to reach the golden buddha (with a 100 baht ticket, valid only for this floor - the other exhibits also have fees to enter). Yes, it has become very touristy and you will have to be aware of the scams and traps (everywhere!), but there is nothing else like this anywhere in the world (it is the biggest solid gold statue in the world), so it really is impressive, very beautiful and worth a visit.

Many thanks for bringing luck to me. It is no doubt that this is one of the top of Bangkok sights. It is also a great place for photography.Once you come here, you should pay attention to every detail and you will feel admire of craftsmanship due to its complexity and elaborateness in design.I had a lucky chance to come here and to get to know about its interesting history and witness a fabulous Buddah statue.I also had a chance to entreat help from deities and buy a lucky charm form here. Thanks to this, I had the feeling of guardian.Because you will have to walk for a long distance so wear hat or cap along. Remember the dress code in Thai standards.I do recommend this place.

All that gold!. With a Buddha encased in all that gold - about 5.5 tons of it - who could fail to be impressed. No wonder it is one of the top Bangkok sights. As September is one of the wet months when there are not so many tourists around we had no waiting in line to view the Buddha. This meant we could stay as long as we wished which was very good. Our guide from Tour East who took us there was very knowledgeable about the history of this particular Buddha.The grounds surrounding the temple were beautiful too. This is a sight worth visiting even if you do feel "templed out".

Not central but worth seeing if you're close by. If you're not suffering from temple fatigue this is worth a visit. You can choose whether or not to pay the full price and visit the museum or the reduced rate for the temple only.

Golden Buddha, Bangkok, Thailand.. I visited there along with my family and enjoyed a lot. Its history is that Golden Buddha, officially titled Phra Phuttha Maha Suwan Patimakom, is the world's largest solid gold statue. The origins of this statue remain uncertain. It is made in the Sukhothai Dynasty style, and is thought to have been made during the Sukhothai period in the 13th - 14th centuries. The statue is 3 meters tall and weighs 5.5 ton.

Golden for a reason. Hubby and I visited this temple the other day. Apparently when they tried to move the original buddha it fell and some of the plaster chipped off. Underneath was gold. Yes gold. Not 100% gold as it would have been too soft but around the quality of a wedding ring - 51/2 ton! It is a wonder to see and you don't have to stand just admiring the buddha - the grounds - surroundings are beautiful too. We loved it and would say to anyone that it is worth a visit!
Wow. This temple has to be seen to be believed. There is so much to see in such a small place, make sure you take the time to really look around at the beauty of this temple.

Golden Buddha. It was amazing to see the all golden buddha and learn some history about the temple. It can be crowded and you must take your shoes off when visiting a temple. Respect the culture and remember the dress code.
If You Have Time To Spare. The Standing Golden Buddha in Bangkok is nice. If you are staying in Bangkok for 4+ days, go take a look. If not, there are many other attractions to see during your stay.

Not bad. Not bad, but won't be visiting it again. The reason is because once you've seen a few temples they are all very much similar, but the fact that the Buddha is made of gold (I don't know if it's actually true) makes it a bit awesome, other than that, how long are you going to look at a statue or a temple?
the gold Buddah. Great to visit but be prepared for crowds. This attraction was only 100 BHT with a cold water thrown in. It was very hot the day we visited but still a must see!!

Impressive Buddha and way better than the grand palace. Traveled as a group visiting the temple with a guide. Very impressive Buddha and temple, less crowded and much more enjoyable than the grand palace.Remember to wear 'respectable clothing' (in Thai standards) including covering shoulders and knees (goes for both men and women) and easy to remove shoes as you can't wear shoes inside the actual Buddha temple. Definitely taking friends here again.
Quick visit. First part of our tourIt's a 5 ton golden Buddha. Impressive to see but I'd want to have a Plan to visit other places because this wouldn't be worth it to see by itself
Good One. Good temple with a good historical background. Good place for Photography. Also wish pot outside the temple is a place liked by tourists. They give holy water to all visitors.

Surely worth the walk. The Wat Traimit is a bit off, but surely worth the walk to it. If you visit chinatown from the ferrystation you just have to make you way through all of it to come to the Wat.The wat has several levels so after you purchsed the entrance ticket you will have to climb up several stairs but every level has interesting facts and offers a new view of the surrounding city. On the top you find a Buddha which is not so beautiful (it has an extreme nose) but completely made of gold. As the building is pretty modern it does lack the kind of decor which are typical for older Wats but here your attention will be focused on the main thing.
Golden view. Short hike up the hill not far from Kao San Road. Nice wind and view up there. Have a rest and give your donation to Buddha.

Average place. Except for the golden Buddha which is made up of 5500 kg gold there isn't much to see at this place.Entry for only the temple is 40 Baht and with the museum it is 140 Baht which is too high for this. Visit if you are already in this location or if you are visiting chinatown in the evening.
Golden Buddha for good times. I love this place so much, Especially when i come to bangkok i go there many times. so shiny and bright, so interesting history. so deep feeling. i love thailand

Great time at the Golden Buddha. I enjoyed this tour, ideal for first time visitors to Bangkok as you get to see around the city and visit 3 of many temples in Bangkok, all of which are pretty impressive. I would definitely recommend the morning tour as the temples and roads are busier in the afternoon and it’s not as hot. We book out tour with Tour East - Bangkok City and Temples Tour.I cant speak highly enough of the team at Tour East. The vehicles are all well presented - with much loved Air Conditioning and the guides we had were very friendly, informative and amusing.
Real Gold!. it was awesome to see the Gold Buddah and understand its history. each and every temple is unique and dress comfortably to enjoy the sights.
So shiny and bright.. This Buddha is in a sitting position and is solid gold. The monks there gave us a blessing with a wet kind of whisk brush. Another day of oohs and aaaahhs
See gold for real. Not a very big temple. But at least able to see real gold on display.Its real gold for sure. There is a small entrance see one has to pay to enter.

Another Temple. After visiting the most "important" temples in Bangkok, it seems you are constantly seeing the same thing... Buddhas, buddhas and more buddhas. A nice temple with an exposition which helps you to understand the Thai history a little bit better.

Work for an answer!. I was wondering during my trip what about the different positions of Buda, and this one answer me about the universal diluvian, Beautiful a MUST BE o your tour.Just an advice:Bring a lot of water!
Good. The Golden Buddha temple is 36 m height and its wonderful, surely to visit and pray to God. I will surely visit it again if a get a opportunity.

Lovely...and amazing!. The Golden Buddha is well worth a visit, although a little crowded there was still sufficient time and space to really view the Temples. Please remember these are Temples and dress accordingly!
famous. everyone must see this temple , so famous and although a lot of peoples , worth the visit , really spectacular , we highly reccommend
Quite Impressive. It's a really quick visit, but if you do your homework before you go, you will really appreciate the greatness of the temple.
Excellent. It is very inexpensive to visit the Golden Buddha and it is worth seeing. Lovely grounds and worth going to see.
must visit site. beautiful & the entire temple complex is very clean. There is lots to see so wear your sneakers.. :-)

Wat Traimit Bangkok. Visited on a very hot humid day and taking your own water a must as we had to que for more and overpriced and not very cold ,temple was stunning and plenty info available on the history,felt there were to many hawkers at temple entrance trying to enage tourists as the entered ,we had a guide so were not pestered,all in all a must see if you are in Bangkok but on reflection would go early moring when it is a bit cooler.
Beautiful and Humbling. Needs to be visited to really appreciate the beauty and splendor of it all, It is something that I cannot express in words how beautiful it is, go Visit
Beautiful Arts. beautiful arts , nice people , and of course peace of mind from the crowd. Worth to visit . But beware of street brokers.
Another Buddha. It is another buddha. If you enjoy seeing culture and monuments, then it is worth a few minutes of your time. It is very tall and gold.

very impressive. very impressive temple with giant golden Buddha statues. Very interesting for tourists to visit. You must be neatly dressed, but can borrow appropriate things in the temple. Do not fall for the many traders who try in front of the temple to sell e.g. long pants at high prices!
very impressive. Beautiful buildings and 12 tons of Gold...that is a show stopper..women wear skirts in the temples below the knees..some offer slip over skirts they bring themselves

A must see. Brilliant as it also had alot of interesting information about Thailand's history..Take some extra bahts with you as you can donate to the health of the monks..great place, highly recommend!!

So interesting. This is one of many interesting Buddhist Temples that we visited while in Thailand. We found each one was unique and interesting, each in it's own way. This is worth visiting while in Bangkok. (Don't forget the dress code -- no bare arms for women!)

Well worth a visit. The temple itself is very impressive and the Golden Buddha is a magnificent sight. The surrounding area was extremely busy and there were traffic jams but we were glad we visited this tourist attraction.

Unique and expensive. A 10 feet Buddha statue made of over 5 tonnes of solid gold - need I say more.
Even if you are not religious, it is something you probably won't find anywhere else in the world and is probably the most expensive statue in the world.
Definitely worth a visit.

Amazing. It is hard to describe how beautiful this temple is. Up the stairs to see the Golden Budda and it is amazing how big it is. The story on how it was found to be gold is very interesting. A lift is available for the elderly or disabled. There is also a museum in the complex but did not have time to check it out. Well worth spending time to go and view this temple.

A nice place to spend an hour or so.. Very interesting story behind the Buddha - makes it stand out among the countless other wats to visit. A cute little museum attached, detailing about the Chinese community in Thailand (the wat is very close to Chinatown).
Visted with my daughter. One of the sights to see on a walking tour we took. Only speny a short time there...almost closing time when we got there. Beautiful

Peaceful and magnificent. Loved this place, a simple 5 ton gold image of Buddha looking at you and giving the inner strength. A visit to Bangkok is incomplete without watching this place.Women should cover their shoulders and wear at least knee length dress.

Interesting.. With temples on every corner in Thailand, this one does stand out a bit. View from the tower is nice. Interesting reading the history about this Buddah. As with all temples here, there is a dress code, but you can rent wraps there to cover yourself appropriately. You do get mobbed with peddlers all around this temple.
Gorgeous. Great temple, can get very packed but the wallpaper is amazing as it is hand painted on, and this place has a great view
Good and reasonably priced. The restaurant has a great atmosphere. The food is good and varied and the service very good. Great as something different.

The other golden buddha. Look, Thailand is a buddhist country so expect to see lots of Golden Buddha statues around. Having said that, this Golden Buddha temple is amazing. Located at Bangkok's chinatown, the temple towers high over the surround buildings and the buddha itself is quite magnificent but smaller than other golden buddhas. I skipped the exhibit only because of time constraint but from what i read about it, it is interesting to understand the history and architecture of the Wat Traimit temple (Temple of the Golden Buddha in Thai) That said, if you have limited time in your itinery, there are other more spectacular Golden Buddhas around Bangkok that is worth the time to visit so you can skip this. Entrance to see the Buddha however is a paltry 40 baht per adult.

Our preferred temple. Small temple in the Chinese quarter. Nice and quick visit. For no specific reason, we preferred this temple. Very nice atmosphere with people praying. Not far from the palace so quite well located if you are grouping visits. When you visit Thailand, you will see a lot of temples, i will recommend this one.
Educational experience and amazing!!!. It is very well done the process of seeing everything. The crowds ws hard with kids lots of steps but worth it..take water and snacks to have outside and hats

Great!. Situated in China town, a bit difficult to go (if you go by express boat is best), it really is golden and it shows, nice area and can walk to china town and eat at local Chinese owned and run restaurants and visit the market etc.

Temple of Golden Buddha is rare place, but very nice. I like this place, not so far from Wat Po but we need go by taxi or tuk-tuk ( the special vehicle of Thailand like microlets ). We can see the Golden statue of Buddha. They believe, if You touch the miniature of Buddha then You get gold, You are lucky...
Beautiful place. This is a must see place in Bangkok if you like to visit temples. This Budha is very interesting and the place is very clean and well maintained.

MORE TIME. You need to take your shoes of and they make you put it on a shelve/stand, not telling you that you need to pay if it is on the stand. Only once you come out they want payment. I felt they should tell you before, what if you did not have any money with you.

An Amazingly beautiful, spiritual place to sit and reflect.. This is the most beautiful place to visit, take your camera and take your time. This is not a temple to rush around but to sit and reflect. The Buddha is beautiful beyond belief and is best viewed early morning or late afternoon to capture that amazing glow. A must see in Bangkok.
HUGE. Nice stop off on our trip viewing lots of different Wats and temples, probably the favourite of the day.

Great story, great surroundings.. This 2.5 ton golden Buddha was found only when what everyone thought was an enormous plaster or stone Buddha got dropped, revealing the gold underneath. It's in China town, which is a great place to visit anyway and the Wat is unique in style. There's a good museum about the early Chinese immigrants to Siam included in the 150B admission price. There's also a museum dedicated to how the gold Buddha was discovered inside the Wat. Obviously the best time to visit is Chinese New Year if you can bear the crowds. There's a great old shrine to the Earth Goddess round the back of Wat Traimit, too which is free admission. I recommend it as part of any trip to China town.
Nice Wat. In chinatown, biggest golden Buddha in the world....I think. Have to trek up the temple to the top, not so bad though. Nice temple.
If only visit 1 Buddha make it this one. Huge Buddha, interesting and close to the palace so can combine visits. You can however easily become "templed out" there are so many

Lovely place to visit, avoid the holiday season!. January isn't really a great time to visit this lovely temple. It was SO packed! Well, I guess it is best to visit early in the morning as the air is cool and you'll get better views and can spend longer time admiring the timeless architecture and art of this place.

pretty boudhha but nothing else. You'll be glad to front the golden boudha so big and soft one. Nothing else interesting so for European isn't expensible you can be happy to pay for seeing it but for someone in light buget is not so pertinent

Worth the trip. The Buddha is beautiful and the temple is sacred and peaceful! I enjoyed every minute of it, and felt a kind of serenity. The souvenirs outside the temple were great, I brought some back for my friends and they loved them.

The exhibition was interesting. I've seen the golden buddha before, but went there with my friends. This time they had an exhibition about Thailands history in the floors beneath the buddha, which we found really interesting. The buddha itself is impressive, and the small exhibition that showed how they made it was really cool.
Very Interesting!. wat traimit located in Chinatown, bangkok. its very interesting because the temple is unique. the temple have a buddha statue from Gold with weight 2,5 Ton. its so amazing!!
tour guide if possible. organise a tour guide to tell you more about the buddhist history and you'll gain so much more from any outing

choose, one. this one. Really, you only need to see one or two temples to know what its all about. in my opinion, this one is the one to see. It contains the most impressive solid gold buddha. Ask a tour guide about the history of it, it really is interesting. Furthermore, my tour guide claimed it is her favorite buddha and one of the most beautiful in all of asia. The temple is smaller compared to some but the hand painted walls and beautiful doors and murals really set you up for Bangkok temples.

Excellent. This temple seemed to hold a lot of respect in Thailand. I thought the solid gold Buddha was very impressive to behold. It was a bit of a climb, but for believers in the Buddha, I'm sure it would be worthwhile. This was amongst the best sights I had visited during my trip!
Shiney. My thought while visiting this temple was, what is that Buddha worth? Very impressive! I paid for the museums, in the future, I believe I will only pay to see the Buddha.

Okey. It was okey, worth a visit. Biggest golden Buddha in the world, they say...
Very commercial but hey, its very famous! You can get some 'holy water' for a donation.
Shops and stuff around.

Beautiful and Inspiring. This temple and its surroundings take your breath away. It is advisable to have tour guide to explain history and relevance to Thai people when visiting these type of sites. We used "Tran" from Great Bangkok Travel co. who spoke excellent english and was very informative.
Golden Buddha. If you don't have time for a tour you can just buy a ticket to look at the Buddha. Sarongs are availabel for hire for 20baht if you are not covered up properly. Worth a visit.
Worth the trip to China Town!. Make sure you do the museum as well. Lots of great history there about the Buddha's origin and history.

Huge Golden Buddha. Amazing Golden Bhddha Temple having Thai & Chinese Traditionally built ! All temples at this Property are Great !
Staff is very helpful. They provide free mineral water per entry fees. Also they have very good system to take footwear within carry-bag to respect holy idol . Great Place.

A piece of wonder. Excellent place to visit in Bangkok to know the culture, It is recommended to visit the take a guide with you as there are lots to know about the temple, culture and origin of the temple. The guide will show you all the details of the temple and its origin

Great Temple. We arrived on our first tour and were very impressed by the temple, it was very early and already very humid, also the Budda is amazing, the steps do not look high but with the heat were still hard going, remeber men trousers, ladies cover your shoulders & knees

5.5 tons of golden Buddha goodness.. This is one of my favorite Wats during Chinese New Year its very lively and its a very modern Wat. You can get there via the MRT get off at the last stop out the far exit take a left. There is also a really cool cultural museum located in on the third floor of the Wat.

Maior do mundo - the biggest one!. Maior estatua em ouro maciço do planeta, vale a visita!
Biggest solid golden statue in the world. Worth the visit!

Holy temple. The map shows opposite the mrt, but it is much further hidden by shops. Beware Touts are everywhere and when you are holding a map, they Distract you by saying Chinatown close for washing, templeS closeD! Ask the shop owner or hawkers. Taxis drivers just as bad.Wat Trimit is a lovely temple we can walk from the hualumpang mrt and we paid 40baht entrance fees. Follow the sign to enter and at most temples remember to take off your shoes and no flash for photos.

wow. there is an excellent exhibit that must be seen prior to visiting the golden buddha, giving the history of the discovery of the buddha and the making of the buddha....the buddha itself is impressive and, even though it is a religious site, there is ample opportunity to walk around the buddha and take pictures...and there are photographers who snap you on the way up and present you with a pin/magnet picture of your visit there...corny but i bought one...
Beautiful and Ispiring. It's really a beautiful temple, including not only the structure where the golden Buddha is but also all around it.A must visit!

Most superb Buddha I met before.. I wold like to visit a china town in Bangkok. I have no respect for the temple. But, I happened to find Temple of the Golden Buddha near the entrance of China town. I felt very happy to see the Golden Buddha, because it's the most superb Buddha I met before.
Amazing. We where awestruck by this!! Unbelievable grounds and as for the golden Buddha, well,as I said in my title..Amazing

Amazing Buddha (but there are better temples). The Golden Buddha is huge! And very impressive. Amazing to think that it was only discovered by accident when it was dropped and it's concrete casing cracked open. The temple looks grand, but only because it is new and built to house the Golden Buddha. Compared to other temples in Bangkok it is certainly nothing special, so if you're short on time, make sure you get to the Grand Palace/Wat Pho/Wat Arun before you come here, to see those sights and the original architecture there.

Very nice. The temple was very nice for its history. It was nice to know about the Thais hiding this gold idol away under the earth from the invading Burmese. We went on a hot day and the stone floors were burning hot. The interior architecture is amazing. There is a smaller temple on the outside with a large hall but it was closed to visitors on that day.

Ordinary temple became exceptional. The Golden Buddha, officially titled Phra Phuttha Maha Suwan Patimakon, this is a sukhothai style made statue, The origins of this statue is uncertain,In 1801, Thai King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke (Rama I), after establishing Bangkok as a new capital city of the Kingdom, and after commissioning the construction of many temples in Bangkok, ordered that various old Buddha images should be brought to Bangkok from the ruined temples around the country. So this was the time that the Golden Buddha was probably brought from Ayutthaya to Bangkok.
Wow!. A heritage centre and museum at this temple. It is so different from the old Wat Traimit I used to visit. Definitely worth a visit for the history of Chinese in Bangkok
Beautiful Buddha!. Solid gold ( 5.5 tons ) that is a sight to behold. Don't miss this beauty. Another pleasant experience in BKK that costs very little to do.

Just awesome. A golden Buddha that is made of solid gold! Amazing
You also should see the exhibition which explains the antecedents of the statue. Like all Thai temples, the architecture is fabulous

Golden Buddha - great to see. The paintings on the walls of the temples are absolutely amazing! Such clever people. There was a lot of people visiting the day that we visited. Great to experience just be mindful of theft.
Worth a visit. Well worth the visit did not see this on my first trip to Bangkok but I am glad I did this time around. After the visit it is perfect to stroll about China town.

It is a very big Buddha. The Golden Buddha was a cool little stop to make in Bangkok and I would recommend visiting it to people who are staying in the area. It's cool for a few quick photographs and it is definitely the biggest Buddha statue I have seen. Whether it is good or bad depends on the traveler, but it is a very quick activity. This would only take about 5-15 minutes to enjoy, so I wouldn't plan too much time around it. For me this is a positive because I wouldn't want to waste much more time than that to see it. There is plenty of culture, food and exciting activities in Bangkok, so I would plan a quick morning stop off that doesn't throw you off from all the other things to see and do in this city.-RyanNomadic Adaptation
Interesting. We visited as part of a day tour from our cruise. The story about the Golden Buddha was interesting. It is certainly worth visiting and it is accessible for most fitness levels.

Golden buddha but nothing else. The temples itselfs are not an explicit highlight, Wat Pho is much more impressive, but the former got one highlight: the buddha statue which weighs 5.5 tons of pure gold! We especially liked the history behind the statue as it was only discovered that it was made of gold when there was an accident while switching the buddha between buildings and it fell down. ;)A nice-to-see thing, especially when you are on your way to chinatown - just pass by for some minutes.
A layer of Gold. A one glance & you will shocked with amazing creativity & Finishing with complete Gold hearted Budha temple. you'll feel a great calmness inside you.

Serene Place. A statue of Buddha made of solid gold - wow - see it to believe it. A beautiful temple to visit. The place tends to be crowded in the morning. Most of the tour operators conduct the tour of this temple.
Beautiful. Very beautiful. loved seeing this Buddha and the temple. Just be aware of the pushy people trying to sell photos that they are in your face snapping as soon as you arrive.

Another Buddha. I've seen a lot of Buddha's in Bangkok and this one is probably the least interesting for me. Really nothing special about it - more interesting watching the monks in the area and in their class.

Beautiful Statue, see if you have time.. This Buddha statue is 9.8 ft tall and weighs 5.5 tonnes made from 18 karat of GOLD. What a beauty. However, this statue is the only attraction in the area and the temple is not as beautiful as the Emerald Buddha temple. So if you do not have time, then it's okay to skip this.But if you do plan to visit the Golden Buddha, then do this early evening so that then you can simply walk to China Town from there and spend some time gorging on the food and looking at various knickknacks.Ladies need to wear a long skirt or wrap around a sarong before entering the temple.
Golden Buddha. Interesting first temple visited, the Buddha is solid gold and this is the interest point, overall it's a smaller attraction, if your in the area and want to see a temple this is ok

Gold, gold and more gold. The 'Golden Buddha' in the Chinatown area of Bangkok was amazing - it was so shiny!. We caught the ferry to Chinatown and walked to the temple (remember the sarong) through Chinatown. The Sukothai Traimit Golden Buddha is the largest Golden Buddha image in the world and is over 700 years old. It is made of pure gold and weighs about 5.5 tons. Its value has been put at 28.5 million pounds.Originally the image was covered in plaster to conceal it from the invading enemies. But on moving it to its present location in 1955, it was dropped when a rope broke and was found to be made of gold underneath the plaster. It has been recorded in the Guiness Book of records as 'Sacred object with the highest intrinsic value'.The temple has four levels, with the Golden Buddha on the top level. Beneath this is a an exhibition on the history of how the image was made and also an animated demonstration of the 1955 incident when it was dropped and cracked to reveal the gold underneath. On the second floor is a history of Chinatown, with life-sized models and sound animations. It was very realistic and extremely interesting.Just be careful of the tuk-tuk drivers frequenting the temple. Don't go with them. They offer very cheap fares but take you to restaurants where they get commission and you get ripped off, and also to gem factories. It is a real scam. Get a tuk-tuk or taxi from well away from the temple and ask for a non-stop trip.

Wat Traimit - Just awesome!!. For all the admirers of Buddha and his principles, this is a must visit in Bangkok. To see a 2500 kg golden statue of this great man who guided the world to peace after the great Kalinga War is just so amazing..This shows the love the people have for this great preacher and philosopher..His preachings are valid to this day and humbles you on this visit. Don't miss!!

good but a lot better wats to see in thailand. this was the first temple we saw. I did enjoy it and it was good to see if all you want to do in Thailand is see wats. but this one was tiny in comparison - it was good though. would recommend to a friend if they have time to do something else. cover your arms and legs! I had to wear my mac and was roasting. and had to pay to use a skirt.
magnificent. great place, worth to visit, walk and enjoy yourself, you can get tuk tuk which brings you to all Buddhas and atractinos for silly money

Put this on your list. Interesting place. You will find a lot of people taking your pictures and then when you come out they will sell you the pictures in a button. Beware of the prices asked. Suggest you bargain.

Interesting. Nice backstory of the 'hidden' golden buddha. They have a nice little museum section. It really is a beautiful statue. Temple is much newer, and 'busy' on the outside. Worth a visit in my opinion.
Wonderful city full of temples. Must see and ask the Buddha to grant your prayer. Beautiful temple and with a guide a very interesting story and tradition to learn about.
Beautiful. Cover your knees to get in palace or borrow sarong from entrance with deposit. It is beautiful when you get inside the temple to feel the vibe.

Not very touristy. This is a quiet place and beautiful. The statue is very expressive. And don't miss looking at the doors with some gold inlay work. Infact the large bells there too are beautifu. Take the time to visit it.

Must visit. Amezing Experiance, every one must visit this place, Golden Budha made of 5.5 tons of solid gold, you need ticket to enter but no one will ask you for ticket when you going in, they expect honesty from every one.

A rare discovery. We did not intend to come to this temple and dicovered by accident. The decoration was just amazing and the scupture was stunning. The way out was not easy as we could not find a taxi to get back to our hotel. Great site to visit.
Simple Temple. If you want to avoid the crowd and see a nice temple then this is your place. There are a few steps to climb but not many and not too steep (there is also a left).

Stunning huge 5 tonne gold buddah. This is one of the most impressive man made objects i've seen. If it really is solid gold it is worth an untold fortune. It gleams like the sun and is well worth a look.
Blingy in the extreme!. £27 million of gold buddha in a temple. Has to be seen to be believed! I thought it was gold plated at first.....amazingly not.
Simple but beautiful. In the centre of the city, far from the others monuments, but a beautiful temple and impress Buddha. Very easy to go there by tuk tuk
The biggest golden statue of buddha is here. Brilliant temple and a must watch along with the Wat Pho temple... do not miss it!! the street food outside the temple is also good!

Simply Stunning!. On our first day in Bangkok, we decided to, amongst other things, check out the Golden Buddha. And we were amazed! A golden Buddha that is made of solid gold! Need I say more?There is a sense of peace and calm inside the temple and the Buddha is simply magical. There is also a museum close by that explains the history of the Buddha statues and how they evolved artistically. For serious and casual observers, this temple is a must-visit.
Excellent. Must if ur in Bangkok ...we took a boat till the place and took a tuk tuk till the temple.was excellent

Average for Indian. We Indian are quite accustomed with Temples and we all are quite proud of Golden Temple, Amritsar. When you visit Wat Traimit, what you'd imagined is a huge Temple covered in Gold with equally huge Statue of Buddha covered in gold; and what you get is a normal size temple with a normal statue covered in 18K gold.....
Don't miss it!. Just mind blowing and such beauty. A peaceful and calming place to be. Plenty of shade for those who require it plus the entrance fee allows one a free bottle of water.
Another Temple. We saw 3 temples, they are a MUST SEE on any visit to Bangkok but I would not rush back for another viewing

Far more interesting than I expected. The exhibits and displays tell an interesting story about Thai history and Chinese integration into Thai society that was utterly fascinating.
