Two hours flew by as we travelled through the exhibition. It culminated in looking at the solid gold Buddha (which is hugely impressive) but by then that was almost secondary. Only dislike are the ever present hawkers at the entrances- just move on.

Average site to visit. It was just ok, not such a great place to actually visit. It was very very hot and stepping our of our wagon and climbing the 4 storey temple was a mammoth task for us. There is nothing much except for the golden buddha.

Another wonderful location to visit. Once again if you are on a half day tour they should visit this location. From memory, as I did visit a few temples, they do have a lift to get access to the level where the Golden Buddha sits. Another one to add to the must see list.
nice place. i visited this place and liked it a lot. You get a lot of peace of mind while in the temple.If i go back to Bangkok, will visit this pl;ace again
Nice temple. There are a lot of temple in Bangkok and this is one of the ones that is ok to visit when you are in that area of town.

The golden Buddha is impressive. It is very important to bring long clothes (shirt to the elbow and a skirt or pants to the ankles). Before going to the Buddha you can visit a small museum that tells the history of the Buddha statues and their artistic development. Then up the stairs to the top of temple.The golden Buddha is impressive and very beautiful.
You MUST see this!. Amazing site! Get a picture here at the feet facing towards the head. Amazing in color and black and white!!

5.2 tonne gold. u dont need a ticket to see this though people still but it unknowingly....its amazing to see the 5.2. tonne gold statue but the history behind it is even more amazing.do read about it!

Terriffic.. This was our first stop in Bangkok, and it was beautiful. I am glad I saw it first because the other temples and palaces are even more mind blowing than this one- but this makes an excellent first stop. Remember that these are places of worship and to be respectful. I believe admission is free.And can I also say, I do not understand the people who complain about 15$ to tour an ancient temple or palace. If you are going to travel 1000's of miles to a foreign country and then complain about a small fee? These places are incredible and require maintenance and care for the future of humanity. I cant even see a movie for much less than 15$ these days. Come on people!

Worthwhile to see.... Quite a few temples and shrines in Bangkok and we saw this as part of a half day tour so only spent about 20 minutes here. It's a lot smaller than I imagined but I guess that's understandable as it's solid gold :-) If you like visiting temples and doing the sights in a city then you will appreciate this.

Great Relic and Great Story. The sheer size and value of this almost-solid-gold Buddha is hard to believe. The story of its preservation from Burma invaders, and subsequent re-discovery in the 1950s, is equallyimpressive. Worth a visit.
a solid gold Buddha !!. This Buddha has a very peaceful personality.. and a true gold glory!! Very close to the very busy China market for a bit of shopping after a visit to Wat Traimit.
Quiet, beautiful. Lovely temple, awesome giant Buddha to admire, wasn't too busy when I went in the afternoon. Recommend
Great treat. Fantastic golden Buddha massive in size. We went with one other couple . We saw other Buddhas as wellafter seeing about 3or4 different Buddhas that's enough

Bling bling shinning temple. This temple closest station is Hua Lam Phong although some roadworks were ongoing during our visited.To enter this temple, you have to pay for entrance fees. Most of temple in Thailand have to wear long sleeves and dress longer down to knee.This temple is have a lot of steps to get up therefore get ready yourself to climb up.Have fun !

Beautiful. This sitting Buddha was just beautiful. It made me wonder how they managed to lift a 5.5 tonne Gold and remain hidden during the war.Ticket purchase counter at the back. Be careful when you're here. Lots of con people around especially outside the temple at the corner of the Mechanic shop (exactly in front of the Chinatown Gate).Anyone offers you advise on what to visit and insist that there's an attraction nearby that's not to be missed, NEVER BELIEVE THEM !!.Walk away. Be safe and trust your own instinct.

Another beautiful temple. If this is your first time to Bangkok, then this is a must. Do take the main boat and pay on the boat, Baht15 per trip. If you pay at the counter its Baht40. Entrance fee: Baht40Do dress appropriately. Do bring a shawl if you are wearing sleeveless blouses. Lots of pictures to take outside the temple and inside the temple. If I am not mistaken, we took some nice shots inside the temple.You can get blessings from the monk, tooWill go again..
Massive gold buddha!. Very impressive to look at, the Buddha's head and lower body parts are made from massive gold. If the sun is out, it can be very hot to climb up the steps.
ano t her great tour. What a sight to see, the culture and history.outfielders exceptional and made learning so interesting

A gem. A stone's throw from the metro, its in the middle of China town. The statue (5.5 tons of solid gold) is a sight to behold. A must is to also see the exhibition which explains the antecedents of the statue. Like all Thai temples, the architecture is fabulous

Beautiful Golden Buddha. Quite impressive, this Golden Buddha, said to be the world's largest solid gold statue. There are a variety of stories as to how the Buddha came to be uncovered from the plaster coating that "protected" it from being stolen. If you visit the temple make certain to go to Chinatown, the flower market and vegtable market, good location for this beautiful Buddha making the entire trip worthwhile.

Golden Buddha. A real gold statue of lord Buddha looks beautiful. Although the temple gets very crowded in evenings so try and go in the morning. The story behind it says that this gold statue was discovered accidentally! Wow!

Wow. Not too much else to see in the grounds (which doesn't have the greatest location) except for the immense, golden Buddha which is a sight in itself. But what's why you're here, isn't it?Worth a look if you're in the area (it's kind of near Chinatown), has an interesting and amusing history too.
Amazing!. This Buddha is truly beautiful and well worth a visit, it would have been nice to spend more time here and with less people. It was very crowded the day we visited

Beautiful Buddah. I have been visiting this temple since at the old premises (next to the new one). The new ones is very beautiful and building is very well build and grand. Worth the walk up and see the GOLDEN buddah.
It glows. We went early in the morning before the huge crowds showed up. It was beautiful and serene. The Buddha seemed to glow in the morning light.

Hard to find in a filthy city, really worth a visit?. Is this place really worth a visit in this terribly hot all year round, filthy and noisy bangkok? Ultra kitsch temple (looking like litterally ALL others)with "golden" Buddha... Allow max 15mns, that s it. Now, as generally thailand has gotten more agressive, people are less interested in tourists, only money seems to count anymore, smiles are NON EXISTANT most of the time and beaches are filthy almost everywhere, full of SCAMMERS, russians and their mafias, unless you go in the extreme south national parks. Go to Laos instead for nature, Cambodia for smiles, Myamar for buddhism and maldives for clean beaches!

It isn't real gold we found out. But it's still worth the trip. The Buddha is beautiful and the temple is sacred and peaceful! I enjoyed every minute of it, and felt a kind of serenity. The souvenirs outside the temple were great, I brought some back for my friends and they loved them.

Good Attraction. May not be top of the must see's in Bangkok but a good one none the less. The Buddha really dwafts all around it. Very clean surrounding area with local's praying in the adjourning temples.
Captivating & Calm. Sight of a large golden Buddha for a moment captivates your attention. Would recommend that you sit there for at least 5 minutes
a Big Big Statue. It is known for 3 meter tall and tons of solid gold image. The exchange rate was the best inside the complex, as you enter and next to the ticket windows.

Peaceful, beautiful and very shiny!. Wat Traimit was the first temple in which I felt peace. I'm not religious, but I love seeing people of faith practicing and believing, and walking into this temple made me feel at peace.
It's story is very interesting, and as in with the Emerald Buddha, you can see how Buddhists see their deity as a jewel.

Good but you have to pay. I think paying for religious sites is a bit of a wrong, trying to cash in. It's not that expensive to be fair. It cost a little extra to see the museum underneath also. But seeing the Golden Buddha is well worth it, be aware that short skirts and vests are not allowed and they will require you to wrap them in a scarf , which costs to hire. So be prepared before you go, this is the same for all Wat's (temples)
So much gold!!. The temples are built with so much gold. Everything is so put away and the tours are amazing. So much history inside there!!

Dedicated roof tiles for lost loved ones. Great place. Peaceful and culturally aware. We made donations to place messages to lost loved ones on the roof using their clay tiles.Beautiful golden oversized buddha. Worth a quick visit to marvel at the sheer size of it. Can see locals in prayer and experience the real reason for temples. Less commercial here. However, do your best to resist the tuk tuk drivers who want to take you to suit and jewellery shops in return for your visit here.

Impressive. This temple is impressive, my one warning is that if you go in the middle of the day it is extremely hot and the marble heats up, you are to take your shoes off when visiting inside the te,ple. Just be wary that once you step back outside it is hotter than stepping on hot sand!!! The views around the temple are not so impressive as you are down town in the district, parking can be an issue. Not a place to spend more than 30 minutes or so.
Beautiful. The time I went there it was under construction but even in reforms it is a beautful wat. Worth a visit, it is close to chinatown in bangkok.

Golden Buddha. Located in China town area of Bangkok. The story goes that the statue was earlier covered in plaster to hide the gold underneath from ravaging soldiers from enemy countries. It was discovered accidently.The statue itself is grand and huge with a very peaceful glow.
golden buddha. worth seeing out of many Buddha temples in city. travel in taxi. avoid evening time to avoid rush. real gold statue
Golden Budda. Found the Temple very interesting the only problem I had was by using the underground was to then actually find the temple!!

Fantastic. The best way to get to Wat Traimit has to be via the Chao Phraya River Taxi Boats that go up & down the river. There is a stop very close to the Temple. The groups of touts outside can be a little pushy & annoying but a little Thai goes a long way as they say, just be polite when saying no!The statue of Buddha is amazing & although the temple can get a little crowded with all the visitors it is well worth the trip.Please if you are visiting though, remember this is a temple & an important place for us Buddhists so please show respect. During my last visit I had words with some English people as their teenage children were sat with the soles of their feet directed at the Buddha image. This is very disrespectful & they were offended when I pointed this out to them! Please show respect to the Buddha image.

Over rated. Of course it was 95 degrees, humid day w/o air conditioning. Beautiful temple and place, but w/o a guide didnt realy appreciate everything there was to see. In retrospect get a guide. The tour books were all too confusing. Couldnt figure out what was what. I guess I am not into temples.
Beautiful buddha. Beautiful buddha, but reclinig is better! Beware they do not ask for tickets! You can avoid paying if you are a Skroutz guy!

Pure Gold. I have never seen a piece of pure gold like this before. It is truly beautiful. Learning about the history of it only provides further appreciation for the whole set. I would recommend it if you got time, but I wouldn't call it a "must see"

Golden!!!!!!!!!!!!!. I visited this place last on April with my big and it's really a beautiful temple and incredible. The golden buddha was amazing.Although, the best way for me to get there is by the river !

Beautiful Buddha, fantastic history. A jaw droppingly beautiful sight!! this Buddha is solid gold, and is totally awe-inspiring. Our guide Sulai made the whole visit even better by filling us in on the history surrounding its discovery. The touts at the bottom of the steps are annoying, but having Suai with us made it easier to say no!
not my preferred. may be because I am Italian, but in my opinion it is more curious than artistic.And normally too many visitors and a too small area around to appreciate it's impressive dimensions.
So much gold. Very interesting looking at the museum to learn about the early culture of Bangkok with the Chinese settlment.

simply amazing. Just visited this place last week with my friends and it's really a beautiful temple and incredible. The golden buddha was amazing.Although, the best way for me to get there is by the river (an experience not to be missed). It's really worthwhile!!!
But I almost fainted because it's too hot.

Serene atmosphere. Wat Traimit was in our must-see list, and it was worth the time to get there. The Golden Buddha statue was a remarkable sight and seeing Buddhists doing their prayer added a beautiful and serene atmosphere to it.

5.5 tonnes of gold is going to be worth a look!. Beautiful temple, beautiful buddha, so peaceful and relaxing. A bit of a walk up steps in searing heat and be sure to take something for the women to cover themselves with. Not too crowded, easy to access, well worth the visit.

Good temple. - Really nice Golden Buddha.
- Need to climb 2 floors to visit Buddha so plan accordingly, entrace fee is 60 THB per person.
-- Temple closes at 5pm.
-- There is a museum at the 2nd floor which you need to pay extra for entering in to it.

Amazing Buddha. This temple isn't big like wat phra kaew or wat pho.. But the Buddha statue is incredible, it's all made from gold.. When you know about the story how they found this statue, you will amazed

Did you know what is so special about the golden temple. The Golden Buddha Temple (Wat Traimit) is an amazing architecture and a beautiful place to visit but do you know the secret that is hidden at the dome. Ok let’s go back to 1920 in Tibet and monk who is being sent to Bangkok to study and spread the word, he stays in Bangkok for ten years and loves the people and country when again he is asked to take over a temple in India and of course he goes.Now he has spent a couple of years in India when he read a story in the newspaper that a British farmer in the far North West of the country was clearing his land to plant crops mostly tea and have come across some rubble on his that had an ancient script which he was having problem deciphering and put a notice in the Indian Times Paper that he was going to remove the rubble unless anyone could read the script and published a few lines in the paper.The monk had been studying this script in Bangkok and understood it; he straight away went to the far North West to visit the farmer. And got permission from the farmer to read and dig the stone and read the script. The stones said below lays Gupta, he then asked permission to excavate the site this required the High Commission to get involved and they agreed so under supervision he excavated the site and found a jade coffin a small one and in the lid was written here lays Buddha light of the world. Inside the small coffin was an Urn and in which was ashes. This was quite a sensation at the time, he asked and was granted permission to give the ashes to the then King of Thailand. He was given an escort back to Thailand where he gave the King the ashes. The ashes were split into 50% 25% 25% with 50% being put into the top dome of the golden Buddha temple and 25% being put into the emerald Buddha temple and the last 25% being given as a gift to the king of Japan. When the ashes arrived in Japan it was given a state procession through Tokyo to the palace where a specially constructed temple was built to deposit the ashes. And today in Japan there is a public holiday to commemorate the arrival of Buddha’s ashes. In Thailand no holiday but the Golden temple was built to house the ashes, and in Japan even today a holiday to remember the ashes.

All that gold.... Really a must see. The suggestion is to pay 40 bat per person however on my observation no one collected tickets purchased just to see the golden buddha. No water is offered. You pretty much take off your shoes and enter after climbing to the 2nd set of steps. Its open doors surrounding the statue lends for excellent pics. Go without a tour guide and see China Town after.

Amazing. A marvelous sight to behold. Don't miss this if you are in Bangkok. You can imagine what a solid gold Buddha might look like, but the actual sight surpasses your imagination. Be prepared, however, to climb many stairs to get there.

Our favorite. We had a tour guide for the day and this was our first stop. What we found most interesting is that this Buddha has been around they estimate for appx. 800 years and it was only in the last 50 or so years that they knew it was gold! It has been moved around and some plaster or white covering chipped off revealing the gold beneath. Since it's solid gold, they weren't sure how to move it. By accident, an arm came off at a joint and then they realized the architect so many years ago designed it to be taken apart in 9 pieces. He even put extra cold inside the Buddha for touch ups. From what we were told, currently, they can only figure out how to disassemble 2 or 3 of the body parts. If you look close, you'll see the joints.Enjoy!

Solid Gold!. How often can you claim you have seen a $350 million dollar statue? The solid Au statue has a different look than all the other 'gold' buddhas in Thailand. While this temple is not as popular as the Wat Po's, the Temple is within walking distance from the final stop on the subway. There are also some low cost eating options in China Town or down by the river towards the Sheraton.
Spectacular. The Golden Buddha was an awesome sight. Wat Traimit was abuzz with a small market and monks selling holy things. There is also a good view of the Chinese Gate from the top of the temple.
You have to come here!. you have to come & seeing this destination if your going to thailand for a holiday, i do not to talk more if you want to know coming &seeing you know what happen

Hard to believe it is solid gold!. Beautiful seated Buddha - 12.5 feet high.weighing 5.5 tons, and worth 28.5 £million! Incredible to think it is 700 years old, but was only discovered to be solid gold in 1955 - before that, it was covered in plaster to keep it safe from theft.Well worth a visit - but expect crowds, naturally. Don't forget to dress modestly and leave shoes at the door.
Loved it.. Its a must see destination if your going to thailand for a holiday, no need to rave about it or oversell it....its one of the things that needs to go on your bucket list of places to go.

Impressive artwork, but little else to see. If you like Buddha statues and gold sculptures, this is the place for you. This is the biggest golden Buddha in the world, with 5.5 tons worth of pure gold. You will take 5 minutes appreciating it and that's it - there's not much else around. There a big Buddha like thousand others. Except this one is made of gold.

5.5 TONS of solid gold. Wow! Hard to believe that there was 5.5 tons of solid 18k gold just sitting there. The Buddha was beautiful, so peaceful looking. The history on how it got to where it sit today was intresting.
Stunning!. Visited this Buddha during a cycling tour. It was absolutely stunning. We were able to hear the monks chanting which was really beautiful

beautiful. its a lovely temple with an actual gold statue.., when we climb up, we were surprise that it actually made of gold and not really that all guarded.. as a mater of fact. we only see 1 guard sitting on the corner and almost fell to sleep..it was gorgeous and humble at the same time, along with other statues and the beautiful doors, its a kind of serene feeling once all the tourist are done with the pictures.this place really need to be visited, its really nice. and so is the lady at the ticket box (very helpful and kind to us)

pure gold!. I went here since I was already in the Chinatown area and was curious as the buddha was said to be made of gold. It's a huge buddha image made of gold! you have the option to see the exhibitions at the 2nd and 3rd floors at 100 baht and the entrance to the buddha is 40 baht.There are two ways in getting here. via the boat, get off at Tha Rachawongse and from the pier, walk about one km to the buddha along Thanon Yaowarat. Or you can take the MRT route and get off at Sa Tha Ni Hua Lamphong (Hua Lamphong station), walk a bit and you'll reach the temple.

Wat with a Museum. Wat Traimit is a good sized Wat. It does look a little different to some of the others in Bangkok. At present there is an exhibition about the Golden Buddha in the Wat also which provides more information than most of the other Wats
Amazing place. A lovely Temple with amazing Golden Buddha....Very humbling place with stunning architecture ....Make sure ladies are dressed appropriately though!!

Solid marble as well as gold.... The last time I visited the Golden Buddha about 22 years ago, it was still housed in a relatively simple wooden temple. Since then this marble marvel has been erected for it and it is a little overwhelming. There is however a very interesting exhibition on the discovery and transport of the Buddha on the second floor, as well as an adjoining gift shop. Admission was 100 Bht at our visit plus additional 40 for the viewing of the Buddha, which is still very beautiful. I could just sit at it's feet forever, so despite the grand surroundings it is wonderful to visit.The temple is so close to Chinatown that you can do both the temple and a walk through Chinatown in half a day.To get there, walk from the Hua Lamphong metro station, beware of many scam artists on the way.

Not very visited, yet really beautiful.. The cost into this temple is 20 Baht only, the Golden Buddha inside is gorgeous, and the wall paintings are even better than the statue. This temple is not visited too much, so you can get all the pictures you want with no random people walking into it. We enjoyed the visit to this temple very much.

Peace with serenity. 500 Baht is a bit expensive as entry fees but yet definitely worth spent money. The crafted walls, gold temple with hanging silver trees everything symbolizes the aristrocracy of the holy emerald Buddha. You can not take pictures inside and can take some flowers to show respect.
Nice place. Good place to visit in bangkok. This was a part of the half day bangkok city tour. Its worth watching this temple.
awesome temple. very amazing temple,,the way they have made it and it gives a feel of you being in a spiritual place
Wonderful to see. A must see experience for any visitor to Bangkok. It exhibits the culture and history of a time long gone.
Worth a sight. This one was quite impressive. We could not spend a lot of time here as it was also quite hot on the day we went. However, this is something one should budget at least an hour to do.

Worth the visit. Wow! Glad we spent the extra money on a tuk tuk to go see the Golden buddha. It is huge! Very touristy but if you get there early enough you will have a steady flow and will be able to take in all beauty that it is.

You Don't Understand the Grandeur Until You See It With Your Own Eyes.. When we started out that day of sightseeing, I thought to myself, "So...we'll start with the Golden Buddha" and not thinking too much about it. But then, we saw it. It was so huge, so impressive! Seeing all that gold in one spot that was handcrafted so long ago...it's unimaginable. The size of this Buddha is huge. Pictures will never do it justice.And to think it was encased in cement to keep it a secret and then, by accident, they found the Golden Buddha inside! Amazing. Wonderful.Just a couple of other items about this attraction - you'll get bombarded by paparazzi at the base of the temple. They'll come running down the steps with their cameras clicking away. It's hilarious. Then once you are done seeing the Golden Buddha, they'll be waiting for you, ready to sell you pictures of yourself.Additionally, inside the temple, you can give a donation and pick up a bottle of Buddhist Holy Water. If you drink it, it's supposed to wash away evil. It's all such a good time. Enjoy!

Out of the way and worth it!. This temple houses a solid gold, massive buddha. I went here expecting something the size of the jade Buddha, and I was mistaken. It is HUGE! Well worth. Also a great story behind it and a nice tuk tuk ride if you can find a trustworthy driver.

OMG!. This is the most awesome thing that I have ever seen in my life. What a sight! A magnificent, beautiful piece of art. The golden buddha is by far the most must thing to go and see in Bangkok. The guide that we had, Adul told us all about the history and made our visit even more spectacular.

A Holy Place In Chinatown. I walked from Hua Lamphong MRT to this temple. Although the temple that house the golden sitting Buddha is small, it is beautiful and unique. This is the temple worth visiting in Chinatown.The Golden Buddha itself has an old history. I would recommend this temple to others.

Beautiful start to exploring Yaowarat. Wat Traimit is near the beginning of Yaowarat and makes a good starting point to exploring Chinatown.It's easily reached, MRT to Hua Lamphong station and follow the walkways North West until you see the white and gold gates of Wat Traimit. the tickets are sold at an unassuming kiosk deeper into the temple grounds, you can buy a basic ticket to just see the golden buddha statue at the top or you can buy the full package and see all the attractions, which include a history of Chinese settlement in Thailand (english language translations right next to the thai on the attraction info plaques).The temple's main attraction is at the top (you have to take your shoes off and must be dressed appropriately) and it is a sight to see. The general artistry of the statue is not that pretty to look at, you can tell the casting process used was not that sophisticated, but anything cast in 5 tons of pure gold looks beautiful. be mindful while you're there, devoud buddhists and locals will be praying, so careful while you're surepitously attempting to snape a photo, or you might find out how devout many of these guys really are.

Impressive and inspiring. Don't miss this Buddha. It is unique and if possible, read the history and the story of how it was rediscovered in the 50s. My guide mentioned that there were a lot of gaps in the history of this Buddha. That made an already special attraction just that bit more mystical.
Excellent. Yet another of the iconic Bangkok temples and one not to be missed from any itinerary. Easy to fit in alongside the other key places not to be missed.

The artistry extends beyond the buddha. A great temple to visit and start to appreciate the true artisanship that goes into creating and maintaining these living spiritual centers. Stop and look closely. The details of the buildings, both inside and out are the result of painstaking work and patience.

Wonderful 5 ton gold statue!. Very nice temple, with this huge pure gold statue as the cherry on top of the visit. A 5 ton Buddha only discovered last century, as before it was thought to be made of plaster, because it was covered in it to be protected from attack from any enemies. Great place to start a visit through Chinatown and then walk your way up there!

Impressed. I think this was my favorite temple (and we saw a lot of temples) there was something about this one that impressed my more than any other, not just the Buddha but the whole temple. I recommend you take your time taking it all in, we were lucky in that we had the time to do that.

Not to be missed. Culture is every were here. You feel the past sweeping over you when you visit the temple.
Time can stand still and you see & feel it all around you. Well worth the day trip out to see all the temples.

Gold Gold Gold!. This temple is beautiful!!! It's near Shanghai Mansion hotel in Chinatown. The architectural designs are beyond words. Very attention to details and I bet Thai people are very proud of their Wats because they are all so well taken care of and preserved. The buddha inside is the highlight. Made of pure solid 5 tons gold! Amazing! There's a small admission fee that you have to pay, I think it's around 60 bht per person. Worth a visit!The history about this temple and how they found the Golden Buddha was a miracle itself, which you will only get to hear if you visit this temple by joining a tour or having a private local guide. The temple does not offer guide tour though.So make sure you visit this temple when you're in Bangkok. It is a beautiful grand temple that will amaze you.

Not on the normal Bangkok visit list but should be. Temple of the Golden Buddha (Wat Traimit) is not in a regular visited section of Bangkok but does not require any significant travelling. A reasonable temple but the Golden Buddha inside is what you want to visit.In 1955 a plaster Buddha was being relocated to a new building and it was dropped. To everyone's surprise the plaster cracked and revealed a 5.5t gold Buddha.To get to it take the marine dept ferry stop (just north of Sathon Pier), then walk through some very interesting back streets for +-500m to the temple. These streets have vehicle repair shops where gearboxes , drive shafts and other dirty second hand parts are piled 3+m high in the street outside the businesses. Interesting to see.You are not too far from Bangkok central railway station and Lamphong BRT station.

lots of gold. This is a wonderful Wat to see. The buddha is large and there is an opportunity to pose for pictures right in front of the alter with the 5.5 ton golden buddha behind. Be sure to look behind the buddha...you can see how he was assembled.

A Must See and Do!. Open every day!DO NOT pay ANY attention to anyone who tries to tell you that the venue is closed or tries to direct you to another entrance! Such people are just out to scam you!Men MUST wear long pants and women MUST cover bare shoulders!Don't have long pants/cover up? Don't worry as you may rent such for 30Baht + 100 Baht deposit refunded upon returning the clothing!The Grand Palace is a very large complex so be prepared to walk!

Temple visit.. It is a very beautiful temple very well maintained. Basic amenities like water and washrooms are provided.It is a very tourist friendly place.It is a vey peaceful place good for meditation.

Must Visit. Another must see temple in Bangkok. Climb the stairs for a great view of the river and city. All sales booths are tucked on the sides so it's not distracting from the temple. Great place to sit and meditate or simply enjoy the view.

Great Thai treasure. Very spiritual place...too many people though. I thinkk it has to be more secure by the authorities. Try to get a reading first about the history about it. Because if you have a tour guide the explanation is very quick due the people visiting the temple.
700 yr old History. Beautiful Wat. 5 storyed complex, lots of stairs. Wear clothes that cver your legs ad shoulder. Ensure that you wear socks as the marble can burn your feet.

Huge golden buddah. It is located about 8 mins walk away from the MRT station. The entrance fee is B40. You can take a good picture of the Wat from the building where the prayers are done. You can see the locals pray and release sparrows.The main Golden Buddah building is 4 storey high and the golden buddah is located at the top. You get good view of many buddah statutes. It is well worth the visit.

Shocking to see that much gold close up!. We were taken to Wat Traimit by a local Thai friend and it was a great spot away from some of the crazy tourist areas (it's in Chinatown). You simply can't comprehend that the massive Buddha in front of you is pure gold - it's just unbelievable. Know that as with most wats, there is a dress code. There's also a nominal admission fee (our friend paid - a few dollars?). And, of course, be mindful of the people who are actually going in there for spiritual/religious reasons (don't take photos of them if you can avoid it).

Great history of the Golden Buddha. This was the first temple we visited on our stay in Bangkok and I love the history behind it. Apparently (and I'm paraphrasing terribly), the current shining golden buddha that graces this temple had once been housed in Cambodia. During the ensuring wars, the temple had been afraid of conquerors taking the 5.5 tons of golden buddha away and melting him down, so they encased him in plaster. Move forward 400-600 years, and when he was taken from the Cambodian temple to Bangkok, and efforts were made to clean him up, they discovered the gold underneath and realized how precious this buddha was, not just spiritually, but what he traveled through to reach them now in Bangkok. When we toured the temple, we were blessed by a monk, just across the path from the main temple. Since monks are not allowed to touch women (or vice versa), when he was tying the string bracelet around our wrists, we were very careful that he not have to touch us. He blessed us with a quick sprinkling of holy water and then tied the bracelet on to wish us good luck going forward. A very cool experience and a great way to start our tour of Thailand and Cambodia.
Interesting story. The history of this buddha is the most interesting. Get a guide, I don't know how much of the story is true but, it's a good story!

Must see Buddah image. No visit to Chinatown is complete without a visit to see the Golden Buddha at Wat Traimit. I'm slightly biased about this temple as, since I first saw this Buddah image 25 years ago, I have always felt quite spiritual in a way that I don't with my own religion (to the extent that I got a full back tattoo of the image a few years ago). There are lots of golden Buddahs dotted around Bangkok but only one made of solid gold hence the need for a visit. In the past the Buddah's resting place was quite basic but they have now built him a new shrine in the same compound which is more in keeping with his stature.The temple is packed with tour parties in the morning but if you visit after lunch the crowds have thinned out. If you go on your own rather than part of a tour party take the MRT to Hualamphong and the temple is about a 10 minute walk away.

Unbelievable. Reported as the largest Golden Buddha in the world in the mara conquering attitude is a sight to see.Over 15 feet high, solid gold weighing over 5.5 tons and 700 years old. Not to be missed.

Another must see...it's the Golden Buddha. If you have time I would see this as it's the world renowned Golden Buddha! It doesn't take long to visit this Wat as the main 'attraction' is the Golden Buddha but worth a visit! Again, as with all Wats, bring long pants and cover the shoulders.
Very nice temple. This is very nice temple so relaxing and be with 1 with the gods and I always like to come and pray to my buddah give me good luck

Beautifull place. The temple of Golden Buddha is interesting and exotic. The statue, the architecture and the views are worth it. Plus you don't need to spend too much time here, can visit this place in 30-40 minutes, so take a chance!
Near Chinatown. Nice Temple and Buddha but we were tired after visiting the Grand Palace and the Reclining Buddha in one day.
Interesting History. While the temple and the Buddha itself are interesting I really enjoyed hearing the history of the Buddha statue. Make sure you ask about it when you go.

Interesting site, borderline spiritual experience. Fun history fact: the Buddha was originally covered up in layers of clay/cement during an invasion on its original temple to avoid being stolen by criminals and wasn't rediscovered to be golden until several years ago when the Buddha was being moved to its new temple. It was accidentally dropped and the outer cast cracked open to reveal the golden making. As it is a running temple, many locals visit to pray and provide their offerings in front of the golden Buddha so its important to be considerate. Was kind of a spiritual experience sitting in silence admiring the golden Buddha and watching the locals honor their faith.TIP: If you want to wear a tank top during your trip (which is highly advised to beat the heat) but plan to visit temples and holy sites always bring a sarong (bottom) and a cardigan (top) for instant cover-up. Better to wear sandals so taking your footwear off at certain cites isn't inconvenient.

spiritual experience. not many tourists were here (part of the charm - hope sharing here doesn't flood the place)...the monks were very welcoming of foreigners and for 100 baht (you choose how much you want to donate) you are welcomed and personally blessed by the monks. i was there on the last day of a religious festival so it mightn't always be like this - but on this day it was.
All Gold. A must see, so beautiful and an all gold Buddha. Make sure to look at the beautiful gilded doors and ceiling...amazing....and this temple was not as crowded as the Grand Palace.

Not bad. The temple is small. Not much to see but it is worth vistarlo as there is the Golden Buddha largest in the world. Inside the temple there is the explanation of how this statue was discovered (once covered with plaster).
Read the history of this Buddha before you go. Our guide explained The history of this Buddha, which made visiting much more magical. Read your guide book before you go.
is reconstracted now. I visited this temple 6 years ago. Now is under reconstraction and is not possible visit temple. Very interesting is history of this golden Budha, please can read this history.

Worth a visit. This was part of a trip to several temples etc. The temple itself is very impressive and the Golden Buddha is a magnificent sight. The surrounding area was extremely busy and there were traffic jams but we were glad we visited this tourist attraction. Well worth a visit

Wanderer Buddah statue. The main attraction is not the Temple but the golden Buddah statue and its history.It's the largest solid gold statue in the world. People say that the statue was created during the period of Ayutthaya Kingdom and it was saved from the invaders because it was covered with stucco, so no one knew how valuable it was(almost 6 tons of gold).Wat Traimit is its new home.
Gold. Solid gold buddha that is huge. The story behind the golden buddha and its location are very interesting. Worth a look.
Impressive!. In Bangkok there is a lot to see and the Temple of the Golden Buddha is a must see. Make sure you ring the bells for good luck before entering the temple.

Five and Half TONs of GOLD...and what a story!. This was one of our first stops in Bangkok and it certainly made an impression. It is not everyday that a person gets to see this much gold in one place. The Golden Buddha's story of "discovery" after being hidden for so many years makes you wonder how no one found it earlier. Thankfully, it did remain hidden during turbulent times and is now available for us all to view. At the time of our visit, first thing in the morning, the temple was not very busy and it made it easy to look around. As mentioned in earlier posts the location is close to Chinatown and it is a nice quiet oasis in the middle of many distractions
Graceful Place. A temple with lots of simplicity as if telling you indirectly about Lord Buddha. The temple closes at 5 pm.

Fun and History. It was a fun and also very glorious to be see first hand the Temple of the Golden Buddha (Wat Trainit) we enjoyed t as a group and we would not mind visiting it again with friends .. you simply get stunned with the beauty there ...

Beautiful temple. Temple was beautiful with golden buddha statue, It was included in our city tour package so the entry ticket was provided. Stayed there for around 1 hour...guide gave us the background and the history of the temple. It was quite crowded as well
Well worth a visit. About a ten minute walk from the grand palace amazing statue off the Buddha no dislikes a must see and you can have a massage while you are there

Excellent !! Impressive ..... The temple is close to Hualaphong subway and train.Its a very well built temple..The major attraction is the buddha statue made of solid gold,,its sheer joy to your eyes...You do not have to spend much time here but its a must visit place .,,, You can see Thai religious rituals being performed ... Nice and serene place to visit ...

Impressive story. The Golden Buddha is pretty impressive and the story on how it was "discovered" is interesting. To think that is made out of solid gold! Not many tour groups go here so it is an easy sight to walk around.This is not considered a major sight but makes a good starting point for visiting Chinatown next door.

Great temple at the gateway to Chinatown ! What dreams are made of !. Loved this place ! Only temple I really explored in Bangkok--within site of the gate to Chinatown--close to Hualaphong subway and train...Full of cute cats...What dreams are made of ! Saffron robed monks, gold and white domed temples, gold buddhas, offerings to the gods and the biggest gold Buddha on earth..>Only a few $$ admission, views and photographic opps galore !

Impressive.. You don't need to spend a great deal of time here to see it all. The Golden Buddha is pretty impressive. To think that is made out of solid gold! My son set some birds free for about 100 Baht. Its meant to be good luck to do it here but for us it was just a cool thing to do while in Bangkok. It was very cool seeing the kids playing at the school next door to the temple. So different to anything we have seen back home.
Golden Buddha..... Temple was just OK. Major attraction is pure gold statue of Buddha weiging million tonnes. One can watch religious ceremonials performed by Thai's.

Impressive Buddha. The Wat holds not only the Golden Buddha but also a museum in where the story about the Golden Buddha is told. Not very cheap but wurth it. From there on you can visit the Chinese quarter by foot.
Another must in bangkok. A great place and a must in bangkok, the buddha is amazing and the vibe in the place is impresive, a little crowdy but it worths.

A Must-See in Bangkok!. What a nice temple to visit!We took the whole package including the Chinese Heritage exhibit. Very interesting!The story how the statue got to this place amazed us.As a sign of respect, make sure you are adequately dressed to visit temples in Thailand. This temple is no exception, but it is worth it.They furnish bags to carry your shoes, if necessary. Otherwise, just leave them outside the temple.What a fascinating story!Enjoy the Chinese Heritage exhibit too!

The Temple of the Golden Buddha - Wat Traimit. I have visited many of the temples in & around Bangkok. Wat Traimit has remained a favorite. The story of how the solid gold Buddha statue came to be in Bangkok is fascinating. To be in the presence of this statue is unforgettable. A recently built Marble temple now houses this Buddha image, If you enjoy the many temples then don't miss this one..

Buddha at high pedastal. It was a unique experience to visit this temple. Trip to Bagkok can not be complete without visiting this temple. A hindu visiting this temple feels that he has come to his own temple.

Not one to miss!. It will truly amaze you when you walk up to this grand site! There are lots of people coming and going and you are to take off your shoes so wear comfortable shoes and clothes. You have to have long pants and your shoulders have to be covered. It was very hot that day do we brought a change of clothes in a backpack. You may also to hire a tour guide. We hired east meets west and ask for Tawee.

buddha tour. The first temple we visited, on our tour. Very beautifully and carefully restored.the temple was less frequented when we arrived and it gave our guide more opportunity to point out interesting facts about the temple and the buddha as we were not rushed through. The buddha itself is truly amazing to see. Also

Take care. Came out of the pier (think pier 9) asked where palace was – got tuk tuk driver to take us there. Only to be told, palace was closed until 14.30 – but we could go on a tour!!! Realized later it was only a 5 minute walk from the pier and although palace is sometimes closed (often on a Wednesday and the priests say prayers until 14.30) worth checking with hotel. Also an “official” then got a tuk tuk driver to take us to see the Big Buddha – but the payoff was we had to endure going to 2 tailors and 1 gem merchants and listen to their sales patter. Also if you go to the pier and someone offers you a boat for 900bht – smile nicely and tell them NO. We got the boat back and paid 15 bht each.

Small but so grand. I've been to both Wat Po and the Grand Palace, but the moment I saw this, my jaw dropped! It's not only beautiful, there were so many activities going on when we were there.Absolutely top dollar attraction this !http://gostansikit.blogspot.com/2013/02/wat-trai-mit-on-temple-grounds.html
Nice. The golden buddha temple was nice. Good idol of sitting buddha, but not as large as the one in reclining buddha's temple
Amazing. Its quite the stunning temple. And when you see the magnificent buddha statue its nothing but awe inspiring. Lovely experience.
This temple is OK. There are too many temples to visit in Bangkok but this is one of the best. An amazing sight to see all that gold. This one is worth a visit

Not to miss. Excellent -- take your time, walk in the gaps between tour groups and this can be a most enjoyable place. Lunch time seems a fairly good to go because at least in the times I have been, the crowds seem a little less overpowering. Photos to cherish.

Lots of Gold. The Buddha is interesting, but not to the same degree as others in Bangkok. The best part of our visit was watching people bringing alms and then watching a woman in near constant motion moving them so there would be room for more. Combine this visit with a stop in Chinatown.

Lord Buddha lay peacefully.. and the golden hues of his astride frame.. speechless. This is a must see for those who would like to visit bangkok not merely for the massage parlours and shopping. Its a huge sculpture made out of GOLD, of the reclining Budhha, and all thetourist had to go around him.. Never seem something like this as stupendous and beautiful

Don't go specially here. This site is worth visiting, but don't make a special trip here. Combine a visit to this location with a visit to Bangkok's Chinatown which is also not that great on its own (i.e., if you have been to other major Chinatowns).

Very important tourist destination in Bangkok. Considering the historical and religious importance, the temple is one of the best amongst the Buddha temples in the world. we were informed that this is the biggest golden Buddha idol in the world. Visit to Bangkok never completes without visiting this temple.

Close to the station, and worth the detour. We were due to leave Bangkok by train, so left our bags at the station and walked to the temple. You can pay to see the Golden Buddha temple only, which costs just 40 baht.It is quite a climb up to the 4th floor to reach it, but well worth the climb. The statue itself is around 5.5 tons of solid gold, and the interior of the building has a wonderful ceiling and beatiful paintwork on the walls.
Gold , gold and gold !. It's very impressive to see something big like this made of gold !!! The temple itself is not huge but still impressive with all handmade wallpaper !!
One of the nicer temples. We have seen many of the temples in Bangkok. After a while they start to blend together. If you only want to see a few than this one should be on you list too.

Gold and full 5.5 Tons of it!!! Enthralling!. The temple is not as grand as the other temples in Bangkok, perhaps because it is very new, but the statue inside is truly enchanting and you get to see a solid statue of 5.5 MT of gold…. One thing about the temples of Bangkok: all of them envelop you in sheer calm and peace: all of them are so serene and peaceful, that you just cannot help but get ensconced in the blissful tranquility. Sure must visit. It is very near to China Town.

Interesting experience. This is a beautiful temple, but the amount of cars, people, tourist, venders, make the experience no a relaxing one, you can get there by the MRT (Hua Lamphong station) and walk to the temple, this is Chinatown, is a lot of construction around, so be aware of the traffic and pedestrians, it can be a very stressful process just to get there, you need to pay to go inside but it is beautiful, they have two different buildings in this complex, walk around as in the back is a school and you can see the students interacting and playing basketball, try to just bring the minimum amount of stuff, and of course long pants. Chinatown is a very cosmopolitan place, if you like to walk around do it, I am sure you will need a foot massage to keep going back to your destination.

Find yourself at Awe at a solid gold Buddha image.. I cant seem to miss coming to this temple every time I come to Bangkok. There is always an activity for you to participate in the temple. While having to pay an entrance fees to view and pay homage to the Golden Buddha, The rest of the temple complex doesn't impose any entrance fees.After this temple, you can wonder around Chinatown as well. :-)

Amazed at the honesty. Only a small temple, but what a gem. Not only the Buddha which is imposing enough but the internal decoration of the temple itself, wonderful. I still can't get my head around the fact that (assuming it's real) up to $300 million of gold is just sitting there. WOW!
5 golden rings. This is the best of all the golden buddhas in Bangkok. And there are hundreds, maybe thousands. Solid gold. Don't miss it.

Nice temple. People are very polite and welcoming. They know you are a tourist and they willingly approach you and offer to take pictures so we both could be in the pictures together. I thought that was very sweet and thoughtful of them.

Lots to see. The temple itself is quite small. The bottom floor exhibition is quite boring, but the next one up, concerning the history of the Buddha is pretty interesting. The golden Buddha is very pretty, but my nice blissful moment sitting quietly gazing on it was ruined by a brash tour guide shouting about money, and then a large bottom placing itself about an inch from my face. At the back of the littler building facing the temple is a massive fish that looks like a crocodile.

Special site, ancient, impressive and informative.. It is very important to bring long clothes (shirt to the elbow and a skirt or pants to the ankles). Before going to the Buddha you can visit a small museum that tells the history of the Buddha statues and their artistic development. Then up the stairs to the top of temple.The golden Buddha is impressive and very beautiful. The tour lasts no more than fifteen minutes.

Golden Visit. This buddha has an interesting story - be sure your guide shares it with you....respect the fact that people consider this a special place and dress accordingly. It is crowded but worth the climb up stairs...be sure to throw coins into big pot outside for luck - harder than it looks
Wow. Amazing buddha with a good story to tell, the site was not too busy and there are good explanatory exhibitions too.

Must to see, when in Bangkok. You can find this temple close to china town and 5 min walk from the main railway station/MRT. entrance fee is reasonable. The Golden Buddha is amazing, because it`s really big and made from gold. 15 min its enough to look around on this place, but don't miss!
Unique Temple. The Golden Buddha has a neat story that you can read in the guide books. The temple is beautiful and should be on the itinerary.

A Bangkok Essential. Simply seeing the golden statue, made of 5 1/2 tons of pure gold, just rocks you. It is an amazing sight to behold. The story of how it was hidden to protect it from invaders for years under layers of plaster/masonry is also interesting, including how it was discovered that it was made of pure gold. It is an imposing attraction and one not to be missed.

forget the tour guides. Visited this and other Temples via a guided tour. Would much rather have visited these own our own as found the tour rushed and the tour guide quite bossy. Problem is I cant remember the tour operators name.. either way get a tuk tuk to take u there and enjoy at your own pace
Basic Bangkok tour. Well worth seeing, if you go to Bangkok and don't check this out, shame on you! Take a cab to this site, they are incredibly inexpensive.

5 1/2 Ton Gold Buddha-Not to be Missed. The Buddha here is the major attraction and well it should be- 5 1/2 tons of gold housed on a beautiful tranquil site near Chinatown and the city center-rather amazing and spiritual
Must see. Is one of the things Must see in this city! Very beautiful! it's near the centre and so is easy go there

Golden Buddha. This was our first stop and again a sensory overload. The lack of security visible still amazes me and yet it all works. Well worth a visit and always look at roof and surrounding artifacts, They have amazing detail..
sleeping buddha. great experience travelling by boat to this location and pristine clean maintenance of the lovely construction.
Golden Buddha. A good sight to see a very large Buddha, all of the temples are brilliant amazing to know that this Buddha was covered in clay until they tried to move it and it was solid gold.

WOW. Was taken here by our Tuk-Tuk driver, and we were amazed at this site. Such peace and calm exudes from just looking at the mammoth statue of the golden buddha. Make sure you look around the complex, and don't just get back in your Tuk-Tuk.

one more bangkok temple. you have to visit buddhist temples while being in thailand and they have many in bangkok. They are all quiet impressive, but once you have seen a few, the rest are all just temples. This one is beautiful though.

Impressive temple with history of Chinese community. This temple, built between Bangkok's main railway station and the entrance to Chinatown, was erected to house a Buddha statue being moved from a temple north of BKK which was being closed. When the statue was dropped, a chunk of the plaster covering it broke off, revealing that it was, in fact, a 15-foot high solid gold statue. That's a whole lot of gold, and it's fashioned into a truly beautiful statue. On a floor lower down than the statue is a fascinating exhibition about the history of the Chinese community in Bangkok--a great introduction to an exploration of Chinatown itself.

a lot of history to take in. In order to really make the visit worth while, you need to do some preparatory work and understand the history. I ran into a local who gave me enough to really appreciate the temple. Of course he wanted to sell me some jewelery as well. Beware,,

£35m of solid gold..... Whatever you do in Bangkok please make sure this is in your list, you will be astounded by the majesty and beauty of this temple. The pure scale of this Buddha, the largest gold Buddha in the world, will take your breath away.

The bigest Golden Buddha of the world. This temple is called Wat Tri Mit name Thai means 3 Chinese man donation together to build a temple.The temple was built about 80 years, but the Golden Buddha Image is 3 meter tall 5.5 tons of gold Buddha is 18 karat gold. Golden Buddha statue in Sukhothai period were built about 700 years. Originally covered with plaster to hide them from being stolen Myanmar.Golden Buddha statue was found that the removal of gold from Wat Phraya Krai. During the transportation, it weighs much less, making the arm of a crane to lift the hammer down on the cement floor to cover the crack out. It was an accidental encounter gold. When we found with nine gold pieces, but later performed together as the current one.You can see from the trail are still visible to the shoulder, elbow and back of the body. The current Golden Buddha was situated in the new building on the fourth floor shape of this cross.Elderly people and people with disabilities have the service elevator in the back, on second floor a museum, but visitors must pay for my visit. After you visit this temple, can make a short walk toChinatown. Is open every day from 8.00 to 17.00 admission fee of 40 Baht.

It was our first way ( temple). After starting with the golden Buddha everything else had a hard act to followWe loved the story behind the Buddha... Lots of steps so you might like to do this one out of the heat of the day

must visit. for those who want to explore the greatness of Buddhist religion, the temple visit is a must. Not very far off from the hotel, take a taxi or use the city tour for this beautiful experience.
Golden Buddha. We toured 4 different temples, and this was one of my favorites because of the story behind it.It wasn't know that is was made of gold until later.

supper huggee gold infront of your eyes, but you cant bring home. =P. to be honest, I might be weird, but when I enter the temple, one thing on my mine was like... how am I going to rob this huge gold....and one day if the gold is missing, I might be the top suspect.it's just the buddha statue, really, but it is gold. like solid gold 5.5ton... I never feel so rich before, by just seeing a bling infront of my eyes...
Must see once. Beautiful golden buddha statue kept in a very well decorated temple.. It's a must see during your Bangkok trip. From the top you can also see some of adjacent temples..
It's ok. I really doubt it is 5 ton of gold sitting out in public besides once you see Emarald Budhha, Reclining Budhha, and Wat Arun.. you get it enough..everything else becomes "ok.
Bling Bling. The Temple of the Golden Buddha is well worth a visit. Beautiful. Gold. Shiny. Its great! A definite must see while touring Bangkok!
Worth a look. It was worth a visit if you are in the area, couldnt get into the tower to see the views but the buddha and the temples that surrond were very good. Free entry too.

Wow. I dont even remember how much the ticket was, it was so cheap. There is only one thing to see though and it is the giant Buddha made all from Gold and 5000kg of it. Amazing and in an amazing country with amazing people. Great!!
Worth the climb. Tis Temple Mount is a bit away from the main tourist trial but it is well worth the effort to get some spectacular views over the city.

Worth to see. I think after seeing couple of the temples, they are most likely to feel similar but not this one. Because it is made of gold. Not gold leaf or anything, solid gold. I've never seen this amount of gold in my life.
Beautiful. The Buddha is as large as you might expect for a 5 to Buddha! Definitely worth the visit. There are lots of crowds, but once you get inside you have time to see the Buddha.
Work of Art. A real work of art....really beautiful...not to be missed!! Next to China Town. Do come with a guide.
golden Buddah. i visited the temple and i was amazing of how big is the golden buddah and tried to take decent pic but now with lens everything is possible

Gold. this temple must be on your list. take plenty of water as these places get busy and hot plus dont forget your camera. They didnt know that this was solid gold because it was covered by some type of plaster and when it started to crack they could see the glint

Big Buddha. The story behind this Buddha is just as cool as the actual thing - they discovered it was solid gold not too long ago when they dropped the plaster Buddha they thought they had. The temple is pretty, but not as spectacular as the other temples in Bangkok. We didn't pay extra for the exhibits. No one checked our temple ticket.

this is another temple to visit. this temple must be on your list take plenty of water as these places get busy and hot plus dont forget your camera ,but you can buy pro pictures at all of the temples at a cheap cost
Really nice to see. So crazy that it's 3 meters tall and 5.5 tonnes of solid gold!! It's exciting to experience seeing it and being able to say you've been there.

Worth a look. Wat Traimit is just on the edge of Chinatown. I found the exterior of the Temple very light & bright & fairly impressive in a restrained style(for Thais). The Golden Buddha is a "must see" and to me looked small to be worth US$30 million plus. There were lots of tourists & buses as it is a very popular tourist site. While I was there an interesting exhibition about the founding and developing of the Bangkok chinese community.
Unbelievable. This is something you have to see to believe. Aside from the Golden Buddha, the temple surroundings are pretty spectacular as well.
Worth seeing. Won't take up much of your time but very inspiring to see, it is a temple so be warned people do visit to pray.

More scammers ouside. Another post to warn Bangkok travelers of a common scam. A friendly person standing outside the tourist attraction will ask you questions about your travels and ask if you have done something like a boat tour. In my case I got taken.I fell for this once and that was enough. The taxi driver was part of the scam along with the boat operators. The "tour" was supposed to include several stops but the motorman abandoned us at the first stop and tried to get out of taking us there. He wanted us to get off and take the ferry over. Word of advice: don't trust anyone who seems to be friendly because Bangkok is not.
Amazing history. The reclining Buddha is an amazing sight. The delicate pearl inlay at the feet just add to the grandeur of the site.
a must see. a trip to thailand would not be complete without a visit to this amazing site , we preferred a morning visit as a bit cooler and not so many tourists

Wat Traimit. We took the train then jutted over to silom station you get off at lamphomg station and walk a block.. This buddha weighs 5 tons and is absolutley Beautiful!! after this you can take a Tuk Tuk to the tallest building in Bangkok and walk back to the Central mall passing through small shops all along the street!!

Very interesting. This place has three levels. The very top has the golden Buddha - which is the worlds most valuable religious artifact. It's a very cool sight. The 2nd level has a short video clip followed by an airconditioned information walk through which outlines how the golden Buddha came about. The bottom level has a museum of china town and how the Chinese assimilated into Thailand society. This is a great tourist attraction.

Beautiful Buddha. The story behind the discovery of the largest solid gold Buddha in the world is fascinating. This is a 'must see' exhibition and temple for all visitors to Bangkok. The entry is very reasonably priced, photographs are permitted and the history is well documented in several displays...in both English and Thai. First class.
Interesting. Great exhibition beforehand explaining how they moved the buddha and discovered the gold underneath. The buddha itself is amazing, a must see if you go to Bangkok.

5 tons of pure gold!. It was amazing to see 5 tons of pure gold like that. We like it for its simplicity and there was not too much frills around it. I think People are supposed to admire it for its simple presentation as the pure gold speaks for itself the pureness of it all. It also wasn't as crowded as the other famous temples. Definitely worth a visit!
One of may buddha temples @ Bangkok. Impressive, captivating, peaceful. I personally felt a lot of positive vibrations in the sanctum sanctorum. Must see @ Bangkok
lovely. golden tranquil....huge buddha with an air of peace and quiet.....good souvenirs ...friendly guides....joss sticks and piety...a tuk tuk ride away from grand palace
Stunning!. Another must-visit site in Bangkok. The craftsmanship, the design, the location ... all great. Lovely. Don't forget your camera.

Nice trip - but too much hassling by souvenier vendors. There is a lot of hassling by souvenier sellers in Bangkok and none more so than around the various Temples. It just gets a bit too much in the end!

not as crowded as expected. late afternoon was there, pretty much empty, but a guide with is good idea , as there are some other temples at rear that are equally good , give yourself some time to wander around, dont do bus tour they just seem to stick to front bit.
Nice Place to visit. It's a temple, like the others - and just like the others, it has its own characteristics as well. Make sure you visit.

nice place. traffic is a bit chaotic
parking needs a lot of improvements
the temple itself is beautiful and at a height
souvenir shop is nice
a must see. never seen a giant golden buddah, or a tiny budday covered in jade or diamond cloth well i have and you should to, cannot remember the price, but its worth it and its beyond magnificent!!

Pure gold & made with revernece & love. What a beautiful statue made in solid gold. This is obviously made with dedication & love for their God. It's places like this which give you an insight to the pleasant, smiling & warm Thai culture.
Very interesting. We had a good guide on this trip, he gave us a detailed history of how this Buddha was made, hidden away and rediscovered again, it is one of the best Temples to see the Buddha.

No crowds!. Found this place by talking to a local who directed us there. No one was there apart from a former monk now living in America who was only too delighted to talk to us. No touts, no shops, no stalls. Lovely!

A Must see. This was a short walk from my hotel (15 minutes). But a bit of adventure to get there (only because I have a hard time following the signage in Thailand. But it also so worth it. If you are not up for the adventure you can always cab or take a Tuk Tuk. I went early and there lots of visitors but much less than peak times (it was already more crowded when I left). It is a compact space but quite inspiring.
Quite enjoyed this. We visited as part of another trip and that is probably the best way to do it. However, it is impressive and there are one or two other things to view in the vicinity.
Worth a visit!. In the country of 40,000 Wat(t)s, this is one of the 3 that make it to the top of this list... so dont miss it.

Great temple. A small yet serene temple in the heart of Chinatown. You can also purchase some authentic Thai amulets at the temple ground. I believe the temple is going to build another annex to it and is requesting for donations.

Breathtaking. Go to the Temple with a Tour Guide who will explain to you that this Budda was hidden from invaders during the war by covering it's 5.5 tons of gold with stucco...and so much more. Receive a blessing from a Monk...great place to exchange money also for a very reasonable price.

jaw dropping. This was our first temple visited in Thailand and found it amazingThe buddah itself is huge and mesmerising but the walls inside are all hand painted and you would think it was wall papered. The detail is just something to be seen.So glad we visited this one.
Beautiful!. I really loved this Temple and the story behind the Golden Buddha, this was my favorite in Bangkok! The colors on the Temple are incredible and the inside is simply stunning.

Stunning and impressive. For some reason, the first time we visited Bangkok, we had given Wat Traimit a miss, possibly because we had done major part of our sight-seeing via the Chao Phraya Tourist boat and Wat Traimit was missed out on.So this time, the Golden Buddha was the first on our list of places to visit and it was stunning! It started off though with an unpleasant experience, whereby we were accosted by some touts, right across the road from our hotel (sukhumvit area). It was the morning rush hour and our star hotel rightly advised us to take a cab from across the other side of the hotel. No sooner we had crossed the road, a gentleman approached us as a cop claiming to be incharge of the area, to ask if we required any assistance. On hearing our destination, he asked us not to visit the place before noon, as being a Sunday the monks were preparing and feeding lunch to poor people in the morning! And hence we should take a tuktuk from across the road (and one was conveniently parked there) to visit the Trade Centre. Having read and warned on the net, regarding such incidents, we thanked him and tried to walk away. And within a few seconds, a lady approached us and tried to befriend us as a nurse.....with the same story of lunch by the monks, Wat Traimit being closed till 1pm for visitors and pointing to the same tuk tuk who will show us around only for THB40 before taking us to Wat Traimit ! We ignored her ofcourse and walked away to take a cab to the Wat Traimit. And what a visual treat the Golden Buddha is. Its amazing and as if by magic, the unpleasant incident of the morning, was erased, as we looked with awe at the impressive Buddha made of gold. One can either climb the stairs of the temple or for the elderly and impaired, there is the option of an elevator too. Its a must visit in Bangkok, for sure.

Awe Inspiring. My Mom and I stared at the Golden Buddha for about 15 minutes before saying a word. I could not believe how huge it was! The temple is gorgeous, all of the hand-painted detailing on the walls was breathtaking. This is a must see!
Great Buddha. This is a great goldden boddha and well worth a visit, we went on a hot day but did not feel too hot while looking around this temple

Magnificent. Wat Traimit, also known as the Temple of the Golden Buddha, is home to the world’s largest gold statue, a gleaming, 3m-tall, 5.5 tonne Buddha image, the new temple structure is simply magnificent , this place must not be missed

wow!. saw lots of temples whilst in Thailand but this one, guess because its solid gold, was the most fascinating. Definitely worth seeing. Yes there will be tourists everywhere but its still worth it.
Amazing. The story alone makes the golden Buddha a special thing to see.It has a history all its ownand so shocking to discover.

Beautiful. The first thing we visited in Bangkok. Worth the walk and the visit. It is so beautiful. Be careful not to get taken advantage of by taxis in the area. Say where you want to go and say "no stops"...they will try to take you somewhere else or tell you things are closed.

The Buddha is the attraction. Easy to reach on the MRT to Hualampong Staion. Smallish compound without the variety of the Grand Palace grounds but magnificence of The Golden Buddha is really astounding. A real plus that one can get fairly up close & photograph it, unlike at the Temple of the Emerald Buddha

Sky-train then ferries to the temples was the most enjoyable way to sightsee!. If you haven't been to China, walk through China town on the way from the ferry. Don't listen to the "Info Looking" man outside who tells you to take a taxi because the river (ferries) is "shut down due to the President going through"!
Buddhas everywhere. You'll see a lot of buddhas almost everywhere in this area. You may also give donations for "different causes" above this temple.

A new temple in Wat Traimit. It's been 5 years since my last visit to Bangkok , so it was a pleasant surprise for m,e to see a new massive temple housing the Golden Buddha. While I like the rustic charm of the old small temple , the new temple is a fitting place where the revered image should be enshrined. A compact temple coumpound I would never tire of visiting everytime I am in Bangkok.
Place of worship. Worth a visit, great architecture, amazing details. Can take a tuk tuk to travel there or great a taxi, or be apart of a group organized visit.

Beautiful and peaceful. We walked in there and felt the peace and beauty of the place! In the complex was a small temple where there was a life like statue of the famous monk sitting peacefully and chanting was on. The experience was beautfiful and surreal!

Mesmerising. I visited this place exactly when the prayers were happening, wow I was literally Mesmerisied. The entire place has a beautiful vibration. But when you come out and take a tuk-tuk or cab be careful they cheat you.

Beautifull as they all are. First went here in 2009, when it was not completed, it was impressive from the outside.Went there with my wife, (she is Thai) and was very impressed with the inside, the golden Buddha, is stunning. I paid the extra to see the two exhibitions, on the lower two floors, very interesting and informative (Thai don't have to pay, which is the way it should be, unlike the UK, where us locals are screwed over!!!!).It is well worth visiting, and China Town is only 5 mins walk, from here
Golden Buddha. Would recommend this temple as it is one of the only temples where you are permitted to take photographs inside the temple.

The Golden Buddha. Fantastic. The beauty of the image overshadows the fact that it comprises five and half tons of gold! The history is highly interesting. Hope to be able to see it once again in the not too distant future.

Interesting. Visited the Gold Buddha while I was in Bangkok. Wandering in and around everything takes about an hour. Tickets are paid for at a kiosk next to the temple. I bought two ... one for the museum and one for the actual Golden Buddha portion.There are a couple parts to the exhibit. The first floors are a museum dedicated to understanding the Chinese infuluence in Bangkok. Didn't explain it very well, but I assumed this was where the Buddist influence in Thailand came from. There is a short movie at the beginning of the tour ... 70% propaganda, 30% interesting fact ... skip it. The very top level is the actual Golden Buddha image. Worth a look. Standard street vendors trying to sell silk images or umbrellas. Good stuff to take home ... I'd start haggling at 1/4 whatever they're asking.

Larger than life.... The Golden Buddha is a must see in Bangkok. Make sure you have a lot of time on hand to explore, again better to go on your own instead of a organised tour. This way you will not be rushed and you will be able to see more....
Nice but.... It was a nice temple complex, but defrinetly not my favorite in the city, pressed for time visit Wat Pho as the time is better spent and so much more to see!

A lovely Wat with the world's largest piece of solid gold. It is difficult to go to Wat Triamitre without concentrating on the gold statue of The Buddha to the exclusion of all else there. The neighborhood is lovely, the newly-rehabbed buildings there are (finally!) up to snuff, even the brass temple bells, painted to seem as if covered in leather and held up by small Garudas are fascinating...all that can be lost in the face of that amazing, shockingly-large $299million Buddha of solid gold sitting there without guards, without alarms, without even closed doors!
Small but friendly. Nice but small temple - not bad and in easy reach of Big two temples if they are overly busy or closed

its sure shiny. the temple is impressive. tall steps, marble floors. as soon as you see the buddha, you cant believe its solid gold and been kept secretly for years. after your spin around the buddha, your out of the temple and that's it. kinda anti climatic but there are more temples to see.

Its giant Budha. The place not too big...but d statue so high. I didnt plan 2 come here but d tuk-tuk driver stop me here. They offer free charge when using their car.... but then they took us 2 many places dat we dont want 2 visit, like silk shops, jewelleries shops, souvenir shops...al d price very expensive....but d quality also gud....but feel guilty when U not buy coz Ur tuktuk driver will get more tipos when we bought der. But even we not buy its okk... d tuktuk driver still get free fuel from every shop we visited.

Stunning. The golden buddah is situated in a recently built temple. It is 5500kg of solid gold! Beautiful!You an ignore all of the hawkers and photo vendors that cluster around the base of the temple steps, although my wife did buy a parasol for 200 baht ( the initial asking price was 700 baht)

A hidden gem. We knew this was here but it took us a while to find it. It is very close to Shanghai Mansion, just down the road but well hidden, we only noticed it because of the tourist buses parked outside the temple walls. This was by far the most magnificent Buddha in Bangkok and a must. There is a good information gallery and the staff were really friendly. This was the only place that we were hassled with people trying to sell us stuff which was amazing really as you can't find the site easily.
Amazing. This was the first temple we saw in Bangkok. The temple was amazing. The golden buddha was beautiful and the story behind its travels was interesting.

Beautiful temple. I thought this was an absolutely breathtaking temple. The solid gold Buddha statue is very impressive and so are its surroundings inside the temple. I think I enjoyed this temple more than any of the others I visited during my stay in Thailand.
Incredable. Dont miss this atteaction. The size of this Buddha and the fact it is solid gold is mind blowing. The history behind this statue is also very interesting. Well worth the effort.
Newer refurbished temple. Good refurbishment with air conditioners etc. Very touristy as the main attraction was the 5.5 ton of pure gold Buddha. Located in Chinatown.

What a lump of solid gold!. This is a relatively new temple, which displays what is said to be the largest solid-gold buddha in the world. It is impressive, and spent a large part of its life covered in concrete, until it was being moved and was dropped, and the concrete cracked, revealing the golden statue.Almost as impressive is the speed with which the enterprising locals will try to take your photo and then reproduce it as part of a souvenir which they will want to sell to you before you leave. The closer you get to the exit, the cheaper the price will be! If you are feeling reasonably energetic, then it is not too far to walk into Chinatown from the Wat.

A short stop would do if you have extra time.... The only interesting thing is the Golden Buddha itself but should you have to choose between the Leaning Buddha or the Emerald Buddha at the Royal Palace, I would recommend the latter two.

The most beautiful of the temples. There is little doubt that by the time you leave Bangkok you wibe templed out! There are just so many. However the Golden Buddha has the most amazing and vast display of architecture and if it is not too crowded it is quite pleasant wandering around. The sheer size is overwhelming but definitely a must even if you only see one temple whilst in Bangkok.
