Amazing history with many mysteries.... Weighing more than 5 tons, the largest gold Buddha image in the world makes an incredible statement about giving up wealth to create a spiritual object. Even at 5 tons the image consists of 176,000 ounces of gold...about US$285 million at today's prices!The story behind the Buddha is nothing less than extraordinary. No one knows who cast the huge gold image during the Sukhothai era of the Thai kingdom in the 13th century (the date is theorized based on its artistic style). Nor is is known how such a huge quantity of pure gold was acquired to cast a single image -- an extravagant gesture for a young expanding kingdom that must have needed funds for government buildings, defense, trade, infrastructure like roads, irrigation and schools, and countless other projects. But the essentially priceless object was cast...and then it disappeared in plain sight!At some point in the ensuing centuries -- evidently to hide it from enemies (most likely the Burmese) -- someone covered the statue with tar and plaster. Incredibly everyone connected with this act died or chose to keep the secret. The gold inside was totally forgotten until the statue was cracked during a move on May 25, 1955. Since then, the statue has inspired millions as an icon of the birth of the Thai nation.On Sep 22 2008, HRH Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn and the royal consort HRH Princess Srirasmi presided over the ceremony to install the Buddha in its new image hall at Wat Traimit. Just below are two museums with excellent displays about the history of the image and the growth and importance of the surrounding Chinatown area.Full admission for foreigners is 140 baht and photos are permitted. For those of Thai, Buddhist and Chinese heritage this is an essential pilgrimage. For all other visitors it's an amazing sight that raises many provocative questions about ancient times.
don't miss this one. We really enjoyed our visit to this Temple and though you need to be mindful of conservative dressing it is worth the effort. the buildings are a photographers dream.
A little spoilt but worth a visit. They have finished the new temple and it is a little garish inside which detracts from the Buddha which is spectacular.
Average. I did not find it as good as the countless other attractions in Thailand, I did not get a chance to see the Jade Buddha but I think that would be better
Beautiful. Our guide let us know the importance of this temple and let us know its importance which is good to be told because such beauty and wealth in such a filthy city is hard to justify.

An wonderful ancient creation. Once we arrived at the Wat Taimit, we just can't help ourself taking lots of photos. It like when we last visited the great wall of China. The status and building were built in a such a wonderful art pieces. It's a must for tourist to visit.

SURPRISING. In Chinatown....out of the way for most tourists....must use a taxi. The Buddha is in a simple room, that looks like someone's apartment. But the statue is certainly worth seeing. Then you can shop in Chnatown, but watch out for traffic. Buy saffron and cashews.

Amazing. Beautiful Solid gold Buddha statue. The new Pagoda is amazing and the museum is also really interesting. For someone who has been visiting Wat Traimit my whole life I learnt a lot about the history of Chinatown in Bangkok at the museum. Highly recommended!

Magnificient. The history of this budha is fascinating and the temple that they have created to house it magnificient. The Thai people know how to create beautiful works of art that show their dedication to the budhist way of life.

Superb Temple !!. Date : November 2011
I visited temple with my friends.
Temple is three floor building, and the Golden Buddha is situated at 3rd floor.
Just outside the Temple on 3rd floor there is a big bell.
Buddha temple is very quite place.
temple has very good architecture all aournd the temple.
Must visit this temple.

Very Impressive !. Beautiful temple with the impressive Golden Buddha made from solid gold- I think about 6 tonnes. Right in the heart of China Town, the entry fee was 40 bahts. There was a visitor centre on the first floor which we didn't bother with. The main temple is beautiful and the golden statue very impressive. It was kind of very peaceful and really enjoyed sitting inside the temple admiring the statue. Definitely worth the visit.

From insignificant to awesome. The Golden Buddha can now be seen in a marvelous new temple erected near the old site. The former temple was not really worth a visit, but the new structure is a piece of art. Well worth a detour if you're in Bangkok.Entry fee: 40 baht for the Golden Buddha (access to the whole temple except for the exhibition which costs an extra 100 baht)

GOLDEN WONDER..!. This attraction should need no introduction, but ! here goes anyway. The golden Buddha sits in a new building/temple and is on the upper floor, when you enter as always you have to remove your shoes and walk through via a little museum detailing how this iconic image came about. As we all know the story of the Golden Buddha being encased in cement to hide it from warring tribes 400yrs ago, and the Buddha being discovered accidentally when some cement fell off to the shock of everyone at the time.When you have finished here you will find there are lifts for the disabled as its two flights of stairs up..! On arriving upstairs you enter the temple and are confronted by this magnificent image looking down at you, all around are many people praying with this in mind as long as you respect the Buddhist's praying you can walk quietly right around this 22,000lb of solid golden image and take as many photos as you want. And spend as much time here too , but as we were on a tight schedule we got roughly 30 mins but, even at that you get a real feeling of peacefulness around you . And yes it was busy but in a quiet way, outside there was a very discreet stall selling everything Buddhist if you want anything, also there are several flights of stairs leading down to the main street but, remember the lifts are there too. This Temple is well worth a visit and is very easy to find as it's next to China town , it's one of these must do things while in Bangkok..!

Gorgeous. One word - Gorgeous. You will not like to leave the place. Its so quiet and very calming that you just want to stay there for hours. We were on a tight schedule or else I would have loved to be there for good few hours. Again one of the most famous buddha statues in the world, you have to see this to believe in its beauty. A must do for every traveller.

Impressive. The golden Buddha is well worth the visit. The Buddha itself is very impressive, the largest one we saw in Thailand, and one of the largest anywhere, and knowing it is made of gold makes it even more impressive. There is also a museum describing the history of the Chinese people in Thailand and their relationships with the Thai people and government which I found interesting. Finally there is a section describing the history and making of the Buddha image itself.It is easy enough to get to, just around the corner from the Hua Lamphong railway station and MRT. It's also on the edge of Chinatown so lunch is taken care of as well.

Well worth a visit. We visited this statue in June. We walked from Chinatown in order to find this temple.This statue is now situated in a new impressive building, the last time we came to Bangkok it was situated in a older smaller building close by which was closed on the day we came. This newer building I believe does this statue more justice and will bring more visitors. This staute is only small compared to others, however it is made out of pure gold. We only paid 30 baht to go up the steps to see the statue. If you are in the Chinatown area this is well worth a visit and you will not be disappointed.
Golden Buddha in Bangkok. there is NO entrance fee. The entrance fee is only for the exibition/museum on the first level. The visit of the buddha is free. Don't be fooled.
small but interesting temple. i've visited this temple as last but i loved this temple because i could interact with locals which was my favorite part of the day :)

Worth a quick visit on your trip to Bangkok - before you tire of Buddhas!. We took a tuk tuk ride to the Temple of the Golden Buddha on a hot and steamy Bangkok morning. The building it's housed in is lovely, but the gardens aren't great.The buddha itself doesn't take too long to pop in and see and take a few photos of. There were a few quietly worshipping whilst we were there - but even with a few pedestal fans blowing, it was fairly oppressive.The outer courtyard also houses many buddhas and their stories are all there to read, so it's not just the Golden Buddha housed here.
Precious & Massive. This temple of Golden Buddha has got most precious & massive Golden Buddha made of 5.5 tons of Gold. This holy place is very peaceful and worth watching.

Very impressive. The impressive fact about this statue of Buddah is that it is made of gold. i've seen other statues which are just as large, if not larger, but the worth of this one is what makes it so interesting to view.

Depends upon your tastes, I imagine. The temple is located on the Eastern edges of Chinatown, an easy walk from Hualamphong metro station. The grounds of the temple are, in my opinion, rather ordinary. The building that the Buddha is housed in is on the impressive side (see photo as well as short video I've posted). You pay something like 400 baht ($1.50) and climb to the top to see the Golden Buddha inside. You can also pay an extra 1000 baht (a little over $3) and tour some "museum" related to the history of the temple. For some reason, the Buddha statue itself wasn't quite as big as I imagined it would be, but then it's purported to be solid gold (or something along those lines), so anything larger than a fist would be impressive, I suppose. I'm giving this a low rating for the following reason: I felt that the statue and the shrine that housed it held little sense of tranquility or sacredness to it. It truly did feel to me like a tourist attraction and little else. I'm likely biased in this regard, but in my travels, most temples in Japan, for example, have a deep aura of peace, reverence, and quietness to them that draws me into a contemplative state of mind. This place had none of that for me. It could have been the tacky Chinese music blaring through the speakers of the shrine (you can hear it on the video I've posted). Or it could be how most visitors just take a few pictures, then saunter around. Although a few will make prayers and offerings, I just couldn't connect to that sense of awe or reverence here.

wow. Wat Traimit is located in the Chinatown area of Bangkok. The Buddha is over 9ft and weighs 5 and a half tons of solid gold. It's open between 9 to 5 daily. The admission is 20 baht. I was there in 2002 and the buddha was housed in a very modest temple.When I was there on 8/12/09 they were in the process of building a new temple so we couldn't see the Buddha.We were told the new temple would be finished sometime in december of 2009.

A National Treasure. The Golden Buddha is one of the treasures of Bangkok. It is probably the largest lump of gold in the world. At over five tons, its gold value alone exceeds $100 million. The story of its discovery (from under a plastered shell) is well known, but , just the same, it must be seen to be believed. It is near Hualamphong Train Station, so if you are going anywhere by train, stop by and take a look . You'll never forget the experience.

Quick China Town Stop. We were suffering from jet lag and a bit out of sorts waiting for our Rice Barge Tour (which was fun) at the River City mall. A taxi driver offered to take us on a tour of China Town, 50 baht. It was air conditioned and there wasn't much traffic (Songkraw week), so we went. We stopped at the Golden Budda. It was our first temple and budda experience! The site was quaint with vendor booths and other opportunities to spend money. A good first temple tour.China Town was largely empty for the holiday, but we got a glimpse of the area. The taxi driver then proceeded to take us to a jewelry store and tailor so he could get gas coupons! The driver was from Laos and very pleasant. He wasn't able to go home for the holiday, so we were happy to do him a favor. Besides, we got to experience the classic taxi driver, jewelry store, and tailor scams the first day of our trip! It's what Thailand is, for better or worse.

Hmmm another buddha.... Yes Bangkok is full of them. Why is this one different well, its made of gold theres a bunch of gongs outside which some annoying little child walks around hitting and theres a rip-off charge, we had someone trying to charge us whilst we left. Two good things, its location is close to some good markets and it doesn't make a bad photo.
